results.description:
Bring your laptop, current project(s), and prepare to make some progress! Folks have walked away grinning from our previous project nights after solving problems that had been frustrating them for a while. We'll do introductions around 6:30pm to get a sense of the skill set in the room, then settle in to work.

These sessions are super-informal and low-key. We always have attendees of all experience levels--don't feel like you have to be "good" or know "something" before you can come hang out with us. If you feel like the term pre-beginner applies to you, project nights are a great time to meet other code-curious women and start figuring out what you need to learn to start working toward your goals. We guarantee that you'll meet someone who will nerd out about what you are interested in and make you excited to start tinkering.

On hand to help out will be:

Paige Eaton is a librarian turned Drupal developer. She loves sports, games, and long walks on the beach, but not too long. It's really tiring to walk on sand. Paige is helpful for questions about UX, HTML, CSS, some PHP, and is a good listener/sounding board for ideas & projects.

Jessica Pang is an interactive designer at ExtensionEngine, a web/mobile app development company. She has spent the past 3 years there working on projects from the ground up. Jessica has experience in wire framing, branding, user experience design, and user interface design.

Radhika Malik is a full stack web developer at Panorama Education, an edtech company. Her recent experience has been with HTML, CSS, Javascript and Ruby but she comes from a broad CS background and is happy to work with you to crack any coding problem you might be stuck in!

Reasons why you should come work with us:

Accountability: it's the perfect way to get away from it all (other work, family/housemates, the laundry) and work.

Nerd friends: you'll meet other women who are coding and creating awesome stuff.

Practice: it's an opportunity to practice some of the skills you've picked up if you've taken some of our classes.

Brain exchange: you can ask your neighbor for help on a bug or teach a n00b how to do something you've mastered.

No agenda: Have non-technical work to do? Need a sounding board? Looking for feedback? Just want to get your inbox under control? You're welcome too!

Perks:

+ Fast, reliable internet

+ Fancy, schmancy (i.e., comfy) Aeron chairs

+ Way more fun than working in a coffee shop =)


Location

14th floor, Room Charles

Cambridge Innovation Center

1 Broadway

Cambridge, MA 02142

T Stop: Kendall / MIT

Street parking is available on Broadway St., Third St., and Main St.


Access

Please bring photo ID. Upon entering 1 Broadway you'll check in with security. Tell them you're visiting the 14th floor.

Doors open at 6:15pm; if you arrive before 6:15pm, please wait in the 1st floor lobby, as no one will be available to let you in upstairs.

Once you depart the elevator, you'll find glass doors that are locked. Look for the door sign.

We're meeting in the room labeled Charles.
results.name: Project Night

results.description:
>>RSVP and Ticket ($10) Required - Click here to purchase tickets!<<

Please join us for the first Stanford Medicine X Pop-Up in Boston! Thanks to Mad*Pow for hosting a night of discussions on patient-centered design!

Schedule:

6:15 PM - Check-in, Networking, Tech Demos, and Light Snacks

7:00 PM - Welcoming Remarks by Dr. Larry Chu, Executive Director, Stanford Medicine X

7:10 PM - ePatient Ignite! Presentation by Sarah E. Kucharski, Coordinator of ePatient Programs, Stanford Medicine X

7:15 PM - Medicine X | Ed Ignite! Presentation by Dhruv Khullar, Resident Physician, Massachusetts General Hospital

7:20 PM - Introduction to Boston Region Events by Alicia Staley, Medicine X Boston Community Organizer

7:30 PM - Keynote Address by Catherine Rose, Pediatric Innovator and Founder, LightAide

7:50 PM - Panel Discussion on Patient-Centered Design, moderated by Alicia Staley, and featuring panelists:

• Catherine Rose, Pediatric Innovator and Founder, LightAide

• Sarah E. Kucharski, Coordinator of ePatient Programs, Stanford Medicine X

• Amy Cueva, Founder, Chief Experience Officer, and Health Principle at Mad*Pow

8:20 PM - Closing Remarks by Dr. Larry Chu and Alicia Staley

8:30 PM - Tech Demos and Networking

About Stanford Medicine X:

Stanford Medicine X programs aim to connect all stakeholders to innovate healthcare at the intersection of emerging technologies and medicine. 

Medicine X is a catalyst for new ideas about the future of medicine and health care. The initiative explores how emerging technologies will advance the practice of medicine, improve health, empower patients to be active participants in their own care, and more. Learn more about Medicine X by visiting our website: medicinex.stanford.edu

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tNi8BIIH-xo
results.name: Medicine X - Boston Pop-Up!

results.description:
It's letter and number tile night! Do you have games that we can have fun with? Bring them tonight!

Come join the C&C crew over for a night of Letter Tile Games. Bring Banana Grams, Scrabble, Boggle, Upwords, Appleletters and any other letter game and let the fun begin.  

We'll also be playing number tiles too like Rummikub and Dominos.

Although we start around 6:30pm or so, early birds (before 6pm) can take advantage of their half-price happy hour menu. These are full-portion sized appetizers for real cheap! If not, you'll still be able to take advantage of the monthly specials.

HOW TO GET THERE

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex. Here is a map of the area.

By Subway: Take the Orange Line to Wellington. Walk over the skybridge and cross through the parking lot. Upon exiting the garage, you'll see a building complex (SL75) across the street. Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. There are a number of stores in the Station Landing complex -- look for the Margarita's, Starbucks or Not Your Average Joe's signs. NYAJ is located right off of Rte. 28. Although there is free parking all around the building, we recommend that C&C members park in the garage underneath the restaurant.

See you there!!
results.name: LETTER and NUMBER TILE NIGHT

We meet at the Food Court at Boston University.

At 8:00, we usually walk to the Super 88 Food Court for dinner.

results.description:
For this meetup we are excited to be joined by some great speakers! Brian Hess, Sr Product Manager for Analytics at DataStax will be presenting on Cassandra+Spark and Carl Yeksigian, Cassandra Dev at DataStax will be presenting on upcoming features to expect in Cassandra 3.0. We will also be joined by a few folks from the Spotify/Echo Nest team who will be presenting on their use cases.

Full Agenda:

6:30PM:Food/Drinks + Networking

6:45PM: Spotify Cassandra Use Case

7:00PM: Cassandra + Spark

7:30PM: Cassandra 3.0

Directions & Parking:

We are in Davis Square, just next to Boston, MA, USA. The easiest way to get to Spotify is the MBTA Subway. We are right behind the Davis Square stop of the Red Line T. From the main building entrance go down the set of stairs to the first floor and walk to the end of the hallway, we’re the last door on the left just before the end of the hall.

Public Transportation

Take the Red Line to Davis Square. As you exit the station, follow the "College Ave" signs. At street level, there are doors straight ahead and to your left. Take the doors on the left. Turn left. The street you are on is marked "For Buses Only" and should only have buses, pedestrians and bicyclists on it. Walk to the end of the block with Davis Square behind you. The brick building to your left is our building — 48 Grove Street. The entrance is at the end of the block.


Parking


There is metered parking available at the Rite Aid lot next to the building 8am-8pm. There are also reserved business spaces that are open after 5pm in the back of the Rite Aid lot.

*A big thank you to Aaron and the rest of the Spotify/Echo Nest team for hosting! Food and drinks will be served, hope to see you all there.
results.name: Cassandra+Spark, Cassandra 3.0, and Cassandra at Spotify

results.description:
CHUCK WILL BE THE HOST FOR THIS WEEK WHILE  JZ IS AWAY.  CLIMB ON!

Let's climb at Central Rock Gym in Watertown! Meet by the cubbies/bench facing the rock wall (they will be on the right as you enter). I (JZ) am usually wearing green and have a blue harness and climbing shoes.  We usually climb for ~3 hrs and welcome all skill levels.  If you come late, come find us or ask the CRG staff for help.  They know we climb on Tuesdays and can help you find the group.

You will need to fill out the rock gym waivers and TAKE their Belay test, if you haven't already.

Day Passes
- $20 Adult*
- $16 Student/Military
* There are also punch-cards available to get 10 Day-Passes for the price of 9 visits

Gear Rental
- $8 Full Package
- $5 Harness
- $5 Shoes
- $2 Chalk
- $2 Belay Device

Membership options and further details are available on the website. You can also fill out a waiver online to save on paperwork when you arrive at the gym.
http://www.centralrockgym.com/watertown.php
results.name: Central Rock Watertown Tuesday

results.description:
Spend some time on your project by bringing it along to our weekly project night, an evening designed around you and what you're working on.

This weekly event is about finding time to tinker, being creative, and meeting other members of the community.  You'll get the chance to see what others are working on, share your projects, and to get inspiration and feedback from fellow tinkerers.

On any given Tuesday night you have people working on electronics, knitting, writing code, wood-working, or just their plans for world domination. Beer is also consumed.

We’ll provide: space to work, basic tools, power, a room full of like minded people.

You’ll provide: your project, ideas and beer. A laptop would probably be useful too.

Sometimes we work on group projects together, which are usually set up as separate meetup events. Keep an eye on our events page to see what we’re working on next.

Find us: http://p.irateship.com/treasuremap.html
results.how_to_find_us: We are in the same building as Little India Market (next to Market Basket) - but at opposite end of the building. Door is left of the painted Pirateship mural.
results.name: Hackspace Project Night

results.description:
https://www.google.com/maps/dir/ - for Google Maps

Directions from YOUR starting point...

Until further notice, we're in Kresge 201 (which has been newly-refurbished), at the top of the open stairwell near the guard's desk near the Countway Courtyard entrance to the Kresge Building.

Fred (ZHOU Hanlin) and Justin Kwan host these friendly meetups (in Kresge 201).  
Enter as you have long done; then walk UP the open stairway near the security guard's desk.

results.description:
We start off chatting about our work, including setting goals for ourselves (which is entirely optional but super helpful!), and then we write. That's what it's all about. As simple as the idea is, it's amazing how much more you can get done simply by being in the presence of other writers at work. The baked goods don't hurt, either.


There is power for laptops, and some of us use pen and paper. Your choice! Bonus: there's no Internet access, so you can omit a huge distraction without even trying. And, although we are not a discussion group, there are many areas where people can go if they want to talk without being disruptive.

Please click here for detailed directions! The school can be a bit of a maze and I don't want anybody getting lost.
results.name: Quite Write: Writing Night!

results.description:
Fruit Hunters
Eco-Film Series: The Fruit Hunters

Trailer: http://youtu.be/ANUPINHT5dI

When: Tuesday, November 17, 2015, 6:30 pm
Where: Lowell National Historical Park Visitor Center, 246 Market St.
The Fruit Hunters travels across culture, history and geography to show how intertwined we are with the fruits we eat. Our guides are devoted fruit fanatics. This film is a cinematic odyssey through nature and commerce, The Fruit Hunters will change not only the way we look at what we eat but how we view our relationship to the natural world.

Although we had to post-pone the showing of this film from May, we're excited to offer it November 17 as a kick-off to our winter Eco-film series! The Eco-film series is offered in partnership with the Lowell Film Collaborative, Lowell National Historical Park, and our primary sponsors: Mill City Environmental and Eno, Martin, & Donahue.

Email [masked] to RSVP

Getting to the Visitor Center
From Interstate Route 495 take Exit 35C on to the Lowell Connector
From Route 3 take Exit 30A if traveling southbound, Exit 30B if traveling northbound.

• Take the Lowell Connector to Exit 5B Thorndike Street.
• Continue right on to Thorndike Street, which becomes Dutton Street.
• At the third traffic light continue straight under the overpass.
• At the next light turn right into the Visitor Center Parking Lot. Free parking is available here during Park operating hours in the gated section of the lot with ticket validation at the Visitor Center.
• From the lot, follow the set of steps located behind the flag pole and continue walking through the courtyard. The Visitor Center will be on your left.

results.description:
Join Therapist Sally Plone, Parenting Coach Kathy Whitham, and Financial Consultant Deanna Coyle for a special parent only viewing and discussion of the documentary Split, Divorce Through Kids' Eyes. The goal for this event is to come together as a community of separated/divorced or divorcing adults to watch, ask questions and share insight about the film. This nurturing and confidential environment will allow individuals to feel secure enough to share their personal stories, fears and challenges. This powerful film, made exclusively from the point of view of children aged 6-13, explores the often frightening and always life altering separation of their parents. Watching this documentary will provide new insight on how to talk to your kids.

There is no charge for this event. Complimentary light bites, wine and other refreshments will be provided for your enjoyment through the event.

results.description:
After a one week hiatus, the Mystery Speaker Series returns with Mystery Speaker #4 on November 17th!

Every Tuesday, Branchfood hosts an entrepreneur to tell the story of how they launched a successful food enterprise (#BOSFoodStories). This recurring series debuted Oct 20th with Mark Andrus from Stacy’s Pita Chips, and continued with Nicolas Warren from Perfect Fuel on Oct 27th, and Niari Keverian from Zoos Greek Iced Tea on Nov 3rd.

Our FOURTH mystery speaker continues our kick-ass female founder theme. Join us to learn about early challenges of launching a food biz, what it’s like to be a female entrepreneur in a male dominated field, how to find capital and investors, and how to get your product into major vendors in the Boston Area.

Mystery Speaker #4 will present on November 17th. This is an intimate event limited to 30 attendees. Tickets are available for $10 on Eventbrite. Please RSVP early to ensure your spot. A special thank you to Sam Adams for sponsoring this series!

Mystery Speaker #4
November 17th, 6:30 PM
CIC, 50 Milk Street, Boston

Hey now, don’t get your “pants” in a twist! We have a few clues about the Mystery Speaker right here. Any guesses?

• “Fancying” herself as quite the baker, this female entrepreneur started making these treats out of her small, cramped Boston apartment in 2004.

• Together with her co-founder (a former teacher), she decided to quit her job in statistical analysis to dedicate herself to the business full-time.

• After ten years running her business, her efforts have certainly paid off as these treats are now available in major grocery stores in New England.

• Health-conscious foodies can rest easy, because these treats are non-GMO project verified and nut-free, and are made by hand at their factory in Walpole.

Join us to hear this entrepreneur's #BOSFoodStory on 11/17. Mystery speakers will be revealed the day of the event.

Intrigued? See you there!

Lauren, Sarah, and Ally @ Branchfood
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be in the Einstein Room on the 16th Floor.
results.name: Mystery Speaker Event #4

results.description:
The last journal club on Gene drives was great! Thank you for participating in building this thoughtful discussion.

For the next session we’ll talk about an advanced synthetic biology feat. We will dive into an intricate story involving viruses, bacteria and yeasts! The paper is called Engineering Modular Viral Scaffolds for Targeted Bacterial Population Editing.  


http://www.cell.com/cell-systems/abstract/S2405-4712(15)00111-8


The agenda for the journal club: 

- Short overview of the paper to understand the scope of this work.  
- Go over the paper figure by figure. So everyone understand what exactly what was done and how it was done. 
- Free form discussion.


Previous reading of the paper is not required but much advised. It will help you not to get lost. As well some prior knowledge of basic biological concepts will be very useful for you to follow: what are genes, the central dogma of DNA -> RNA -> Proteins, and some general understanding of how viruses infect cells. 

See you all soon!
The Boslab team

Location

From now on our journal club will take place in the MIT Center for Biomedical Engineering (500 Technology Square Cambridge), room 189 (to the left from the main entrance). It is a big building with rounded corners windows, to the left from Technology Square.  The doors are automatically locked around 6:30PM. If you are lost or got late call (256)[masked], someone will let you in.
results.name: Journal Club: Engineering Modular Viral Scaffolds

results.description:
Valerie Hammond will be leading this meditation.

The Seated Awareness Meditation includes breath awareness, body awareness, sound awareness, thought awareness, and choiceless (open) awareness. In partnership with the Cambridge Ten Thousand Villages store, MindfulBoston teachers and teacher-trainees will be leading a series of Meditation events in the coming months as a service to our community.

Place:
The Cambridge Ten Thousand Villages is located at
694 Massachusetts Avenue
Central Square, Cambridge 02139
Time:
6:45pm to 8pm

Schedule:
There will be an informal schedule.
At about 6:45pm we'll set up some seats and have a chat about what meditation is about. This is the official start time for our event.

The front door will be locked by 7:01. Make sure to arrive either on-time or early!
The store's registers will be closed by 7:05 so that employees can join us in meditation.

How to reserve your space:

Please rsvp here or call the store to rsvp. There are no "tickets" but we would like a head count in order to prepare a big enough space for sitting together.

Note: we typically have up to 30 people attend these events. RSVPing is pretty important because we need to move bookcases around to fit everybody in the space. Thanks! 

Seating:
If you have hip/knee or other reasons to need a chair, make sure to rsvp here and say 'reserve a chair' in your comments.
There are seven folding chairs and a few low stools. Zafu style cushions are sometimes available if the store has some in stock. But there are no guarantees. Most of us will be sitting on the floor. Feel free to bring your own pillow with you. What is planned:
The hour (or so) that we spend together will include: discussion about awareness and mindfulness meditation, and an experience of seated awareness meditation. The length of the meditation itself will probably be about 15 to 20 minutes long. No previous experience is required, the meditation will be easy for beginners to understand.
results.name: Community Meditation Night- Seated Awareness Meditation

results.description:
How many times have you heard someone complain that whoever they meet online is not a good fit. Or that they’re not meeting anybody? Have you complained about online dating? 


You're not alone. There are a lot of men and women who are suffering – needlessly - because of how they’re going about the whole online dating thing (and they don't realize that this experience that they are having is f-i-x-a-b-l-e). 

But…you also hear about all these people who are connecting with great people online, right? Lots of dates. And the dates are awesome. They're having a great time. Both scenarios are happening… All. The. Time. 

So maybe you’ve been on the “This ain’t workin’!” side of the equation, and you want to join the “Wow, this is rockin’!” gang… If so, you’ll want to be there for a very informative evening where you’ll learn what those people are doing who are having fun, meeting great men and women, and all as a result of online dating. 

Come…join us! Learn how you can rock your online dating adventure!

Presenter: Karen Jones, founder of The Heart Matters, has been a relationship coach since 1997, and has helped countless women end up in scrumptious relationships. She is a very big fan of online dating…if it’s done right (and she loves to help women get it right!). To learn more about Karen, please visit her website: www.TheHeartMatters.com 

Doors open at 7 - Event begins at 7:30, and goes until 9

Wine and cheese reception following the event

Fee: $25 per person (or bring a friend and you both pay $20)
results.name: How to ROCK your Online Dating Adventure!

results.description:
This Reiki Share is for you if you have been attuned as a Reiki Practitioner it is a powerful group Reiki session for all level Reiki Practitioners. A safe, supportive, nurturing and positive space is created for us to develop, practice and give back Reiki with like-minded friends. It is a great time to give yourself a tune-up and relish in Reiki.  Each practitioner will have the opportunity to give and receive Reiki during this relaxation and rejuvenating Reiki Share. Contact me if you have questions.

  Reiki Share Agenda

• The 1st 15 minutes of each share we will have time to connect with friends and introduce new members, allowing time to center and prepare for our Reiki sessions.

• It is our goal that each practitioner will have the opportunity to relish in 20 to 30 minutes of Reiki; dependent on how many practitioners are present for the share. 

• We will make every effort to synchronize each session allowing for the highest healing good of each person.

• Quiet discussion of the sessions may be shared quietly while your group is preparing for the next person.

• The room will be available at the conclusion of the Reiki Share so that you can socialize, give feedback and network with like-minded friends.

  Reiki Share Guidelines

• RSVP so that we may plan for adequate space and tables.

• Arrive on time, this allows time to center and enjoy the evening in a stress free manner.

• Please silence or turn off cell/mobile phones.

• During the share please be respectful of other groups enjoying Reiki by keeping conversations to a whisper and as brief as possible.  There will be ample time at the end of the evening for comments and discussions.

• If arriving late to the share, please enter the room "quietly" so the active session is not disturbed.  You may spend time in quite mediation, preparing for Reiki or enjoying self Reiki joining a group when the monument presents itself.  

Donations will be collected to offset the cost of the room.

results.name: Reiki Share ~ Roots & Wings

results.description:
Join Us!!!  We are the Advanced Access Toastmasters.  An Advanced Toastmasters Club giving you Access to the best Toastmasters in the Boston Area.  Become a member and begin enjoying the benefits of taking your speaking, evaluations and leadership to a whole new level.  

Join us on the third Tuesday of every month.

Brookline Police Department | 350 Washington Street | 7:00 p.m. until 9:00 p.m.

Toastmasters that have already completed their Competent Communicator Achievement and wanting to push the envelope with their speaking and leadership skills will enjoy the challenge of joining the Advanced Access Toastmasters Club!


Why should you join an Advanced Club?

• You are a Toastmaster that has earned their Competent Communicator and is looking for a club where members are practicing advanced speeches.

• You want feedback on your speeches from members that have gone beyond their Competent Communicator, many of which have achieved their Distinguished Toastmaster.

• You want to learn from successful leaders in other clubs on how to contribute largely to your home club.

• You are thirsting for knowledge on how to elevate your speeches to an advanced or even professional level.

• You want to network with business professionals and executives that have used Toastmasters to catapult their careers.
results.name: Advancing Public Speaking -  Advanced Access Toastmaster Club (Brookline)

results.description:
Ongoing class in Medieval and Renaissance Longsword in the tradition of Johannes Lichtenauer.

The Longsword is the iconic fantasy Knight's sword - a two-handed, straight blade with a cross guard. The weapon may seem to be simple at first but is in reality a weapon of finesse and skill.

The class covers all the basics of footwork, attacks and defenses. Drills are developed from simple to complex; from rigidly choreographed to open-ended. Timing, distance and judgement are developed. All classes begin with a Strength & Conditioning program designed to physically prepare one for fighting with the sword. Elements develop agility, core stability and power.
results.name: Lichtenauer Longsword

results.description:
WHY ME?  Understanding Karma                                                                                                          a meditation class series 

TUESDAYS | OCT 13th - NOV 17th


7:00 - 8:30pm

with Kadampa Buddhist Teacher, Kyle Davis

Do you ever wonder why certain things, good or bad, happen to you? How can an understanding of Karma change things for the better?

Karma means ‘action’. Every action we perform leaves an imprint on our very subtle mind and each imprint eventually gives rise to its own effect. Our mind is like a field and performing actions is like sowing seeds in that field. In this series, we will explore Buddha’s teachings on Karma. We will learn how to apply its wisdom into our daily lives in beautiful meditations, so that we can learn to accept our present circumstances and joyfully cultivate our future happiness.

Each class includes a short talk and two guided meditations. Everyone welcome - no experience necessary.  

Drop in anytime! No need to pre-registration. 

Cost | $10 per class / $5 students & seniors.  Members FREE! 

Location | 179 Green Street – Boston, Jamaica Plain, MA 02130  

meditationINboston.org

For more info please call[masked] or email [masked]

results.description:
This Meetup is intended for intermediate level players or higher, which means:Yankee C and above level, players with firm understanding of game strategy. Should be able to play 5-1 and 6-2 formations, have a good grasp of skills (passing, setting, hitting) and be able to move around to cover areas of the court. Play should consistently be bump-set-spike.



If you'd like to play, please do the following:


1. Send an email to Kory using the following URL: http://www.meetup.com/volleyball-122/message/?recipientId=8675200

2. In the message please indicate the date of event and your preferred position so we can make sure we have the right mix. ( If I don't know your position already)

Note that sending an email does not guarantee a spot to play; spots are only guaranteed if you receive a positive confirmation email. We will do our best to make sure the event is co-ed, have setters,  and incorporate a couple new members who want to join as well.

The location for this volleyball meetup is at the Orient Heights Community Center located at 86 Boardman Street in East Boston. Kory and Wing will be hosting these Tuesday night volleyball meetups.

This event is free if you are a member of Boston Community Centers. If not, it's a one-time $20 membership fee that is valid for a year. The Community Center is a short walk away from the Orient Heights T Stop on the Blue Line and also has plenty of parking. When you drive up, turn at the Mariott Hotel Sign and park in the lot or further along the fence.

As always, please remember:

- Respect the RSVP system (Don't show up expecting to play without a confirmed RSVP)

- The gym is open before the event to warm up, so please arrive a little early if you would like to warm up and stretch as we would like to start the game promptly from 7:00PM

- If it looks like you won't be able to make it or will run late please cancel your RSVP in time for someone else to join.  Event day/last minute cancellations and no shows will jeopardize your participation in future events.
results.name: 11/17 Intermediate+ Indoor Volleyball East Boston

results.description:
In view of the recent tragic events in the news, let's do a compassion meditation, a 20-minute meditation in which we bring to mind someone's suffering on the in-breath, and evoke compassion on the out-breath. The object of compassion may be someone else or yourself. This meditation is a secular adaptation of the Tibetan practice of Tonglen

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tonglen We'll have a discussion after the meditation.
results.name: Compassion Meditation

results.description:
Next up is Y The Last Man, volumes 1 & 2.

Sorry about the delay in scheduling this one; I kinda spaced. I'm putting it 3 weeks out from now (rather than the last meetup) so people have the same amount of time as usual to acquire and read the book.


The Bumf:

Written by Brian K. Vaughan (LOST, PRIDE OF BAGHDAD, EX MACHINA) and with art by Pia Guerra, this is the saga of Yorick Brown—the only human survivor of a planet-wide plague that instantly kills every mammal possessing a Y chromosome. Accompanied by a mysterious government agent, a brilliant young geneticist and his pet monkey, Ampersand, Yorick travels the world in search of his lost love and the answer to why he's the last man on earth.

If you plan on coming, once you've read the book please post one discussion question in the comments for this event. I'll bring a list of them with me, and as usual we'll have them there to draw from when we're looking for stuff to talk about. I won't turn you away if you don't, but let's make running these things a group effort!

For those who haven't been to the Comic Book Club before, it's pretty simple - we sit around, order some food and some drink, and we probe deep into the merits and meanings of our chosen book or books. I also bring along a list of questions (written by you!) to give the discussion a bit of structure - but don't worry - it's pretty casual!

The venue is the Friendly Toast, which is a very casual kinda place with plenty of room where we can easily be heard. Please note though, that it's best to bring cash - although supposedly their card minimum has been relaxed - perhaps even obliterated!
results.how_to_find_us: We gather on the couches in the front beforehand, and once we have a quorum we get a table -- usually one of the booths or the tables in the very back if it's a large group. Ask the staff if you can't find us!
results.name: Y The Last Man, Volumes 1 & 2 by Brian K. Vaughan

results.description:
Life's a Beach: The Unauthorized Biography of a Sand Grain, with Allen Gontz, Professor of Coastal Geology at UMass Boston

Tuesday, November 17 from 7-8pm | Le Laboratoire Cambridge


We continue our fall Rock the Café series on with a talk about coastal geology - and in specifically the world of sand - with Allen Gontz, Assistant Professor of Coastal Geology at UMass Boston. Beaches are some of the world's most dynamic ecological environments. Each grain of sand on the beach has a story to tell; a tale of great travels, interactions with others, and surviving through catastrophic events. The research of Dr. Gontz will take you on a journey that begins to unravel and decipher the stories. Speaker Bio: Allen Gontz is an Associate Professor of Coastal Geology and Geophysics at UMass Boston. His research interest is in coastal geological evolution and how landscapes change over time. Gontz's lab focuses on the investigation of changes to the landscape within the Quaternary that are primarily the result of changing sea-level and anthropogenic impacts.

Do You Plan to Attend? Please join us for drink and conversation. This is a free event, but limited seating is available. We encourage you to you RSVP through Eventbrite:


https://www.eventbrite.com/e/lifes-a-beach-the-unauthorized-biography-of-a-sand-grain-with-allen-gontz-professor-of-coastal-tickets-19463756620

Directions to Le Laboratoire Cambridge, 650 East Kendall Street Public Transit: Red line to Kendall Square, walk straight down 3rd Street, turn right onto Athenaeum Street, and left onto East Kendall Parking: There is a parking deck - the 650 East Kendall Street Garage - accessible by Linskey Way.


If you purchase food or drink from Le Lab, your parking ticket can be validated for discounted rates.
results.name: CafeSci Boston -  Life's a Beach: The Unauthorized Biography of a Sand Grain

results.description:
Contact me [Jose (click the link, then click "Message")] for the address.

General board gaming. We have a good library of widely played board games, and people normally bring many more of them. We regularly run three to five tables of board games - this provides enough variety.  It is normal for people to get two or three games a session.  The game night format was inspired by Unity Games and the event is very casual and structureless.  If you have gone to one of the meetup's quarterly events you will know.

Q & A:

Q.  What types of games are played?
A.  Any type of board game.  Browse through the most popular games at http://boardgamegeek.com/ and that should give you an idea.

Q.  Until when do you play games?  Can I arrive later than 7pm?
A.  Until the last game of the evening ends, usually past midnight.  Yes, you can arrive later than 7pm, but you may have to wait for a new game to start if you do.

Q.  Should I bring something?  
A.  If you want, bring a game you feel comfortable teaching. There will be pizza and sodas served. Feel free to bring snacks or beverages to share or chip in $5 to $10 for the pizza/sodas in the pizza cup. 

Q.  I really want to play XYZ game, can we schedule it?
A.  Some people ask for interest in a particular game on the event comments below.  This may be the way to make sure you get to play the game you want. 

Q.  Where do I park?
A.  The driveway is the obvious spot, but eventually it will fill up on most of these game nights.  Some people do park on the street.  The soccer field parking across the street is a safe option and is the suggestion the town police gave me when I asked about overflow parking.
results.how_to_find_us: The house is just across from a soccer field.  If the driveway starts to fill up, the soccer field parking lot is a good option.
results.name: Board Games in Sudbury

results.description: For November, we shall be reading Daniel Abraham's, A Shadow in Summer, the first book of The Long Price Quartet. In this elegantly simple fantasy world, poet "wizards" create and bind powerful beings who oversee the economies of the city-states by removing seeds from cotton plants and keeping marauders at bay. Alas, the poets' creations reflect their own psychologies and flaws, and in this story, one such "creation" hatches a plan to escape from his eternal servitude. The story features delicate prose, well-developed characters, and an intricate plot of criss-crossed machinations.
results.name: Book Discussion - A Shadow in Summer

results.description:
Two talks tonight, with plenty of time for mingling, meeting, and greeting.  If you would like to sponsor, get in touch!


Chelsea Voss and Anders Kaseorg: One-lining Python

A common past-time among programmers is finding how much they can accomplish in one line of code.  Chelsea has made all that work unnecessary with oneliner: it automatically converts any Python program into a single line of code.  What!? Why!? How!?  Chelsea and Anders will explain all.

David Baumgold: Flask-Dance

Flask is a popular lightweight Python web framework.  OAuth is a popular authentication mechanism that allows you to use web sites without sharing your password.  Implementing OAuth can get complicated.  David will show us his Flask-Dance library that lets you implement OAuth on your Flask site easily, letting your users log in with Facebook/Google/GitHub/etc.

Drinks afterwards at Meadhall, sponsored by Twilio.
results.name: Boston Python November Presentation Night

results.description:
Our weekly work session will be at the Cambridge Innovation Center in Kendall Square, on the FOURTH FLOOR, in the CAFE. These Hack Nights are our time to meet in person to work on and discuss civic tech projects. Come by to say hi and hack with us!

Transportation
The Red Line stop for CIC is Kendall. For those who drive, there is a pay parking lot underneath the building, and limited meter parking in the area. Additionally, the MIT Hayward St lot is free after 5pm. Please make sure to check in with security when you arrive.

Schedule
7:00pm - Opening remarks, project updates, announcements
7:20pm - New member orientation
8:00pm - Hacking!

During the event, join our Hackpad for announcement links and collaborative note taking.

To ensure that Code for Boston is a welcoming space for all, staff and participants are held to our Code of Conduct.

results.description:
How many times have you heard someone complain that nobody they meet online is a good fit. Or that they’re not getting any dates. Are you complaining about online dating? 

You're not alone. There are a lot of men and women who are suffering – needlessly - because of how they’re going about the whole online dating thing (and they don't realize that this experience that they are having is f-i-x-a-b-l-e). 

But…you also hear about all these people who are connecting with great people online, right? Lots of dates. And the dates are awesome. They're having a great time. Both scenarios are happening… All. The. Time. 

So maybe you’ve been on the “This ain’t workin’!” side of the equation, and you want to join the “Wow, this is rockin’!” gang… 

If so, you’ll want to be there for a very informative evening where you’ll learn what those people are doing who are having fun, meeting great men and women, and all as a result of online dating. Come…join us! Learn how you can rock your online dating adventure!

Presenter: Karen Jones, founder of The Heart Matters, has been a relationship coach since 1997, and has helped countless women end up in scrumptious relationships. She is a very big fan of online dating…if it’s done right (and she loves to help women get it right!). To learn more about Karen, please visit her website: www.TheHeartMatters.com 

Doors open at 7 - Event begins at 7:30, and goes until 9

Wine and cheese reception following the event

Fee: $25 per person (or bring a friend and you both pay $20)

---------------------------------------------------------------

New Meetup Group: Boston Dating Success

If you can use some help in this department, there will be workshops to guide you to be more successful in the dating world. There will be tips and tricks and other guidance from dating coaches and others.  This will be for online dating and dating in general. All workshops will have a social component and there will be some parties thrown in too. Most events will be in my photography studio on Moody St in Waltham. Please join the group to get the info on all of the upcoming events. Boston Dating Success

results.description:
Come join us on Tuesday, Nov 17 at Porter Square for our monthly meetup. Get travel ideas from fellow travelers, and share your own travel stories!

QUESTION FOR NOV 17: Regarding your travels, to whom are you most thankful?  (e.g. Someone who first inspired you to travel; A travel companion or a special person you met on the road; Someone who saved your life after getting bitten by that venomous snake in Costa Rica; etc.)

Our concept is simple: meet other travelers or expats, talk about where you've been and where they've been, and get inspired for your next trip. Everyone with an open mind and sense of adventure is welcome, whether you're a travel novice or an experienced travel junkie.

This month we'll meet at Tavern in the Square @ Porter Sq. This is a very accessible location; There is parking closeby, and it's literally a 1 min walk from the T (red-line) - just exit the T station and walk down Mass Ave, away from the big Porter Sq parking lot. There are lots of convenient bus connections too. We'll be in the front area, to the right of the bar.

Each month, we generally switch back and forth between Porter Sq and White Horse Tavern in Allston. We're also considering future options in other neighborhoods - suggestions are welcome!

Please note: Active solicitation of members at our meetups by commercial organizations is contrary to the spirit of the group. Please stay away if you are a travel company just looking to promote your business! Thank you!
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be to the right of the bar, by the windows overlooking Mass Ave
results.name: November Travel Meetup

Hey guys, lets have another great night of trivia! This event is always a success and everyone meets new friends! 

IF YOUR RSVP, PLEASE COMMIT TO ATTEND THE EVENT OR UPDATE YOUR RSVP. THE HOSTS OF THIS EVENT ARE NOT PAID, AND DO A LOT OF WORK IN ADVANCE TO ENSURE THE EVENT RUNS WELL. 

What's new? We are tired of being asked questions that are hard to answer so we're switching it up and making the trivia questions more relevant today by surveying our mailing list!

A lot of Meetup groups join this event so we will set up tables reserved for meetup! We will help you split up into teams of 2-6 if you aren't putting together a team :) 

When: Tuesday, November 17

Time: 7-9pm 

Where: Lansdowne Pub in Fenway  

Price: Free!

General Information:  
Remember the days of Family Feud? Well those days are back! And this time, with adult beverages! Form a crew with teammates past/present and/or other friends or come as an individual for some fun competition! Get those brain synapses charged up and join us for this great event!

THE TRIVIA:
Because there are more than 2 “families” coming this night, the trivia works in reverse of how traditional Family Feud scoring goes. All teams are given the survey questions that people were asked, and then you have to guess the answers given. You get MORE points for guessing the lower answers (the ones that only a few people said) and LESS points for guessing the most popular answers! So the challenge lies in guessing the toughest answer!

We will have awesome prizes for the winning team as well as other categories.
results.name: FREE Family Feud Trivia with FREE Apps!

• Sessions are booked using the Eventbrite link below.

• These are one on one sessions held  via a private telephone conference line. You can call in from your home or office.

• We review your dating profile together over the phone during our private session.

Are you sending message & after message on OKCupid or Match and not getting any responses?

Here's what we're going to do:

You and I are going to take a tour of your online dating profile via phone. I'll tell you if there are any red flags or bad buzzwords that might be keeping someone from hitting that message button. We'll look at your profile text, your photos and any other details that you share. We'll review everything together, and I'll tell you what might be sending the wrong impression. Or I'll tell you everything is perfect and you don't need to change a thing!

After this session, you're going to have more control and can go back to those days when you'd get excited before a first date. Just pick a time slot and register.

Get a 30 minute one on one review of your profile with me.  I’ll go over your picture selection and ad text and let you know if your profile includes any buzz words or red flags. I’ll also help you tweak/write your profile if it needs some freshening up.

results.description:
Join Lama Joe Szep and the NDF Cambridge sangha in person or via LiveStream (http://www.naturaldharma.org/live-teachings/) for a teaching on patience from the sixth chapter of Shantideva's A Guide to the Bodhisattva's Way of Life:

There is no evil like hated,
And no fortitude like patience.
Thus I should strive in various ways
To meditate on patience.

- Shantideva

Together, we will look at the nature of anger and patience, the benefits of practicing patience, and methods and meditations to foster it.

Lama Joe became interested in the Buddha Dharma in the late ’80s and took refuge in August of 1993 with Dzogchen Ponlop Rinpoche in Santa Clara. In 1995, he entered Three Year Retreat at Kagyu Thubten Choling. The retreat completed in the spring of 1999 and Lama Joe remained on at KTC for some time, working with Lama Willa at a Charlottesville, VA retreat center and supporting other local KTC centers. At the end of the summer of 2000 he moved back to Boston. In the summer of 2001, he took over the care and administration of Kagyu Trinley Kunchab in Watertown, MA, where he is acting director. In February of 2007, he was conferred the title of Tripon (teaching) Lama by Lama Norlha Rinpoche. Lama Joe also works as a computer systems administrator at Boston University.Please join us for a session of natural meditation in the Tibetan Buddhist traditions of Dzogchen and Mahamudra. More details and information about our group can be found at the following URL:

http://www.naturaldharma.org

Please note: most of the friends who attend regularly are not Meetup members, so there are always more people attending than are signed up using this web site.

Contact : [masked]
results.name: Patience - The Antidote For Anger with Lama Joe Szep

We'll attend this panel discussion. 


If you're interested in meeting up beforehand, please put a message in the comments area before 5 pm on the day of the event. Some of us will be meeting at Haley House Bakery Cafe for dinner at 5:45 pm before leaving at 6:45 to walk over to the event.  Address for Haley House Bakery Cafe: 12 Dade Street, Dudley Square, Roxbury, MA 02119


Info about the event from the Facebook event description:


It's no secret that People of Color, religious minorities, and other "suspect communities" are targeted by criminal justice and national security agencies. From police scrutiny of Black Lives Matter activists to the Muslim-focused "countering violent extremism" (CVE) initiative, government surveillance divides communities, interferes with First Amendment protected activity, and impedes movement organizing.

This event will examine parallels and intersections between state profiling of Black communities, Muslims, and other Communities of Color in Boston and beyond, with special focus on the new federal CVE initiative.

Come engage with a panel of inspiring activists to explore how we can resist surveillance and strengthen the movement for racial justice through building solidarity across our diverse local communities.


..............................

Get more details on Facebook.
results.name: Attend "Resisting Surveillance: Racial & Religious Profiling in Boston & Beyond"

results.description:
NOTE LOCATION CHANGE. THIS IS NOT THE WATERTOWN HEALING CENTER. IT IS AROUND THE CORNER ON MAIN ST.

Join Brynn Bishop and Monique Darling for a night of diving deep within and without to find the true gift of ourselves and be able to relate from that place with everyone else.

INVITATION:


What if we treated ourselves the way we wished our Mom/Dad had treated us? What if we offered ourselves the very things we long for from a lover or best friend? What if we were as kind to ourselves as we would be to a lost child we found alone on the street? What if we loved US the way we long for the beloved to love us?

DON'T JUST ASK WHAT IF. TRY IT!! Take a moment to imagine someone you truly love. Allow yourself to feel the full extent of your love for that person. Now turn it back on yourself, and feel what it feels like to love yourself THAT much.

OPPORTUNITY:


If you could have anything, do anything, what would you choose? What do you really want? What is keeping you from having it? Your life is alive with an abundance of possibilities, opportunities, potential - all you have to do is be willing to ask.


In this workshop you will learn, play, and practice:

*To ask for what you want, skillfully and without attachment to the response.
*To honor, respect, and be grateful for the answer "no", and still be hopeful for the answer "yes".
*To be honest and vulnerable about your wants and desires without shame, without deflection, without armor.
*To hold space for someone who has not yet learned these skills.
*To own your fears instead of them owning you.
*To not be afraid to be the one you love the most.
*To learn to be even more vulnerable when you want to isolate or close down.

You will gain tools and leave with the ability to relate with everyone in your life with more ease, grace, and blissful contentment from your own center.

and get to connect with one another through breath, touch, sound, energy and movement.....

If you ever begin to understand what/who you are, you could not possibly ever compare yourself to another......envy, wish to impress, to BE different than you are.... for in the beauty, wonder, and awe at discovering how magnificently "your" puzzle pieces fit together, at the ever changing infinite ways YOU shift, dance, and weave together, you would laugh in the greatest joy at just a glimpse of the truly miraculous depths that lie within you, within us, each one so unique, so extraordinary, it would take an entire lifetime to only just begin to discover. And yet so often we abandon the quest, the remembrance, the curiosity, the self discovery, to follow another, or invest in relationships, doing what we have been told is the "right" way to be. The greatest freedom that we could ever express, imagine, by simply giving myself permission to gently keep returning to me... from here the greatest relating can take place -- from here we can transform the world by simply being 100% us.

You see you ARE the gift!!

About Your Facilitators:

Monique Darling, San Diego, CA, is the founder of Divine Interludes which provides workshops and experiential play-shops in the art of Tantra and conscious loving. She has studied and taught with renowned Tantra teachers and extraordinary workshop facilitators since 1990 and is a certified Cuddly Party Facilitator. She has been featured on TLC and The Dr’s and has been interviewed by magazines across the USA. Monique is dedicated to empowering others utilizing her vast repertoire of cutting-edge teachings. She specializes in helping others reclaim their power and natural sensuality by transmuting fear and repression into courage, self-love and freedom. She guides from a place of understanding and her natural exuberance is infectious! She is available for private sessions, experiential workshops and Cuddle Parties. www.divineinterludes.com

Brynn Bishop, founder of Conscious Intimacy, is an Advanced Certified Tantra Educator and Intimacy Coach with over twenty-five years experience in the field of Conscious Relating. Her mission is to empower people to create authentic, loving, pleasurable relationships with themselves and others. She specializes in helping people release sexual shame and trauma and awaken their sacred erotic potential. Brynn’s unique approach weaves together cutting edge Somatic Psychology and Trauma Resolution with Taoist and Tantric Healing Arts and Awakening practices - providing the most effective methods of healing, transformation and empowerment. She teaches nationally and maintains a private practice in Boston and via phone and video conference. www.conscious-intimacy.com.

results.description:
Meditation practice gives us a chance to step away from the busy-ness of our day-to-day lives. It provides space for us to be free from reaction, from expectation, from doing, and step into the gentle space of being.

This weekly practice consists of 25-30 minutes of guided Vipassana meditation followed by a brief discussion. Vipassana meditation encourages us to experience each moment exactly how it is, fostering presence and awareness.

In this practice we allow thoughts, emotions, and all other stimuli to surface. We become a witness of these, cultivating a space of non-attachment and revealing a deeper connection with one's inner self.

Newcomers to meditation and long-time practitioners are welcome to attend. This is a FREE practice. There is a suggested donation, but that is not required to attend.

results.description:
We are meeting every Tuesday night from 8:00 PM to 10:00 PM practicing Modern Arnis, WC, and SCJ flow drills and Self-Defense skills.

All levels are welcome!  For ages 15 and up.


The price is $15.00 /per person /per meetup. The first meetup is free.

Please wear loose fitting, comfortable cloths suitable for working out.

Please do not wear shoes that you've worn outdoors on the wood floor.

Instructor's Background

Alix Lavaud has been training Martial Arts for over 45 years and is a master of Modern Arnis, Pien San Wing Chun Kung Fu, and has extensive training in Small Circle Jujitsu.  He also humbly owns the rank of Lakan Apat (a 4th degree BLACKBELT ).


Lineage

Modern Arnis :  Remy Presas  -->  Alix Lavaud

Wing Chun:  Henry Mui  -->  Alix Lavaud

Small Circle Jujitsu:  Wally Jay -->  Alix Lavaud


Philosophy

 Go With The Flow ...

Some Quotes we Love

“If your mind is empty, it is ready for anything. In the beginner’s mind there are many possibilities, but in the expert’s there are few”
― Shunryu Suzuki


“Everything is perfect and there is always room for improvement.”
― Shunryu Suzuki

“We must exist right here and right now!”
― Shunryu Suzuki

Benefits of Martial Arts

1.  Mental Benefits

2.  Improved Balance

3.  Improved Flexibility

4.  Focus and stillness

5.  Hand and Eye Coordination

6.  Improved reflexes

7.  Learn self-defense skills

8.  Stress relief

9.  Relax

10.  Gain Self Confident and Self Respect

11.  Learn to Breathe

12.  Learn to Find Focus and Stillness

13.  Encouraging Non-Violent Conflict Resolution

14.  Improvement in many other Areas of Life

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
Do you VEGETABLE-TARIANS want all the OTHER people (even if they have not committed to be vegetarians) to eat fresh produce?  Then help us - each Wednesday late afternoon - bag vegetables (and some fruit) for the neighbors in Mission Hill.  Usually there are also freshly-baked loaves of bread, also (baked that morning - Jessica's Bakery).

It's an assembly line, then take home a bag (or two) of produce for yourself. 

Bring your business cards, smartphone, or notepad, and prepare to exchange contact info with other volunteers you like.  Volunteers come from several sources (not merely this meetup or others:Craigslist, Pharmacy School, School of Public Health, etc.) 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
VOLUNTEERING for $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill 
Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street 
Mission Hill, Roxbury 
(between Brigham Circle and Roxbury Crossing T stops) 
Boston, MA 02120 - <2 blocks from Orange Line T Each Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm (indoors in bad weather)

We will be VOLUNTEERING for the weekly Wednesday late afternoon $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill.

When you volunteer, 
YOU will ALSO TAKE HOME one or two of those "$2 bags"! 
We've had 55 volunteers, and we've had 7.  Workloads vary!

Fair Foods provides a 20-22 bag of produce for the Mission Hill neighbors so they can eat like me - on produce. The neighbors only need to pay' $2 for the bag.

Volunteers unload the truck, set up 3 banquet tables, set up the food in order of desntiy (potatoes on bottom - tomatoes and bananas and berries and kale on top), then fill each bag (and 'stack' them upright by one another - for the 'paying neighbors' to pick up (for $2). 

Some arrive as early as 3:30 pm (you don't NEED to do that, but you're welcome to do so; OUR meetup's attendees - it's posted on 6 meetups - are often there early, and you can chat).


We (MOST of us) arrive around 4 pm (maybe as late as 4:30 pm) and work until 6 pm or so (can leave as early as 5:30 pm if we've finished).

In the FRONT of the Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street (between the Brigham Circle T stop - GREEN E-Line - and the Roxbury Crossing Orange Line T stop), behind the wrought iron fence.

Wear comfortable clothing that allows you to move flexibly and to actually work, lifting heavy bags of food. 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Tobin Community Center 
1481 Tremont Street, Boston, MA

THERE IS NO PARKING - IT'S BEST FOR THOSE WHO LIVE IN BOSTON AND TRAVEL IN ON THE MBTA

THERE IS NO PARKING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

Use the T - #66 bus comes by - E-Line or Orange Line

Every Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Bring friends!  Forward the invitation to others!

Invite FRIENDS through the Facebook, LinkedIn, and Twitter 'share' 
buttons
http://www.yelp.com/events/boston-volunteering-for-2-bag-of-produce-in-mission-hill-each-wednesday-afternoon-from-4-6-pm-at-tobin-community-center

Looking for an ARTIST to help VISUALLY REPRESENT this vegetable outreach effort.
TALK with us FIRST !!
Looking for Gifted Marketers to
(i) conceptualize the WHY of low cost vegetable distribution! and
(ii) the desirability of TAKING the low cost vegetables !!

LOGISTICAL CHALLENGE IS TO GET LOW COST VEGETABLES to the REFRIGERATORS of LOCAL RESIDENTS !!!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Vegan Cooking classes or Vegan Cooking Ideas

What Can You Do With Your $2 Bag?

Portion Control

Bake...Don't Fry!

Roasted Veggie Stackers

No-Guilt Banana Ice Cream

Avocados!!!

Salad with Chipotle Hummus

Simple Cilantro Chutney

More $2 bags of Produce!

Drink your greens!

results.name: VOLUNTEERING for distributing $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill

results.description:
Do you VEGETABLE-TARIANS want all the OTHER people (even if they have not committed to be vegetarians) to eat fresh produce?  Then help us - each Wednesday late afternoon - bag vegetables (and some fruit) for the neighbors in Mission Hill.  Usually there are also freshly-baked loaves of bread, also (baked that morning - Jessica's Bakery).

It's an assembly line, then take home a bag (or two) of produce for yourself. 

Bring your business cards, smartphone, or notepad, and prepare to exchange contact info with other volunteers you like.  Volunteers come from several sources (not merely this meetup or others:Craigslist, Pharmacy School, School of Public Health, etc.) 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
VOLUNTEERING for $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill
Tobin Community Center
1481 Tremont Street - inside the front entrance
Mission Hill, Roxbury
(between Brigham Circle and Roxbury Crossing T stops)
Boston, MA 02120 - <2 blocks from Orange Line T Each Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm (indoors in bad weather)


We will be VOLUNTEERING for the weekly Wednesday late afternoon $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill.

When you volunteer,
YOU will ALSO TAKE HOME one or two of those "$2 bags"! 
We've had 55 volunteers, and we've had 7.  Workloads vary!

Fair Foods provides a 20-22 bag of produce for the Mission Hill neighbors so they can eat like me - on produce. The neighbors only need to pay' $2 for the bag.

Volunteers unload the truck, set up 3 banquet tables, set up the food in order of desntiy (heavy food, such as potatoes or onions, on the bottom - lighter, more perishable foods, such as tomatoes and bananas and berries and kale on top), then fill each bag (and 'stack' them upright by one another - for the 'paying neighbors' to pick up (for $2).

Some arrive as early as 3:30 pm (you don't NEED to do that, but you're welcome to do so; OUR meetup's attendees - it's posted on 6 meetups - are often there early, and you can chat).

We (MOST of us) arrive around 4 pm (maybe as late as 4:30 pm) and work until 6 pm (can leave as early as 5:30 pm if we've finished).

In the FRONT of the Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street (between the Brigham Circle T stop - GREEN E-Line - and the Roxbury Crossing Orange Line T stop), behind the wrought iron fence.

Wear comfortable clothing that allows you to move flexibly and to actually work, lifting heavy bags of food.

results.name: Meditation Class

results.description:
Who should join: Beginners to Advanced speakers interested in learning how to improve their public speaking for fun or professionally.  Reduce your fear and increase your confidence.


Why  members should join: Learn the basics of public speaking, challenge your current skills to be a professional speaker or just to have fun & meet interesting people.  You will also be challenged to give more challenging types of speeches such as ice breakers, humorous and inspirational speeches.

What members can expect out of the group: We have a fast paced 1 hour meeting packed with 2 prepared speeches from members as well as Table Topics where anyone is invited to speak on a suggested topic for 1-2 minutes to hone their ability to speak off the cuff.


You can also join our mentorship program and be assigned an advanced speaker who will guide you to improving your skills.

Lead meetings and presentations at work, begin your path to being a better teacher or professional paid public speaker or simply be a better storyteller.

Tuesday 12pm meeting for members and guests. Please visit for free! 

All are welcome.

results.description:
Hosted by: Beyond Your Hammock & Claudia Connects

Beyond Your Hammock and Claudia Connects are back to bring you another A Night in the Hammock!! As most of you know by now, this isn't your typical networking event. It's social... it's business... it's life! 

Have you found the key to success? Great, come share it with us. Are you stuck in a rut? Not so great, but come share that as well. Our goal is to create an environment that supports you in getting to the next level, no matter where you might be today. Now is only temporary and we have 100% of our lives to live. Let's make the most of it! 

There will be complimentary crudité and cheese and crackers. Also, if you are driving to the event, you can park at 75 State Street and the Harborside Inn will validate your ticket for a discounted rate.

Please check out photos from our May 20th event.

Thank you!

"The discomfort of choosing to do something outside of your comfort zone is temporary... it's the distress of not doing it that lasts forever."  - Eric Roberge, Founder of Beyond Your Hammock

Thank you!
results.how_to_find_us: I'll be the lady near the hammock! ;)

results.description:
Join the New England Network for Women for a relaxed evening of Cocktails and Conversations in Hingham, Massachusetts, on the South Shore.  In November 2015 will be our first time having a networking event here and as of November, the majority of our members were in the Cambridge area, so we don't anticipate the South Shore to kick off for some time, so be patient and meet one or two people at first and we will grow it on the South Shore eventually!  We will try this one as the 3rd Wednesday of the Month.  Please also remember to suggest a venue near your location and we can try it.  We have had some north shore and metro west suggestions, but if you would like to put up an actual event location in the SUGGEST A MEETUP tab and you can lead it, go for it!  So, for tonight's meeting and as always, please come prepared to mingle with a fabulous group of empowering women who will share stories and tips on their business ventures!  There are new faces at each event.

Whether you are networking to meet potential new clients, learn new tips and techniques from seasoned businesswomen, share ideas and experiences with open and like-minded women or just to meet new friends in the area, this is the group for you.  Meet at the rear of the restaurant and bring your marketing materials and business cards to distribute.  We aim to have a member speaker at each gathering, whom I have listed below.  If you would like to give a presentation at one of our meetings, please scroll down to  see if someone has been selected yet.  If not, you may inquire about being our speaker of the evening.  In order to speak, your membership dues must be current and you may pay your dues online or at your next meeting.  

Also, a reminder that I am not always in attendance, since there are so many events and they are for you, I can't possibly make all of them and I own a business in Costa Rica, so if you ever want to be the leader, let me know.

Happy chatting and best wishes on your endeavors!  

As always, I welcome any questions you may have regarding our group or your business ventures! 

Stacey Mac, Owner 
Sonas Ventures LLC, which owns and operates: 
Sonas Real Estate, a division of Century 21 Abigail Adams 
Sonas Assistants, Workshops on Executive Assistant Training 
SUP SONAS, Stand Up Paddleboarding, Surfing & Travel in Boston, New England and Costa Rica 
http://www.Facebook.com/SUPSONAS 
http://www.Facebook.com/NewEnglandNetworkforWomen 
[masked] 
[masked]

MEMBER SPEAKER:  To be determined. :)

results.description:
CREED
Release Date:

November 25, 2015
Rating:

PG-13


Synopsis:

Adonis Johnson (Jordan) never knew his famous father, world heavyweight champion Apollo Creed, who died before he was born. Still, there’s no denying that boxing is in his blood, so Adonis heads to Philadelphia, the site of Apollo Creed’s legendary match with a tough upstart named Rocky Balboa. Once in the City of Brotherly Love, Adonis tracks Rocky (Stallone) down and asks him to be his trainer. Despite his insistence that he is out of the fight game for good, Rocky sees in Adonis the strength and determination he had known in Apollo—the fierce rival who became his closest friend. Agreeing to take him on, Rocky trains the young fighter, even as the former champ is battling an opponent more deadly than any he faced in the ring. With Rocky in his corner, it isn’t long before Adonis gets his own shot at the title…but can he develop not only the drive but also the heart of a true fighter, in time to get into the ring?

https://youtu.be/JQ9OhBYjTds
