results.description:
RSVP Here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/emerging-techtalks-innovation-within-big-data-cloud-computing-and-wearables-tickets-19425255462

The NSBE Boston Professionals and Black Tech Boston meetup are pleased to present:

Emerging TechTalks:  Innovation within Big Data, Cloud Computing and Wearables!

Our sponsors Twitter and The Tech Connection are excited to bring together cross-industry entrepreneurs, experts, and innovators on the future of technology!

Michael Lee – Software Engineering Lead | Twitter | Big Data

Michael Lee currently serves as the lead technologist on the Media Monetization and Analytics team at Twitter. In the past, he has worked as a developer at BlackBerry and OMESH Networks. 

We all know Twitter from a mobile application, but come learn about the emerging technologies that Twitter is working on behind the tweets.

#BigData #Twitter #BehindTheTweets

Justin White – Chief Technology Officer, Elsen | Entrepreneur

Justin White spent his career developing and implementing software-based solutions for the National Science Foundation, IBM, and the US Government before going off to co-found Elsen - a software firm geared towards enabling hedge funds and financial institutions compute complex data simply.

Join as Justin takes us through his experience in the big data space and his visions to rock the financial services industry!

#BigData #Entrepreneur #SoftwareAsService

Rob Browne –Systems & Solution Engineer | Computing Renaissance man

Rob Browne is a Systems & Solutions Engineer with extensive experience in architecting Data Center and Networking solutions utilizing a wide range of technologies.  He has spent the bulk of his career as a Cisco Systems Engineer working with large service providers that include Comcast, Netflix, and many more.

Learn how innovations in cloud computing and continuous operations have impacted the world as we know it and what we can expect from the future.

#CloudComputing #ITtrends #Networking

Donald Schwartz | Founder of VectorSpect |Wearables Expert

Donald Schwartz, is a 30 year veteran in software marketing and Moodle eLearning support systems. An original Google Glass Explorer, Don is the founder of the Wearables New England Meetup group and the host of a series of events focused on wearables in Healthcare. Most recently, Don was the keynote speaker at the Juniata College, Transhumanism Conference 2015. A strong believer in a wearables future for professionals, Don likes to explore ongoing developments in healthcare, education and the enterprise.

Learn how wearable technologies has impacted the world as we know it and what we can expect in the future.
results.name: Emerging TechTalks:  Innovation within Big Data, Cloud Computing and Wearables!

results.description:
The November meetup is focusing on VR input solutions including haptic and tracking systems from XIMMERSE and a hand held 6DOF input controller from Nod Labs. Come and try bringing your hands into VR!

XIMMERSE builds mobile VR input devices, especially for use with head-mounted displays. (See http://www.ximmerse.com/) At the meetup, they will demonstrate a stereo camera-based system that tracks joysticks, haptic gloves and head position inside-out. It can also track bare hand gestures and record VR videos. The speaker, Davy, will share his experience in hardware manufacturing and his understanding of VR interaction.


NOD LABS  is a gesture recognition and motion tracking company. With technology that integrates hardware and software, Nod builds intuitive products that communicate human intent. Nod’s products transform even the most subtle of movements into precise commands. From entertainment, gaming, VR/AR, connected devices and drones, Nod is redefining the way we interact with our devices. The company is based in Mountain View, CA. Learn more at nod.com, and join us on Facebook and Twitter @meetnod.


PLEASE NOTE: Our venue requires our guests to sign in with a photo ID at the security desk. When you RSVP you'll get a pop up question; please enter your full name as it appears on your ID. Thanks for your cooperation.


RSVP's are $4; we've introduced this fee to insure that we can continue to afford to have meeting spaces and cover the fees from meetup.com. Please note that we have not and will not make any profit from this meetup and in fact we're in the process of making Boston VR part of a 501c3 tax-deductible charity organization.


The pizza is still free! 

SCHEDULE

6 - Doors open, demos begin, pizza is served


7 - 8 - Presentations

8 - 8:15 - Demo intros & announcements

8:15 - 9:45 Demofest!!

9:45pm - Come with us to the afterparty at Firebrand Saints (it's right downstairs!!)

PARKING


If you're coming to the afterparty, Firebrand Saints offers free validated parking for entry after 5pm. Enter through the garage and then keep going into the parking lot so you don't have to go through security again after the garage closes. Please note that the validation is temporary; once they swipe your ticket you should exit the lot immediately.
results.name: Nod Labs & Ximmerse

results.description:
6:00-7:00 Networking, Introductions, Pizza


7:00-7:45 Dan Stolts - Chief Technology Strategist - Microsoft

  Cloud Computing and the Security Landscape

The REAL Security Story

With massive security breaches announced on the nightly news every couple weeks, is cloud computing even viable? Come to this session to get the inside scoop on the security landscape and what that means to cloud computing and managing your infrastructure. We look at the cloud today as well as how we can expect the cloud and security landscape to change in the coming years. Does the launch of Windows 10 have any bearing on the discussion? How can we keep up with the rapid changes in both the cloud and in security? How are enterprises responding to security and privacy threats and breaches? What are companies doing to clean up their house? Most importantly, how should you respond to protect your business’s assets? Come to this session to find out!

Speaker Bio: Dan Stolts – Chief Technology Strategist - Microsoft 
http://www.itproguru.com 
Dan Stolts “ITProGuru” is a technology expert who is a master of systems management and security. He is Chief Technology Strategist for Microsoft, owns several businesses and is a published author. Reach him on his primary bloghttp://itproguru.com or twitter @ITProGuru. He is proficient in many datacenter technologies (Windows Server, System Center, Virtualization, Cloud, etc.) and holds many certifications including MCT, MCITP, MCSE, TS, etc. Dan is currently specializing in system management, virtualization and cloud technologies. Dan is and has been a very active member of the user group community and was the founder of VirtG. Dan is an enthusiastic advocate of technology and is passionate about helping others. See more at: http://itproguru.com/about

8:00-8:45 RES Software

  Securing The End User: A look beyond the enterprise          “gated community” approach to IT security

This presentation will look at ways to ways mitigate end user carelessness and the risk of malicious activities by going beyond the firewall to secure your end users. 

Speaker Bio: Tom Lauzon - Solution Engineer for RES Software 
Tom is an accomplished professional experienced in the automation, operation, management, and deployment of high-volume, mission critical, virtual end-user computing environments. Prior to RES Software, Tom managed the world-wide virtual computing infrastructure for a leading AMLAW 100 law firm, focusing on continuity of experience between physical and virtual end-user computing environments. Tom also has managed the virtual computer infrastructure for a large Electric & Gas utility; securing and virtualizing access to control and outage management applications with a high level of availability. Tom started his career as a support engineer for InterMute, Inc a leader in Spyware detection and removal prior to being acquired by Trend Micro, Inc in 2005. Tom is a Citrix Certified Expert for Virtualization, Microsoft Certified Professional and a RES Software Certified Professional. Follow Tom on Twitter @tcl145.

8:45- Cleanup and prizes
results.name: Security – Mitigating risks from the End User to the Cloud

results.description:
Join us for a discussion on "Fulfillment & Shipping Strategies!"


It's mid-Q4 and the majority of consumer goods businesses will do between 60-80% of their business just ahead of the primary gift giving season. How do you successfully ramp up and manage that kind of volume?

___________________________________________________

Topics we'll cover:

• Fulfilling yourself VS. Using a 3PL or warehouse
• How to set up your systems
• What to look for or consider in fulfillment
• How to project sales/ prep for inventory levels
• Oh sh*t moments
• Shipping rates/ shipping cut off times

Panelists

• Jennifer Milne, Design Engineer at Formlabs

Jennifer ran Formlabs' highly successful Kickstarter campaign, raising $2.9M -- the highest grossing technology product at the time. She learned first hand what it takes to go from 10s of working prototypes to 1,000s of functioning products that work straight out the box, and the surrounding ship/ don't ship decisions that go into it. 

• John Wise, Co-Founder at lovepop


John is an engineer (former ship builder) turned MBA. He built the company's supply chain from the ground up, including opening their own production facility in Vietnam and domestically fulfilling orders out of his basement, an incubation space, a local after school program, and now from a large 3PL.  


• Andrew Kitzenberg, Founder and CEO at OnHand

Andrew founded OnHand as a course project at Babson College in 2010. Since 2012, OnHand has become a major tech accessories supplier to the collegiate market, selling in more than 1,000 retail stores and over 30% of all campus stores in North America.

results.description:
Please join us for our second official Boston Onshape user group meeting, held at our very own office!

We have an exciting night planned. Our tech marketing crew is in town to share Onshape tips & tricks, our partner Shapeways will talk a bit about how 3D printing materials are manufactured, and we have the hardware lead from Grove, one of our customers, coming to share their story about how they used Onshape to design an indoor hydroponic ecosystem.

Not to mention, we'll have food and Onshape swag to give away too.

Our office is easy to get to by T or by car and there is plenty of parking. Feel free to bring others whether they use Onshape or not! The night will be about learning, sharing, and meeting others in the world of CAD.

If you don't have an Onshape account already, sign up for a free account and start CADding in minutes: https://www.onshape.com/
results.how_to_find_us: If you are taking the T, take the red line to Alewife station, then exit from Russell field (the back exit) and take the path on the left (around the T building). Follow that path, cross the parking lot, and arrive at our office!

results.description:
6:00-7:00 Networking, Introductions, Pizza


7:00-7:45 Dan Stolts - Chief Technology Strategist - Microsoft

                     Cloud Computing and the Security Landscape

The REAL Security Story

With massive security breaches announced on the nightly news every couple weeks, is cloud computing even viable? Come to this session to get the inside scoop on the security landscape and what that means to cloud computing and managing your infrastructure. We look at the cloud today as well as how we can expect the cloud and security landscape to change in the coming years. Does the launch of Windows 10 have any bearing on the discussion? How can we keep up with the rapid changes in both the cloud and in security? How are enterprises responding to security and privacy threats and breaches? What are companies doing to clean up their house? Most importantly, how should you respond to protect your business’s assets? Come to this session to find out!

Speaker Bio: Dan Stolts – Chief Technology Strategist - Microsoft
http://www.itproguru.com
Dan Stolts “ITProGuru” is a technology expert who is a master of systems management and security. He is Chief Technology Strategist for Microsoft, owns several businesses and is a published author. Reach him on his primary blog http://itproguru.com or twitter @ITProGuru. He is proficient in many datacenter technologies (Windows Server, System Center, Virtualization, Cloud, etc.) and holds many certifications including MCT, MCITP, MCSE, TS, etc. Dan is currently specializing in system management, virtualization and cloud technologies. Dan is and has been a very active member of the user group community and was the founder of VirtG. Dan is an enthusiastic advocate of technology and is passionate about helping others. See more at: http://itproguru.com/about

8:00-8:45 RES Software

                     Securing The End User: A look beyond the enterprise                  “gated community” approach to IT security

This presentation will look at ways to ways mitigate end user carelessness and the risk of malicious activities by going beyond the firewall to secure your end users.

Speaker Bio: Tom Lauzon - Solution Engineer for RES Software
Tom is an accomplished professional experienced in the automation, operation, management, and deployment of high-volume, mission critical, virtual end-user computing environments. Prior to RES Software, Tom managed the world-wide virtual computing infrastructure for a leading AMLAW 100 law firm, focusing on continuity of experience between physical and virtual end-user computing environments. Tom also has managed the virtual computer infrastructure for a large Electric & Gas utility; securing and virtualizing access to control and outage management applications with a high level of availability. Tom started his career as a support engineer for InterMute, Inc a leader in Spyware detection and removal prior to being acquired by Trend Micro, Inc in 2005. Tom is a Citrix Certified Expert for Virtualization, Microsoft Certified Professional and a RES Software Certified Professional. Follow Tom on Twitter @tcl145.

8:45- Cleanup and prizes
results.how_to_find_us: http://virtg.com/default.aspx
results.name: Security – Mitigating risks from the End User to the Cloud

This is a free event organized by NSBE Boston Professionals and Black Tech Boston meetup. Make sure to register via event link on the bottom:
From the event description:

The Tech Connection and Twitter are excited to bring together cross-industry entrepreneurs, experts, and innovators on the future of technology:


Michael Lee – Software Engineering Lead | Twitter | Big Data

Michael Lee currently serves as the lead technologist on the Media Monetization and Analytics team at Twitter. In the past, he has worked as a developer at BlackBerry and OMESH Networks. We all know Twitter from a mobile application, but come learn about the emerging technologies that Twitter is working on behind the tweets.

#BigData #Twitter #BehindTheTweets


Justin White – Chief Technology Officer, Elsen | Entrepreneur

Justin White spent his career developing and implementing software-based solutions for the National Science Foundation, IBM, and the US Government before going off to co-found Elsen - a software firm geared towards enabling hedge funds and financial institutions compute complex data simply.

Join as Justin takes us through his experience in the big data space and his visions to rock the financial services industry!

#BigData #Entrepreneur #SoftwareAsService

Rob Browne –Systems & Solution Engineer | Computing Renaissance man

Rob Browne is a Systems & Solutions Engineer with extensive experience in architecting Data Center and Networking solutions utilizing a wide range of technologies. He has spent the bulk of his career as a Cisco Systems Engineer working with large service providers that include Comcast, Netflix, and many more.

Learn how innovations in cloud computing and continuous operations have impacted the world as we know it and what we can expect from the future.

#CloudComputing #ITtrends #Networking

Donald Schwartz | Founder of VectorSpect | Wearables Expert

Donald Schwartz, is a 30 year veteran in software marketing and Moodle eLearning support systems. An original Google Glass Explorer, Don is the founder of the Wearables New England Meetup group and the host of a series of events focused on wearables in Healthcare. Most recently, Don was the keynote speaker at the Juniata College, Transhumanism Conference 2015. A strong believer in a wearables future for professionals, Don likes to explore ongoing developments in healthcare, education and the enterprise.

Learn how wearable technologies has impacted the world as we know it and what we can expect in the future.

#Wearables #TrendinginTech #TheFuture

results.description:
BGN Fans,  


We're excited to bring you November's Board Game Night, as always hosted by East Coast Product, and this month sponsored by Localytics, Downeast Cider House, Buffalo Trace Bourbon, and DrugDev. Our sponsor, DrugDev, has generously donated $300 in Amazon gift cards for this months giveaway and Buffalo Trace is giving away some awesome gift baskets!

Your $5 registration includes drinks and snacks. All proceeds benefit the ever awesome Resilient Coders, an organization dedicated to making web tech education more accessible to urban youth. Localytics has offered to match every donation so your $5 donation is going a lot further.

Half-networking, half-gaming -- it's the only event in Boston that brings together innovation enthusiasts for an evening of friendly competition and great conversation. Don't forget to spread the word use the hashtag #BGNio7 and tweet us @BGNio to stay in the loop and build our community.

Our games include:

• Settlers of Catan

• Race to the Galaxy

• Dominion

• Marvel Legendary

• Succession

• Puerto Rico

• DiXit

• San Juan

• Indie Game Spotlight: Moonquake Escape


• Or bring your own! 

Indie Game Spotlight!: Master of Spies


SPONSORS

East Coast Product is the fastest most efficient way to build the right digital product to get your startup to it's next milestone. We are a product accelerator specializing in growth stage startups, helping them through strategy and execution. 

Localytics was conceived in 2009 in Boston, Massachusetts with one simple goal in mind: to help our customers build stronger relationships with their mobile and web app users through our analytics and marketing platform. Localytics currently supports more than 6,000 customers and reaches 32,000 apps, 2.3 billion devices and 50 billion data points monthly.

Ancient buffalo carved paths through the wilderness that led American pioneers and explorers to new frontiers. One such trail led to the banks of the Kentucky River where Buffalo Trace Distillery has been making bourbon whiskey the same way for more than 200 years. In tribute to the mighty buffalo and the rugged, independent spirit of the pioneers who followed them, we created our signature Buffalo Trace Kentucky Straight Bourbon Whiskey.


http://network.myscrs.org/uploads/assets/3500/logo.png?1405712807

DrugDev is transforming the clinical trial landscape with modern SaaS solutions that enable companies to “do more trials” through industry-wide collaboration, standardization and a beautiful technology experience.  Our tools reach tens of thousands of users and have  been making clinical trial operations more efficient for over 7 years (we started on Rails 1.9!).  While we may not be a sexy consumer product, we are playing a part in getting life-saving drugs to market quicker.  Our Newton office is around 40 people and we're looking to hire in Engineering, Marketing and Professional Services.  Creating an amazing, long standing company that focuses on our culture and people is the number one priority as we grow!

New England's Craft Cider. Locally grown. Freshly Pressed. Gluten-Free. Not from Concentrate.

Please RSVP for this game so we know we have enough people. We'll confirm by 3pm or earlier that the game is on.

6:00-6:15 pm - Warm up & practice, we'll work on some throws, passes & catches.

6:15 pm - Game starts.

General guidelines: Dress accordingly. Bring a white & dark shirt so we can easily divide into 2 teams. Have plenty of water. Sunscreen on a sunny day. Stretch & warm up. We'll provide discs and cones.

Weather: Rain in New England is unpredictable. We will send out a final notice one hour before start time if cancellation is necessary.

RSVP: Very helpful as this is how we contact you in case of game changes & cancellations.

About: Playing Ultimate is all about good sportsmanship, respect, and gracefulness on the field.  Fun & having a good time is a must above anything else. It's an easy game to pick up & we keep the rules minimal. No zones, no stall count, no scores, and players self-officiate on the field.  Open to all levels of players.  Beginners welcome.

Warning: Excessive fun & comradery developed from playing Ultimate may become addicting.

results.description:
Hello ASL Enthusiasts!

A number of folks living NORTH of Boston have asked about an ASL SOCIAL. Let's make this happen!

On WEDNESDAYS, starting October 29 - 6pm to 8pm - I / we will be at the NORTH SHORE MALL Food Court.

While technology has improved the way people communicate, "Deaf Social Clubs" are slowly disappearing. This is a way to start bringing REAL social interaction back!

Please join us for a casual, relaxed, no-pressure two-hour Social, where we can chat, tell stories, get to know each other, and meet new people (or old friends!). Friends, Fun and Food!

A warm welcome is extended to all Deaf & non-Deaf people: folks in the Deaf Community, CODA's, Interpreters, ASL students, parents of deaf children AND their children, ASL professors/teachers, Relay Operators, Deaf services workers- EVERYONE!

This will be a "SOME ASL KNOWLEDGE and ABOVE" Social, because not all of us are ASL-fluent! "Voices- Off" -- we'll all laugh & learn WITH and FROM each other!

WHAT: ASL SOCIAL CLUB
WHERE: North Shore Mall Food Court, PEABODY,MA
DAY/TIME: Wednesdays, 6pm - 8pm
WHY: To meet like-minded people, socialize using ASL, tell stories, and have good time!
WHO: Anyone who wants to chat using American Sign Language!
HOW TO FIND US:  We'll be sitting on the couches closest to the "walkway" side of the Food Court, not hidden inside the food court, so easier to locate us!

If you have any question, please contact Connie or Paul I., through the EMAIL LINK via BOSTON ASL profile page.

PLEASE, if you would be good enough, RSVP either "YES" or "NO" so I know who to look for!

CHEERS!

Connie Cassidy / Paul I.

PEACE...
results.why: ASL is the third largest "foreign language" in the U.S.; ASL is fun to use; ASL is NOT English, but does "borrow" from the English language.
results.how_to_find_us: The folks talking with their hands!
results.name: Weekly North Shore ASL Social!

results.description:
$20 to attend. Please be on time and sign up only if you're positive you can be present.


In this workshop we'll read your work and give you constructive suggestions to strengthen it. From larger structural and character considerations to minor formatting and story bumps, we'll help you make your script tighter, evocative, and more compelling. 


Please bring at least four copies of ONE of the following:

1. Ten pages of an original feature screenplay (or a ten or less-page short film) that you wrote yourself.
2. A treatment that you wrote yourself (one to two-page synopsis of the plot) for a proposed original screenplay. Please keep treatments to two pages maximum.


If you haven't written a script or treatment, then come with your questions and a willingness to provide constructive feedback for others.


Regardless of what you bring, be sure to PRINT OUT COPIES so that we can read it together. If you don't print them out, we'll have no way to workshop your work! At least four would be appreciated.

If you haven't written a screenplay or treatment but are curious about the process, then we definitely have a place for you. For beginners, we highly recommend grabbing a copy of The Complete Screenwriter's Manual (http://www.amazon.com/Complete-Screenwriters-Manual-Comprehensive-Reference/dp/0321397932) and screenwriting software (free: CeltX.com, more features: FinalDraft.com)

For more personalized script attention, I offer one-on-one screenplay coverage services. Details and testimonials: http://www.screenplay.guru. 10% off for Cambridge Screenwriting members.

We can't wait to see you!
results.name: Group Screenplay Workshop - $20

results.description:
At this meetup, Dr Paul Prewitt-Freilino, Director of Institutional Research, and Nathan Rush, both from Wheaton College, will be demonstrating a number of ways in which KNIME can be used to facilitate and advance institutional research. This will include:


• Combining and manipulating multiple data sources


• Creating and comparing transformations of variables for predictive modeling


• Flagging potential outliers and other problem data

Tobias Kötter, from KNIME, will be giving a talk on how he uses big data, Hadoop and Spark from within KNIME.

The meetup is very generously hosted by Swissnex Boston. Thank you Niccolo Iorno !


Agenda:

6.00 PM Introduction to KNIME, Tobias Kötter, KNIME

[masked] PM Presentations by Dr Paul Prewitt-Freilino, Nathan Rush and Tobias Kötter

7.30 PM Networking


9.00 PM Close

Snacks & drinks will be provided


Bios:

Dr Paul Prewitt-Freilino works with faculty and staff at Wheaton College to identify opportunities to enhance and grow academic programs and support student retention and success. He has many years of experience establishing institutional research offices at colleges and holds a Ph.D in Educational Leadership and Policy Studies from the University of Oklahoma. His research has focused on statistical models to predict enrollment and persistence and navigating the organizational challenges facing small colleges committed to liberal arts education.

Nathan Rush is a Research Analyst at the Office of Institutional Research, Wheaton College where he is responsible for designing and coordinating a variety of descriptive reports related to enrollment and retention. He is also an active member of the Association for Institutional Research (AIR), North East AIR and Boston AIR and presents at meetings of all three organizations.


Dr Tobias Kötter is a Senior Data Scientist at KNIME.com in Berlin. His research interests include large scale data integration and mining, graph mining, text mining and creativity support systems. At KNIME he is the scientist to talk to on the topic of using KNIME with Big Data and integrating Hadoop and Spark. He received his PhD in Computer Science from the University of Konstanz.
results.name: Data Blending & Predictive Analytics with KNIME

results.description:
Greetings Security of Things Meetup Members! Our November meeting is on! 

We'll be joining with the Internet of Things Meetup group on November 18th from 6-9 pm, with presentations starting at around 7:00 pm. Our hosts for this month's get together are  Foley & Lardner and we'll be meeting in their offices at 111 Huntington Avenue, Suite 2500. As always: food and refreshments will be served. Space is limited, so if you are interested please RSVP! 

We have an amazing agenda lined up for this month's meeting. 

First up, we'll hear a great presentation by Deidre Diamond of the firm CyberSN. 

Deidre will be talking about the (many) professional opportunities that are springing up around information security and the Internet of Things. The Founder of CyberSN, Deidre has more than two decades of experience working in technology and staffing, including a key role in the growth and transformation of Boston-based Rapid7. CyberSN was created to transform the way Cyber Security Professionals approach job searches. 

Our main speaker will be Steve Hanna of the firm Infineon. 

Steve will be giving a presentation titled:What’s The Right Security for IoT?  Steve will be talking about how to scope security for IoT and connected devices. With so many different types of endpoints and deployment scenarios, how is a company supposed to figure out what’s needed and practical? With so many security technologies, standards, and products to choose them, what's the best way to  choose among them? 

Steve is a Senior Principal at Infineon Technologies, responsible for IoT security strategy and technology. Mr. Hanna is an inventor or co-inventor on 43 issued patents, the author of innumerable standards and white papers, and a regular speaker at industry events.

Meeting space is limited for this event, so please RSVP early to make sure you'll have a spot at our November Security of Things event. 

See you there!  

Paul
results.how_to_find_us: RSVP in advance to get in. Look for Foley & Lardner booth in the lobby for name tag. Bring ID.
results.name: Infineon on Getting IoT Security Right, CyberSN on Careers in Security

results.description:
Join us for a security focused meetup in November with Tim Buntel and Paul Boss from Codiscope presenting:

Just about every week it seems like another organization is hit by a high-profile security breach— even though most of the vulnerabilities exploited are easy to fix when they’re found early. So why do we continue to see the same software security mistakes made again and again? Complex, expensive tools that live outside of the agile development process don’t help. And while most developers are aware of security, few have the specialized training to build security in from the beginning. This talk will change that by helping developers drive software security in their own applications. We will focus on Node.js (and will include a demonstration of a new developer tool), but the principles are applicable to other languages and frameworks as well.
results.name: Commit to secure software; how developers can own their own security

results.description:
Please join us at Up Your Networking Game: a multi-meetup group mix and mingle event at The Verve in Natick.


Whether you are engaged in personal or professional networking, psychologists tell us that we only have 7 seconds to make a positive impression! Join noted expert career and relationship coach, Suzanne Blake, to increase your networking skills and confidence. You will learn positive methods to initiate and grow conversations that engage your listener and leave them wanting more!

We will cover these key topics and more:

• Turn Your Blah Conversation Opening to Brilliant!

• Project a Positive, Inviting Image

• Learn to "Work the Room" and Make the Most Optimal Connections

• Overcome Your Resistance to Initiating and Maintaining a Quality Conversation

• Craft a Compelling "Elevator Speech"

• Learn Enticing Icebreakers and Small Talk

• Learn About Following Up...An Essential Skill!

You will leave feeling more comfortable with social and professional networking, with more tools to succeed!

There is no charge for this event. Cash bar. Complimentary appetizers will be provided.

results.description:
The book: The Perks of Being a Wallflower by Stephen Chbosky is a coming-of-age story that takes a look at high school in all its glory. Observant “wallflower” Charlie must chart a course through the strange world between adolescence and adulthood — first dates, family drama, and new friends — with the help of a teacher who recognizes his wisdom and intuition, and his two friends, seniors Samantha and Patrick, while mostly managing to avoid the depression he feels creeping up on him. Caught between trying to live his life and trying to run from it, Charlie must learn to navigate those wild and poignant roller-coaster days known as growing up.

I read this novel when I was in high school along with my friends, and we all loved it so I am curious to see how it holds up over time.

The venue: DUMPLINGS! DUMPLINGS! DUMPLINGS!
results.name: The Perks of Being a Wallflower at Dumpling House in Central Sq

results.description:
Come join us for a midweek climb!


All levels are welcome! If you are new to climbing, there is a belay class at 7 PM. Here is the link to sign up: www.centralrockgym.com/bookeo.php?s=watertown 

I will happily belay those who have not climbed before up until 7 PM, but then it's really important to know how to belay and to take the belay test that starts at 7 PM. You can rejoin the group after taking the belay test.

For those of you who already know how to belay, no need to take the class, you just need to pass this gym's belay test when you arrive.

The price is as follows:

Membership: $89/month

Adult Day Pass: $22 

Gear (shoes, harness, belay device): $8 ($5 for members)

Belay class: $15 (free for members)

Belay test: Free

We will meet at the cluster of cubbies on the first floor at 6:30 PM, greet each other, make sure everyone has a group or person to climb with then head off to climb. I'm looking into whether there is a place nearby to grab a bite or drink at the end of the night. If you have a place in mind, please let me know.

I'll send a message letting you know what color shirt and pants I am wearing incase you arrive late and want to search for us. I will also swing by the cubbies every 15 minutes until everyone who signed up has arrived. So, if you are not able to make it or are running late, PLEASE COMMUNICATE on this event's chat or by contacting my cell-phone, which I will send out once you are confirmed for the event.

Hope you can make it! I'm looking forward to meeting more climbers in the area.

~Avery~
results.how_to_find_us: Will meet at 6:30 PM at the cubbies by the stairs
results.name: Climbing at Central Rock (Watertown)

results.description:
Hello VMT'ers!

[This Meetup is presented in cooperation with the Boston Cloud Services Meetup group] 

VMTurbo wll be hosting us on November 18th for what should be a great meetup with some very interesting technical discussions.  In addition to the VMTurbo team, Bob Familiar will be giving a very interesting talk on Azure and microservices (full description below).  Pizza, soft drinks and beer will be served!

We'll begin at 6:30pm with time for refreshments and networking, as well as to give people time to make it to the location.  We'll start the first presentation at 7pm, take a short break afterwards, then begin the second once everyone gets resettled.  

First Presentation:

Control for Private, Public and Hybrid Cloud. We’ll talk through enterprise challenges as they move from virtualization to cloud first mandates. And a demo of VMTurbo’s application performance control system in the context of  Cloud Platforms (e.g. OpenStack, ManageIQ, AWS, SCORCH). 

Speaker: Ben Yemini https://www.linkedin.com/in/byemini 

Second Presentation:

Microservices, DevOps and Azure PaaS. Developing applications for Azure introduces new opportunities and challenges for developers, architects and operations. This session will define microservices and demonstrate how to automate the provisioning, build and deployment of microservices to Azure using PowerShell. Microservices that leverage DocumentDb, Redis Cache, Web API and other Azure PaaS services will be reviewed. Next generation microservices that leverage Azure Service Fabric will also be discussed. 

BIO: Bob Familiar is the Practice Director for the Cloud & Services team at BlueMetal, a frequent speaker at conferences and meetups and author of Microservice, IoT and Azure published by Apress. The Cloud & Services team are practitioners of Lean Engineering, a high velocity product development process that applies Lean methodology, service oriented patterns and practices and cloud platform capabilities for the design and development of modern applications. The Cloud & Services team specializes in Microservices, Big Data and Internet of Things. 

Here's a link to Bob's book:

http://www.amazon.com/Microservices-IoT-Azure-Microservice-Architecture/dp/1484212762/ref=sr_1_6?ie=UTF8&qid=1446737194&sr=8-6&keywords=microservices 

We're very excited to have VMTurbo hosting for the first time, and this should be one of the best ones yet!
results.how_to_find_us: We’re located at 500 Boylston Street, Boston on the 7th Floor. Parking is: 500 Boylston Street Garage http://boston.lazparking.com/?np_lot=500-boylston-street - $10 Parking after 5 PM, right at the office (Farther, more parking) 100 Clarendon Street
results.name: VMTurbo: Control for Any Cloud & Azure/Microservices with Bob Familiar

results.description: Come joins us as we marvel in the wonders of MTG of the past. This is a night that throws standard out the window. This is a night where anything goes. You want to play control, play control. You want to play land destruction, play land destruction. You want to Timmy, well then Timmy. This is a night where no one cries and where everyone cries. The only rule is remembering that this is a casual play format. Whatever the result is,it's still a night of fun. So do your worst, do your best and do have fun..............
results.name: Wednesday Magic in Medford Presents Throw Back MTG Night

results.description:
More than just for pasta sauce, the major culinary herbs have been efficacious herbal remedies for thousands of years. They are so important to health that their presence in our kitchens has remained unquestioned even as other herbs fell out of common usage.

We will discuss the valuable plants found on every pantry shelf and in every kitchen, in their roles as both food and medicine. We’ll cover the fascinating history of some of our most well-traveled plant companions and make and taste some recipes you can whip up anywhere you can find a chopping block. If you’ve ever wondered why sage is rubbed into lamb dishes, why all Italian food starts with sauteing garlic, or what herb you should grab if you accidentally cut yourself while chopping veggies, then join us for this tasty and informative class!

Wednesday, November 18th, 2015
7:00pm – 9:00pm
25 St. Mary’s Court, Brookline

The fee for this class is $20.

RSVP by emailing us at [masked], or calling[masked]-5274.
results.name: Herbal Kitchen Remedies

results.description:
(Please note our new RSVP policy below.) 


We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, most of which are Euro style games of medium complexity.  Games often last 90 minutes or more and involve juggling a lot of rules and factors in your head, to decide what to do.  However, there's also plenty of laughter and friendship involved.  If that sounds up your alley, we hope you'll join us. 

Our weekly meetup is in a TERRIFIC space for games steps from the Kendall Square T, with easy parking, and lots of room to spread out in.  Full directions are below.  The building door does get locked in the evening, but there is plenty of foot traffic in and out.  If you expect to arrive later than 8:30, send Tucker a message earlier in the day, and we'll make sure someone is there to let you in.

Our meetups happen once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 pm onwards.  Our group has been running since 2007, and we have a large crowd of regulars as well as new members each week.


BEANTOWN GAMERS RSVP POLICY:

1. Due to finite space, you must RSVP to attend.

2. Please be considerate of others -- only RSVP if you are likely to attend.

3. If you need to cancel your RSVP, please do so at least 24 hours before the event.  This allows enough notice for someone else to use your spot.

4. If you would like to come but there are no spots, consider attending our alternative "Light Game Night" a few steps away at Cosi Cafe.  You can also sign up as "wants a spot" and receive emails from meetup if a spot opens up.  Finally, if there are unusual circumstances, you can send Tucker a message.

5. We know everyone has emergencies.  But consistent, inconsiderate use of RSVPs -- which includes being a "no show", cancelling in the last 24 hours, or frequently cancelling RSVPs -- will lead to being removed from the group.  Sorry, we still like you, it's just not fair to everyone else!

6. If you use a "+1" spot, you are responsible for all of the above for your +1.  Since you are using two spots, it is extra important that you are considerate about it.

NEW MEMBERS: Welcome!  We look forward to meeting you.  If you want to bring a friend, please have them sign up with their own account rather than using a +1.  Unfortunately, we've gotten a lot of no-show +1's from first time attendees, so we don't accept those anymore.  Sorry!


We play whatever people bring, which typically includes a lot of Euros.  Here's a "tip of the iceberg" look at a few games that have been popular lately:

7 Wonders, Terra Mystica, Race for the Galaxy, Splendor, One Night Werewolf, Le Havre, Hansa Teutonica, Machi Koro, Concordia, Super Big Boggle

As you can see, there is some real variety.  A few of our regular attendees bring about 20-30 games between them, so there's always a lot to choose from.  But if you have a game you like, just bring it with you!

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

Finally, a note about Settlers of Catan, Carcassonne, and Ticket to Ride.  These are traditional "gateway games" that many people play when they first discover Euros.  Although you will occasionally find those games at our meetups, many of us have played them to death and have become more interested in games with a little more complexity to them.

Update (10/15): In order to accommodate more people in the room, and maintain an easygoing environment for conversation and game playing, we ask that you please save loud games (like those with real-time arguing) for later in the evening, when the room is less full.  Typically this means 9:30 or later.

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, proceed behind the T entrance (perpendicular to Main Street).  Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs or elevator straight up. Proceed straight ahead (perpendicular to Main Street). Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it.
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south.
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

Once you enter, Room 119 is just past the stairs on the right. There is a suggested donation of $1.00 that goes towards site fees and party supplies.  (When we have a raffle, you will also receive an extra raffle ticket as thanks for donating.)

Feel free to email with any questions -- we hope to see you at a meetup soon.
results.how_to_find_us: Walk a quarter of a block from the Kendall T, in the opposite direction from the Marriott Plaza. We're in the big building on your right (across from the parking lot). When you enter, our room is just across the foyer and on your right.
results.name: Wednesday Game Night

results.description:
This group is for you to BE within a comfortable and relaxing space for a little while and let go.  Nicol will lead the group through breathing, clearing and opening to all levels of your being.  Releasing all that no longer serves, removing negativity and toxicity that gets stored as energy and creates imbalances. Connecting to the Earth, to Your Core and to All That Is (whatever that is to you!).  Opening yourself as a clear channel to receive high frequencies of light/energy which will raise your vibration and personal frequency - aligning you to your highest self! You will allow yourself to expand and bask in the light of all that you are! 

This group is high vibrational and multi dimensional work - always perfect for the NOW moment!  You will receive all that you need to at this time to help you heal, grow, shift, ascend - what ever your goal is - this will be prefect for you! 

All levels are welcome!  If you feel dawn...follow your guidance and explore what is available to you...what your highest self is calling you to!

Energy Exchange $10 at the door. 

Please RSVP.

Nicol Jackson is a certified spiritual counselor and reiki master practicing for over 15 years.  Leading energy and meditation groups is her passion!

www.essencehealing.net to learn more!
results.name: Energy Group - Guided Healing on all levels!

results.description:
Are you frustrated with attracting the same type of lover only to realize that they were not actually what you were looking for?

Are you ready to attract the relationship you really desire? Did you know that your Bedroom may reveal the answer to these questions?

Kirsten Jettinghoff is a Certified BTB Feng Shui Consultant and a Certified Graduate of the Foundations Program in Eden Energy Medicine. She also works with energy as a Usui and Karuna Reiki Master and PSYCH-K practitioner. 

Visit Kirsten’s website for more info: http://www.elementalshift.com/

Come learn how to enhance your state of well-being and relationship through Feng Shui (fung-schway). The principles of Feng Shui were developed in China over 3,000 years ago based on the recognition that everything in life has its own energy or essence.  Just as the human body possesses life force energy, so does your home. The spaces we inhabit and the possessions we surround ourselves with reflect our life histories, current circumstances and our boldest desires. By shifting the energy within our space, we become supported by our surroundings allowing more energy to flow into our life.

You will receive the tools to attract a relationship using Feng Shui & go home with some concrete steps to help you continue on this journey.

We will:

·  Spend time identifying what might be keeping you from attracting the relationship you say you want.

·  Use Meditation & TAT (Tapas Acupressure Technique) to shift your energy

·  Finish up with ideas about self-love... because that is really what ties in with LOA-- you get what you give.

Please bring pen, paper and a blueprint of your bedroom.

With Love & Gratitude

Ellen Sklaver, PSYCH-K & NLP Practitioner

results.description:
The stock market can seem very daunting and inaccessible to many people because of its volatility, risks and uncertainties.   The idea of picking individual stocks has fallen out of style in favor of broadly diversified portfolios. Part art and part science, this discipline could not be more relevant in today's highly correlated markets.  

Over food and drinks at Back Bay Social Club on Boylston Street, I will lead a roundtable discussion on some of the concepts behind stock selection.  We will discuss the basics of fundamental analysis and use real world consumer examples such as Starbucks, McDonald's, Chipotle, Walmart, General Electric and Microsoft to illuminate the conversation.   

The table at the restaurant will be marked by a picture of an orange/yellow hawk pinned to a small stand.
results.name: Introduction to Stock Picking in Back Bay

group.name: Stock Market Analysis and Discussion Group

results.description:
This is our brand new auxiliary meetup event.  This is a great opportunity to socialize and play games in a relaxed environment -- and best of all, there's no cap on attendance.

We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, but the games at this particular event are going to be on the smaller side -- because those are often the games that work best in a cafe setting.

Our main meetup requires RSVPs due to heavy popularity and finite space.  This event runs simultaneously, two buildings away.  RSVPs are NOT required for this event.  RSVPs are still appreciated so the event hosts know how many people to expect, but you don't need to update them and can come even if you don't RSVP.

This event takes place once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 - 9:30 or 10.  Cosi closes at 10, but after 9:30, you are welcome to come and join the regular meetup at that point, no RSVP required.

Cosi Cafe has graciously allowed us to use their back seating area every week.  You are not required to buy anything from them, but their food is honestly pretty good, so please take advantage of them if you are hungry for dinner, soft drinks, or snacks.

We play whatever people bring, but you don't have to bring anything -- the hosts will always have a bag of games with them!  Some games that you might expect to see here include:

Red 7, Love Letter, Codenames, Pictomania, The Resistance, Avalon, One Night Ultimate Werewolf, Bang!, Glory to Rome, Innovation, Mottainai, Chrononaughts, Time Lines, Tash-Kalar

If you're looking for longer or larger Euros (like 7 Wonders, Puerto Rico, or Terra Mystica), check out our regular "Game Night" meetup.

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, turn left and walk about 20 feet to Cosi.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs up, then up again towards the busy street, which is Main Street.  Turn left and walk about 20 feet to Cosi.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it. 
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) One side of the parking lot has a bunch of buildings with a handicapped ramp leading into it.  Go up the ramp, through the walkway, and Cosi will be right next to you when you come out.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south. 
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) One side of the parking lot has a bunch of buildings with a handicapped ramp leading into it.  Go up the ramp, through the walkway, and Cosi will be right next to you when you come out.
results.how_to_find_us: Steps from the Kendall Square Red Line, in the middle of the block.

results.description:
Anyone who loves ASL is welcome to come and be part of the fun! We want to warmly extend an invitation to Deaf people or others fluent/skilled in the language (CODAs for example) to join our group.

This is an easy-going, casual, ASL get-together to meet people who enjoy American Sign Language, who want to brush up on their signing skills, and want to learn more ASL by using it as often as possible.

We strive to have a good time and communicate without using voices. If we need to, we draw or write what we don't know how to sign, and if lots of folks show up, we split up into small groups and mix and mingle, so we can actually see one another clearly, face-to-face and get a good conversation going.

results.description:
Join the Boston Austrian Economics Group as we embark upon Chapter 6, of Part 1, in the Austrian classic; "Human Action: A Treatise on Economics," by Ludwig von Mises. The group will discuss the weekly readings and questions.

Please note that the readings are not required to attend our meeting, but are recommended. As always, anyone interested in economics is welcome.

Tony C's Sports Bar and Grill has plenty of parking and is accessible via the Orange Line "Assembly" stop. 

READINGS:


Chapter 6: UNCERTAINTY

QUESTIONS:


 1) What does action imply, and what role does it play in the field of action?


2) What is probable interference, and what are the two distinct fields of probability?

3) In class probability, we know everything about the entire class of events or phenomena, but what crucial piece of information is missing?

4) When factoring in risk, how does an insurer differ from a gambler?

5) What are the main differences between class probability and case probability?

6) What are the differences between betting and gambling, and how does gambling become betting?

7) Is betting and gambling an action?

8) When attempting to model the market economy, why is game theory misleading?

9) What can be predicted with the aid of praxeological knowledge?

10) What distinguishes quantitative approaches from qualitative ones? 11) What four points were accomplished by Mises, about action and uncertainty, in this chapter?

12) In discussing class probability, what did Mises mean when he said; “crude circularity implied in all definitions referring to the equiprobability of possible events?”

BONUS: Which is the most popular “game theory,” and why?
results.name: ACTION AND UNCERTAINTY

results.description:
PLEASE NOTE: In anticipation of the Glass-Chewing Leader of the Cartel's imminent absence due to Family Growth, hosting duties for the regular Wednesday Night Gaming is being handled by a rotating cast of regulars.

Wednesday Night Gaming is our more-or-less weekly free-for-all of strategy gaming goodness downstairs at the Porter Square Panera. There's rarely a set agenda for these events but you are welcome and encouraged to hash out a plan beforehand in comments if you've got something you're dying to play. Nonetheless, you are not required to bring a game to play -- our only requirement is that you bring an open mind!

The event officially begins at 7 PM but people often trickle in early, so you're welcome to sit down to a filler game to get warmed up, or arrange to meet a little early if you've got a group looking to tackle an extra-meaty game.

Please be aware that Panera has been quite gracious about hosting us with minimal fuss -- in order to keep things this way, please respect the hardworking people who work there and, especially, their desire to get out after a long shift.

We'll see you at the gaming table!
results.name: Wednesday Gaming In Porter Square

The Handmade's Tale is a seminal work in the feminist literary canon. 

Additionally, below are some events that might be of interest:

Dry Land

http://www.bostontheatrescene.com/season/Dry-Land/ 

"Emerging as the Lena Dunham of the theatre world, 21-year-old playwright Ruby Rae Spiegel — a finalist for the Susan Smith Blackburn prize — writes a brazen, no-holds-barred play about that time in your life when no one else can possibly understand what you’re going through. 

A story about abortion, bad jokes, bathing suits, and friendship, DRY LAND, a New York Times critics’ pick, is a brave portrayal of the contemporary American teenager that epitomizes What’s Next in American theatre."

results.description:
Welcome to the weekly BKBS Wednesday meet up. Please join us at 7:00 PM by the 3rd table station in the middle of the top roping / lead area. If you are still by the bouldering wall, keep on walking.

We usually meet there for about 10 mins, and then team up in groups of 2 or 3 for top-rope climbing.

If you know that you'll be late, let us know in the comments section, and maybe tell us what you'll be wearing, so we can look out for you. 

BKBS (http://www.bkbsomerville.com/Classes/. If you have a working knowledge of how to belay, you will need to be belay certified before climbing on the ropes. Please flag down a BKBS employee and let them know you need to take a belay test. To pass such a test you will need to display how to tie a double figure eight knot with a fisherman's backup, safely belay a climber up a wall, catch them on a fall, and lower them to the ground safely.

What equipment do I need?  You will need at the bare minimum a harness and climbing shoes. Rentals are available. Grigri devices are provided at every station.

What if I can come, but at a different time?  Just let everyone know you want to climb at a different time and use the community to find a partner for those dates / times.

These are the climbing rates:

ADMISSION (Full day use, you can leave and come back!): 

Day Pass - $25 (Students $20) 
10 Pack - $225 (Students $180)

(Membership Pricing also available)

RENTALS: 

Shoes - $5 
Harness - $5 
Chalk Bag - $2 
Full Gear Kit - $11
results.how_to_find_us: The third table in the middle of the climbing area between 7:00-7:10 PM. It's the table in the middle of the TR \/ Lead area.

results.description:
This month Edward Kmett will be speaking about his recent investigations into propagators, a framework for bidirectional and parallel computation. He'll explain the basic ideas behind them, and, time permitting, his ideas for connecting them to other areas in computer science research, such as LVars, SAT solving, integer linear programming, constraint programming, conflict-free replicated data types and Datalog, and then stealing techniques used to make those other domains efficient for the rest of the propagator problems.


Logistics: 

If you can, please plan on arriving between 6:45pm and 7pm, but there will be someone in the lobby to greet stragglers.

Food:

Pizzas, salad and soda.

Afterwards:

If you'd like to stick around, a number of us tend to head down to the CBC or another pub afterwards to socialize. If you would like to give a talk or if you have any questions or concerns, please feel free to follow up here or email one of the organizers.
results.how_to_find_us: Simply come to the front door of Akamai. If you can, please plan on arriving between 6:45pm and 7pm, but there will be someone in the lobby to greet stragglers.

"Energy Deregulation: the $500 Billion Frontier (of what?)"


Alex Rhalimi will present what energy deregulation is, how it works and relates to us consumers, and what that means for ecologically-informed visions of human life on the planet. Buffett and Gates each has said that energy deregulation is the biggest transfer of wealth in the history of business and it's ongoing (from The Motley Fool).

Learn about carbon reduction and sustainability impacts.

Wednesday evening discussions with community forming. Discussions and Q&A will follow each presentation. For some interesting comparisons, bring your utility (light, electricity) bills.


Alex Rhalimi's weekly Wednesday evening opportunity meeting is at the Hilton Garden Inn at Boston Logan Airport.

results.description:
Here are just some of the things you can get out of these meetings:

• Access to thousands of dollars of courses, software, and other resources

• Advice on overcoming a business or marketing obstacle you're facing

• Accountability

• Ideas and inspiration

• Meet awesome people who enjoy talking about this stuff as much as you do

Or, you can be a fly on the wall.  No pressure at all.  Feel free to drop in to just listen and see what internet marketing really looks like from people who are actually doing it.

We try to keep the meetings to about 60 - 90 minutes.  Here's the way it works:

• 7:00pm Join the meeting here:  https://hangouts.google.com/call/dq4qhhdefftaq3fmqwij2ipe2ea.  It tends to work best with Chrome (rather than Internet Explorer or FireFox).

• Intros, and goal checking:

• New Members:  What are you working on?  And what is it you hope to get out of attending these meetings?

• Existing Members:  How'd your week go?  Did you accomplish your goals?  What are your goals for next week.

• Check-Up on last week's Couch of Insight participate:  What results did he/she get from the session?

• The Couch of Insight:  One member goes into depth on what they've been working on, telling us where they need assistance, what resources have helped them to be successful, and what strategies have been valuable.

• (Meeting Ends around 8pm officially, but usually runs late with people wanting to help the person on The Couch.)

• Chat and Offer Assistance: The Hangout will remain open until everyone leaves.  You can stay as long as you want to meet new members and give the person on The Couch any advice or feedback you may have.

Feedback

What's ONE thing that would have made this meeting better? Either let me know during the session, or you can keep it anonymous by filling out the a Survey Monkey (I'll provide the link in the session).

<a href="https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/KFNMRFX"></a>
results.how_to_find_us: Google Hangouts.  Join by clicking the link in the description.  Give it a shot before the meeting to make sure you can join without any problems.  Let me know if you're having trouble.

results.description:
More than just for pasta sauce, the major culinary herbs have been efficacious herbal remedies for thousands of years. They are so important to health that their presence in our kitchens has remained unquestioned even as other herbs fell out of common usage.

We will discuss the valuable plants found on every pantry shelf and in every kitchen, in their roles as both food and medicine. We’ll cover the fascinating history of some of our most well-traveled plant companions and make and taste some recipes you can whip up anywhere you can find a chopping block. If you’ve ever wondered why sage is rubbed into lamb dishes, why all Italian food starts with sauteing garlic, or what herb you should grab if you accidentally cut yourself while chopping veggies, then join us for this tasty and informative class!

results.description:
Join 50 to 80 or 100 dancers any Wednesday at Dance Freedom!!

We are the original barefoot weekly dance, continuously running for 44 years, that has spawned hundreds if not thousands of other dances around the world.

In a drug, alcohol, and shoe-free environment, we've been making friends and sharing safe and juicy dances for decades. Come join the fun!! Discover the joy of dancing in a totally non-judgmental atmosphere, where anything safe and respectful goes... dance by yourself, in a group, with a same or opposite sex partner, or even just chat and enjoy watching.

First time visitors are welcomed heartily, and get in for half price! Otherwise, you decide what to pay in a range from $10 to $20, or less later in the evening as the event nears its end (information on late admission discounts is at the door). Our friendly dancers range from utterly new at it to very skilled dancers in funk, rock, salsa, modern, jazz, hip-hop, African & Latin and swing, tango, contact improvisation, and our own unique spontaneous creations! Dance with or alongside amazing dancers from local dance troupes as well as with ordinary good-hearted rug cutters. At work they may be doctors, lawyers, programmers, massage therapists, expressive therapists, artists, students, dog walkers, scientists, or anything else, but at heart they all love to dance.

The music runs the gamut: funk, world music, soul & r&b, house, trance, hip-hop, salsa, yoga music, jazz or swing, reggae, disco, you name it! Each DJ from our rotating list has a unique style, but we try to include something for everyone in every set. We keep a good balance in the music: familiar with unusual, timeless with current, melodic with drum-based, and positive lyrics with instrumentals--in all kinds of rhythms & styles! In any given evening, the world music parts of our dance are likely to include at least 3 or so of the following... African, Latin, Indian, Middle Eastern, Caribbean, zydeco, gypsy and much more. You'll hear everything from basic party music to very danceable songs with socially conscious lyrics, but you won't be hearing anything sexist, racist, violent, hating or otherwise divisive.

Start with a soothing stretch and warm up at 7:30, connect with the group and start to boogie at 7:50 with our first DJ of the evening, take a brief break at 8:50 for community announcements and a short unique performance or workshop (or chatting & stretching in a way that doesn't interfere), then cut the rug again by 9:15 at the latest with the evening's second DJ, till 10:30--plenty of time for a great workout and some feel-good inspiration and respiration and perspiration!

At the beginning of each half of the evening's music, everyone who wants to gathers around a centerpiece to hold hands, and dance in a winding chain together to a song with uplifting, connective (or at least beautiful and hypnotic) slow to medium tempo rhythms. (This dance was created from out of a drumming circle on the Cambridge Common in the sixties, after all, and some of that great political and community spirit still lives on here.) Then, it's all dance music, generally building in tempo to a crescendo, slowing down again for some more melodic and slow dance songs for a few minutes, then gradually building to a second crescendo. The second half of the evening's dance follows roughly the same pattern with a different DJ and style, and ends with another circle dance for those who enjoy it.

Dancers are always welcome to help with set-up or take-down, and get in free for doing so! It's a great chance to get to know the community better and be serviceful, as well as to save money and help us to be around for another 42 years... Welcome! For more information, E-mail: [masked]
results.how_to_find_us: Opposite the Cambridge Common, see the Sheraton Hotel w/the big red letters COMMANDER on top.  Enter the stone church just left of hotel, @ entrance closest to hotel.  Follow the hall straight, left and right to the desk to sign in.
results.name: Dance Freedom 11/18 Dj's Dustin & Alan S.

results.description:
Good TIDE-ings,

I invite you to join me for an enchanting evening of sea sounds. Every Sound Healing that I do has a theme. The theme for 11/18 revolves around Neptune moving out of retrograde and going direct. The changing energy affects us on a mental, physical and emotional level, moving us forward in our spiritual endeavors.


Neptune rules the oceans of Earth and is quite fluid, changeable and illusory in nature. Dreams, illusion, abstract thought and the mysterious are all governed by Neptune. Our spirituality is important to this planet, and how we harness that energy for our personal betterment is the focus of 11/18, which is the day Neptune stops moving backward through the zodiac and resumes its forward movement.


Neptune retrograde, which lasts half a year, has been important in helping us to bring critical focus to the confusing and illusory aspects of our life so thatwe may correct them. Neptune retrograde causes us to no longer be able to ignore things like bad relationships, debt or toxic habits. In retrograde, Neptune has been pushing us to stop dreaming and start doing as we figure out what is real from fantasy and plan more deliberately for actualizing the future we want to manifest by re-evaluating what is important to us. Now, on 11/18, as we move out of retrograde, it is the time to explore the space of what we want our future to feel like. With Neptune’s forward turn, we lift the lid on the innerwork of retrograde to move forward with our spiritual and artistic endeavors, leaving behind the unwholesome bonds that do not bring us love, light and balance. Tuning into Neptunian energy can strengthen our sense of discernment to detach from draining delusion and dysfunction and transition to what is soul-nurturing. So don't overthink what Neptunian energy should 'feel' like. Just float and feel the inspiration flow in!

So if you come to the Buddhist Temple for a sound healing, what can you expect?

When you come in, you take your shoes off, then you walk to the Dharma Hall which will be on your immediate right at the top of the stairs. We'll start with a short introduction and discuss each of our intentions for how we want to work with the sound and then meditate for a few minutes to tune into each of our specific intentions. The general theme will be answering the wake-up call to the divine presence ... And trust me, if you come, you will hear it ringing ; )

Then, everyone will sit or lie down on super comfy pillow mats (bring your own blanket/blindfold) and we'll begin our journey into sound.

I start by playing the 500 pound cast-iron temple bell and then I move into the sweet sounds of my Tibetan singing bowls. The three I use to entrain the brain to meditation allow the body to enter deep relaxation so that the body, mind and spirit are capable of opening to the really deep work that needs be done!

What follows, I can't exactly say, as the sound decides what it wants to say. But you can expect to hear the rainbow voice, the sound of the overtone chant singing with the tibetan bowls. You won't be able to tell which is which but this is all part of the dance. You will even feel what it's like to have the bowls played on you as the sound moves your energy where it needs to go. Tingshas, tuning forks, rattles and more are all part of the play as the sound moves you to rest at your destination without ever having moved. So, please, come and feel something unique. You never leave anywhere exactly the same, but when it comes to sound healing, you will leave sounding more like yourself :)

Suggested donation is $20 and please bring a blanket to enhance the comfort of your experience!  -Much love

Brian 

Contact: [masked]

results.name: Toning NepTune: Sea Sounds for Diving Into the Divine

results.description:
NOTE CHANGE OF VENUE

Join Peter Petersen and Monique Darling for a delightful evening of diving into the 4 elements

• Air

• Earth

• Water 

• Fire (my favorite!)

MOVING MEDITATION

First, Peter brings his love of a moving meditation from China called Qigong.

For thousands of years people have captured the essence of these simple movements to maintain balance and to heal themselves mentally and physically. Qigong accelerates healing and has a positive clinically recognized effect on almost all physical symptoms. Qigong helps heal the physical body and release stress of the mind. By moving your body, releasing trigger points, and stimulating your circulatory system, you literally become your own massage therapist. Simultaneously these movements help release negative emotions and memories that you no longer need and allow yourself to be much more present in your "now" so in a sense you become your own psychiatrist at the same time! Come learn how to build the foundation of being your own health advocate and enjoy emotional freedom and connection to all that is!

CONNECTION, MUSIC, DANCE

Then Peter will take you on an expedition, an adventure through movement and connection, both inward and outward as he takes us on a dance journey that has destination stops at each element. Music is selected to take you through each of the four elements (plus a surprise 5th element) that eventually leads you back to your center (Spirit) Allowing your True Self to be revealed!

SENSUAL TOUCH, BREATHING, CHAKRA BALANCING

Then learn how to empower your sensual conscious touch. Explore the tactile language of stimulating arousal, that touches the deepest part of our soul.

This experiential laboratory will include breathing and chakra balancing meditation, and playful, non-sexual massage. Monique will guide you through an odyssey of touch, that let's you explore the 4 elements, on/through each other.

First you will go on a journey using the most intimate form of touch, our breath. We’ll be introducing an ancient ritual where you will explore each-others bodies, magnifying your connection physically, energetically, and spiritually.

Then align your chakras through touch, breath, connection, and shared intent.

Next comes earth touch, as you ground, and recenter, massage, nurture, hold, BE with one another.

Followed by fire, as you invigorate, entice, awaken, arouse, "heat" up yourself and your partner

Cooling down with water touch, fluid, soft, caressing, gentle, swaying, following, gliding

EXPERIENCE YOUR EMBODIED BLISS STATE

With each element drop even deeper into your embodied bliss state as you learn to touch for YOUR pleasure, as you get to practice asking for the specific types of touch your body is craving/imagining at any moment.

Finally Peter and I, being two Massage Enthusiasts, will lead you through some simple massage techniques for neck, hands and feet and even throw in some of our own unique “black belt” tools that will leave your partner breathless and asking for more.

Bring a partner or come solo and be paired up with practice partner's for the night so you can take these skills home and wow your lover!

Bring a cushion, water bottle, and a curious, open mind.

Wear comfy clothes that you can move around in.


Love Exchange $35 per person $60 a pair

RSVP here: https://foundationsboston.eventbrite.com/


About Your Facilitators

Monique Darling, workshop facilitator extraordinaire has led over 800 workshops in the past 5 years. She is the founder of Juicy Enlightenment an organization dedicated to empowering people who are questioning the assumptions of how their life should be and to offering tools for self expression that create trust, inner knowing and wisdom to enjoy the life they have. Monique has been featured on TLC and The Dr’s as well as various radio shows, podcasts and magazines across the USA. She specializes in helping others reclaim their power and natural sensuality by transmuting fear and repression into courage, self-love and freedom. Her primary purpose is helping folks bring out their vulnerability, energetic embodiment and fearless relating.She guides from a place of understanding and her natural exuberance is infectious! She is available for private sessions, experiential workshops and Cuddle Parties. Learn more about Monique by going to 

juicyenlightenment.com

 or track her whereabouts at 

whereintheworldismoniquedarling.com


Peter Petersen has been teaching for 13 years and has been a certified Sheng Zhen Qigong teacher for the last 11 years, where he has been teaching in health clubs, hospitals, retirement villas, and several different wellness/spa resorts in Mexico and the United States, such as Rancho La Puerta, Mayacamas Ranch, and Present Moment Retreat. Peter is also a personal wellness coach. This Qigong practice helps people ground themselves into their “now” to increase their present moment awareness of their behaviors, and find solutions to problematic habits such as: eating, moving, negative thinking, and sleeping. The result of this tool box of healthy information is that clients become their own health advocate and regain a sense of stability, peace, and well-being into their everyday lives.

results.description:
Free lecture by Steven Pinker, an experimental psychologist at Harvard, cognitive scientist and linguist, author of 10 books, who been named as one of the world’s most influential intellectuals. In "The Sense of Style," he asks why so much writing is so bad. We can’t blame bloviators, the Internet or today’s youth; good writing has always been hard. Rather than worrying about the decline of the language or recycling spurious edicts from century-old rulebooks, we can apply insights from the sciences of language and mind to the challenge of crafting clear, coherent, and stylish prose.


If people are interested, we can go for ice cream at Rancatore's or a drink at Vine Brook Tavern afterwards.

More info:

http://carylectureseries.org/the-sense-of-style-the-thinking-persons-guide-to-writing-in-the-21st-century-with-steven-pinker/
