results.description:
Ellen Jaffe JonesThe Veg Coach

Creative Cook / Author / Consultant
From our test kitchen to your home kitchen

OK, show of hands.  How many of you eat quinoa as a side dish?
Most cooks use the protein-rich grain as a substitute for rice.
But, I've got a treat for you today.  It's a recipe for Quinoa crisp chocolate balls!
What a way to reward yourself for following a healthy lifestyle.

Find it below.

Consider this too as a tasty approach to getting people interested in coming to one of my FREE cooking classes. This week, Wednesday at 9pm EST, I'll be doing a free class prepping and serving 2 recipes from my book "Eat Vegan on $4 a Day." Bring any questions to our Google Hangout: 

https://plus.google.com/events/c0oegddjuh07utbrq1mv6vm1rfg

Happy cooking,

Ellen Jaffe Jones
The Veg Coach
http://www.vegcoach.com

Buy my books:

Paleo Vegan

Eat Vegan on $4 a Day

Kitchen Divided - Vegan Recipes for Semi-Vegan Households

This is a Quinoa crisp chocolate bar you might find at your local health food store.  
But, my recipe lets you create your own Quinoa chocolate treat.  

It'll satisfy your chocolate cravings and it's so easy to make.  

The recipe is below.

You're Going to Love This!  

Quinoa Crisp Chocolate Treats
by Ellen Jaffe Jones

INGREDIENTS 

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

PREPARATION INSTRUCTIONS

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

Melt chocolate chips in a double-boiler, or place in a microwave-safe bowl and heat for about 60 seconds until the chips develop a slight sheen.  
Place all ingredients in a medium pot (or add to the double-boiler) and over medium heat, and stir constantly for about 5 minutes taking care not to burn the chocolate. 
Form small balls and place on a non-stick cookie sheet.  
Refrigerate for at least 60 minutes before serving.  
For those wanting to reduce fat intake, this can be made without the coconut oil, but make sure the chocolate chips are completely melted.   

Buy The Books

results.description:
Important - for this event you must register using this link. The registration fee includes a full breakfast at the Riverbend restaurant

David Maffei, Chief Revenue Officer of Akumina, will lead this month's discussion. The creation of the Chief Revenue Officer was driven by the need to reimagine the way we do business. Nearly every element of a traditional business in 2015, and certainly those elements that are customer facing, directly affect the generation of, protection of and efficient performance of a company’s revenue. 

Revenue generation doesn’t start and stop with sales and marketing, it is the overall accountability for the success of every aspect of a business that can influence what creates and drives revenue for an organization. Departmental silos guarantee failure – and the companies that are succeeding today have figured that out. 


Bring your own ideas and plan to participate! On the third Thursday of (almost) every month SAMI hosts a breakfast discussion on a topic related to new directions in sales and marketing. 

Join us by registering here!
results.how_to_find_us: We're in the Riverbend restaurant at the back of the first floor
results.name: The role of the Chief Revenue Officer

The Golden Chickpea in Brookline Village is hosting a breakfast on Thursdays for Moms and babies/toddlers. The little ones can play while we chat- there are plenty of toys. Hope to see some of you there!

http://www.thegoldenchickpeacenter.com

At The Golden Chickpea Center, we provide a warm and friendly atmosphere with emotional and social support in Brookline Village. Our main objective is to strengthen the initial emotional bond between families and their children in the community, particularly those who have no other family in the area.

In a cosmopolitan city such as Boston where young families come from many parts of the country and the world, due to education and professional opportunities, being far away from family is a common occurrence. Our center is a great alternative to fill this need.

We aim to be the premiere urban destination for cosmopolitan families with young children to socialize, have fun, and experience the richness of different cultures among us.

 Our Center is a welcoming place for families of all compositions and backgrounds where children and parents can learn, play and grow together creating shared experiences that last a lifetime... 


If you are one of those  families, join us,  you will feel at home!

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Thursday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

results.description:
Steven Pinker: The Past, Present, and Future of Violence

Thursday, November 19, 2015
5:00pm 6:15pm
Harvard, Science Center, Lecture Hall D
“The Past, Present, and Future of Violence.”

The past: Contrary to the popular impression view that we are living in extraordinarily violent times, rates of violence at all scales have been in decline over the course of history. The present: Human nature comprises faculties that encourage violence, such as dominance and revenge, but also faculties that inhibit it, such as self-control, empathy, and reason. The level of violence in a given society depends on how its norms and institutions affect the balance between them. The future: Professor Pinker speculates on which of the historical changes that reduced violence in the past will continue into the future.

This lecture is open to the public.

RSVP: https://www.facebook.com/events/1515601885430457/

Hosted by Harvard College Effective Altruism.
results.name: Steven Pinker: The Past, Present, and Future of Violence (hosted by Harvard EA)

Wholesaling: Let's Dig into the Numbers

We're digging into the wholesale process!

Chris Coute of Brownstone Realty Group will go in-depth on estimating properties. Learn how to give real numbers to the rehabber, so thta their Maximum Allowable Offer allows for profit for everyone. Then, he'll review wholesaling and rehabbing deals he has done in the last six months.

Chris Coute has been wokring in real estate for over ten years, both as a top real estate agent in the Taunton area, as well as an active redeveloper  within the New England area. As part of MassCEC’s Boston Cleanweb Meetup Series, please join us for a panel discussion focused on bridging the developer and cleantech communities and highlighting exciting opportunities in the field of Cleanweb.

Engage in an interesting conversation about the applications of information technology, and build connections with individuals working in energy production, grid-modernization, energy efficiency, and water technology.

Panelists:

Martin Flusberg (Powerhouse Dynamics) Jamie Lefkowitz (OptiRTC) Chris Davis (Cimcon Lighting Inc.)
Moderator:

Thomas Burton (Mintz Levin) Cleanweb is a category of cleantech that intersects with and leverages the capability of big data, the internet, social media and mobile technologies to address energy and natural resource consumption and environmental challenges. Cleanweb goes beyond the typical images associated with clean technology and power generation – PV panels or wind turbines – to include the broad range and huge potential of all types of digital media and information technology

Please be sure to register on the Eventbrite page here!

results.description:
Hello Boston Node Community!


Please join us for our next meetup on Thursday, November 19th at LogMeIn's HQ in Boston's Innovation District.  Come for the awesome talks, and stay and chat with fellow Node community members while enjoying free snacks, beer and wine - sponsored by Xively.  Here's who's on tap:

----------------------------------- 

Shai Sachs, Software Architect at NGP VAN, Inc.
@shaisachs
https://github.com/shaisachs


RESTful APIs with HAL and JSON via the Open Support Data Interface

Shai will talk about bringing a core product API written in .NET into compliance with the Open Support Data Interface (http://opensupporter.org) which uses HAL+JSON for discoverability via an open-source facade layer (https://github.com/NGPVAN/osdi-service).  He will dive into OSDI, the reasons behind selecting Hypertext Application Language (HAL) and then go through the implemented solution.

----------------------------------- 

Jonathan Ross,  Director of SDK Development at Jibo
https://github.com/golgobot

Jibo is building a family robot for the home that ships in Spring of next year. Jonathan will share experiences about building a robot platform and SDK that runs on GitHub's Electron (http://electron.atom.io) runtime - which is based on Node.JS and Chromium.  We'll bring a robot and have Jibo introduce himself. Then we'll demo the SDK and show how to build a skill (or app) on him using our toolset build on Atom.  Jibo swag will be available!  Jonathan will also talk about the newly formed Electron meetup group and some of the group organizers will be there to give a quick overview.


----------------------------------- 

As always, if you have any questions or comments about our next meetup please post on the meetup page.

If anybody would still like to talk at a later meetup or has ideas for a future meetup, please let me know.  I already have a small backlog of talks and hope to plan an early-mid December meetup as well - but there may still room for one or two more so please email if you want to speak!  I hope to see many of you in 3.5 weeks.

Ciao!

- Brian

results.description:
Please Join us for the 2015 Boston Latino International Film Festival for 2015 inauguration and films.

BLIFF 2015 will take place on November 19th to 22nd, at two venues:


• Harvard University, CGIS South ($10 each day..Thr/Fri)

• Northeastern University   (Free for Sat/Sun)

This meetup is for the Festival Opening on Thursday, November 19th.

5.30 p.m. Opening reception. Sponsored by Jose's Mexican Grill.

7.00 p.m. Opening program 

I Just Had a DreamDir. Javi Navarro, 7 min. Short Narrative, Spain 

The Empty Classroom, El Aula Vacia 107 min. Feature Narrative. 

Multiple  Countries: Uruguay, U S A, Peru, Mexico, El Salvador, Colombia, Brazil,  Argentina  

Under the creative direction of Gael Garcia Bernal, ten award-winning directors tell the story of the high school dropout crisis in Latin  America in an anthology of narrative and documentary film as beautifully  diverse and complex as the region. 

Travel to seven different countries and  explore the underlying reasons why nearly one out of every two students  never makes it to graduation day. Issues explored range from extreme rural  schools in northern Argentina, to students displaced by conflict in  Colombia, to young people with disabilities in Mexico, to gang violence in  El Salvador, to indigenous rights, to poor education quality. 

Directors: Gael Garcia Bernal, Carlos Gaviria, Daniel Vega, Diego Vega,  Eryk Rocha, Flavia Castro, Lucrecia Martel, Mariana Chenillo, Nicolas  Pereda, Pablo Fendrik, Pablo Stoll, Tatiana Huezo

results.description:
Analytics.Club's Monthly Meet-N-Greet Mixer

About the Event:

Monthly Meet-N-Greet Mixer networking event is conducted every last Thursday of the month. This event will primarily focus on building networks to initiate good conversations on data science across different venues around the town.

The monthly event will be Networking only mixer(Just plain and simple networking with no long sales pitch or knowledge sessions) envisioned to keep local data science professionals connected. You will use the opportunity to exchange contact information, seek opportunities, and connect with fellow data science professionals and build deeper connected networks.

Goal: We hope you at least make 2 new contacts / event & spread the word on event so more and more data science professionals could leverage the opportunity to build their personal network.

When: Last Thursday of the Month

Time: 6:00 p.m. - 8:00 p.m.

Location: Local Bar / Cafe  (hopefully a new exploration every month). Venue will be our participating members choice and will be finalized one week prior to the event every month. 

* Please provide a bar/cafe recommendation in the comment section and vote yes if you agree *

Refreshments/Drinks: Buy Your Own Drink/Meal

(We appreciate sponsor pitching in on drinks/refreshments to support a great cause)

Agenda:

0. Put name tag with following initials in circle (optional, for effective networking):

a. (B) for Business Background 

b. (C) for Coding Background 

c. (S) for Statistician Background 

d. (T) for Technology Background 

e. (M) for Math / Modeling Background

1. Open networking (20min)

2. Job / Employee seekers pitch (20min)

Quick pitch (90secs each) from Job seekers or recruiters

3. Product /Project pitch session (20min)

Quick pitch(2min each) from data enthusiast who wants to share among fellow data science professionals.

4. Open networking (60min)

FAQ:

1. Can I be the event host/organizer for an evening?

Yes. We do appreciate our community members to take charge and help build a great networking event. Please make your interest known to us in comment section.

2. Can my company sponsor for the drinks/refreshments? What do they get?

Yes. Besides great karma points for helping build a strong data science community, the company will also get face time with brightest data science professionals for brand recognition. You also get an opportunity for a 90 sec pitch time about the company & job openings.

3. Will event still happen even if there are no sponsors?

Yes. As long as there is a mutually agreed bar/cafe for the evening the event is a GO. Attendees will buy their own drinks/refreshments.

4. Could we volunteer our office space for the networking?

Yes, one of the bigger objective for the event is to introduce various innovation/discussion hubs to data science community.

5. What are the possible scenarios in which event can be cancelled?

Public Holidays, Bad Weather, Lack of interest or No venue.

6. I still have questions. How can I get them answered?

Best way is to put them in comment section, so that even our members can pitch in. You are welcome to email us as well at info[at]analytics[dot]club
results.name: Data Analytics.Club Monthly Mixer

results.description:
Join us for a presentation by InterSystems about how they are using Open edX to change their education culture with Open edX.

We'll also have an open discussion time, so bring your questions and topics.  Open edX adopters and contributors will be on hand from edX and other institutions around Boston.

Pizza will be provided! :)

Talk description

Learn how InterSystems is shifting from traditional classroom training to training thousands of people anywhere, anytime using Open edX for Online Learning. 

Hear how InterSystems’ strategy is transforming the learner’s experience, as well as creating a culture of learning internally and with its customers. Specific lessons learned and recommendations will also be shared with participants. This talk is especially valuable for corporate organizations just starting out with Open edX.


• How InterSystems addressed the challenge to meet highly-technical training needs and demands of our company internally and externally with partners and end-users using Open edX

• How InterSystems addressed the challenge to scale traditional classroom training, which included access to virtual training environments/sandboxes for hands-on exercises, by using Open edX for online training with virtual lab environments 

• How InterSystems leadership came to understand the need to transform our corporate culture to a culture of learning, what that means for our company, and the opportunities it presents to both us and our customers

• How InterSystems enhanced Open edX for corporate-use online learning

• How the structure and organization of corporate-use of Open edX differs from other use-cases

• How InterSystems developed a model for building online courses using Open edX

• Understanding new models for learning online

• How our strategy for online learning is transforming our learners' experiences.

Speakers

Janine Perkins, Project Manager, Online Learning – InterSystems

Janine is currently the Project Manager for Online Learning at InterSystems where she is helping the company move from offering mainly classroom training and videos to offering interactive online training, including online labs. Janine has been working in the online learning field for over 13 years and has experience in online learning development, implementing learning management systems and marketing. Previously, Janine was an implementation consultant at Centra Software, now Saba where she worked as an Implementation Manager to help customers launch online synchronous training.

Jim Breen, Director, Learning Services - InterSystems

Jim is currently the Director of Learning Services at InterSystems Corporation and has held the role for 14 years. As Director, Jim is responsible for all aspects of education and training worldwide, including: business development, global training teams, classroom delivery, online learning, tutorials, video-learning, certification, international university outreach and a global internship program. Jim is currently executing a strategic plan to foster a culture of learning at InterSystems by transforming learners’ experiences through the utilization of online learning, both internally as well as with customers.

Doug Foster, Manager, Online Learning - InterSystems

Doug Foster is currently the Manager, Online Learning for InterSystems where he is leading a team to transform how they develop and deliver training to their customers and partners.  Prior to InterSystems, Doug was the Director of Learning Services for Boston Scientific where he led a centralized team   responsible for their SuccessFactors LMS and all centrally managed training for 25,000 employees globally.  Previously, Doug was the VP of Services for Click2Learn (now SumTotal Systems) where he lead a team responsible for the development of custom eLearning for clients such as Fidelity and Microsoft.

About InterSystems

InterSystems develops advanced software technologies that enable breakthroughs. With a passion for excellence and a focus on client success, InterSystems provides data management, strategic interoperability, and analytics platforms used in healthcare, financial services, government, and dozens of other industries. In selected countries, InterSystems also offers unified healthcare applications, based on its core technologies that deliver on the promise of connected healthcare. Founded in 1978, InterSystems is a privately held company headquartered in Cambridge, Massachusetts (USA), with offices worldwide, and its products are used daily by millions of people in more than 100 countries. For more information, visit InterSystems.com.
results.name: Transforming Business Education Culture: from Classroom to Online Learning

results.description:
The Boston Traders Meetup will be hosting a monthly options meeting to discuss options trading. This will be an informal gathering of folks who trade options who would like to share their knowledge and learn from each other. 


Beginners and experienced traders are welcome.


This event will be held on the Thursday evening before the monthly expiration Friday.* Holding the meeting at monthly expiration will allow people to discuss the trades that they have put on during the prior month and perhaps to share ideas for trades to put on in the next month. For weekly options traders, the monthly expiry is of little significance unto itself, but for the monthly options traders, it will hold more significance.

Mary-Lou Drozek will be moderating this meeting. She has been trading options for about 5 years and is happy to share ideas.

The meeting location is Panera Bread in Quincy, which has wifi and is visible from the North Quincy T stop on the Red Line. The location could possibly change, so please check back with the event page just to confirm the location before heading off to the meeting.

-------------------------------------------


* Meetup allows for scheduling "the third Thursday of the month," but not the "Thursday before the third Friday of the month," which is what we need. Using the Meetup scheduling system alone without intervention would mean that the third Thursday will be on expiration week except for those months starting on a Friday, as is the case in August of 2014; in which case, the meeting would fall a week after the monthly expiry week. We believe that we will be able to successfully manipulate this consideration in the meetup system to keep the meetings all on the Thursday evening before expiration Friday. If you see a meeting time that isn't the Thursday evening before expiration Friday, please let us know and we will correct it. Thank you.

results.description:
Seth Maislin is a principal consultant in information architecture and digital transformation at Earley Information Science. For more than 20 years, Seth has demonstrated strengths in classification and taxonomy, content modeling, IA, search, and UX. He collaborates with clients on designing and implementing sustainable information management solutions that address real and complex findability and productivity challenges. For clients such as Walmart, Motorola, EY, Corning, Hasbro, Staples, JP Morgan, and Consumer Reports, Seth develops content and governance frameworks for keeping internal and external web content environments both competitive and in the forefront of their business strategies.



Content Types That Fit Your Content

SharePoint content types are in important first step toward classifying content, but often business is more complex. Knowing how to define content types – and even how many are appropriate – requires an understanding of user behavior and content, clear requirements for search design and site UX, and an honest look at governance and maintenance practices. In this presentation, Seth will provide clear guidelines for navigating content types and taxonomy in SharePoint 2013, and show how you can achieve enterprise consistency while allowing flexibility within smaller user groups.
results.name: Content Types That Fit Your Content

results.description:
IMPORTANT: RSVP required; please click here!

After a political regime rapidly collapses leaving society in near total chaos, as happened in Iraq in 2003, what happens next? Why were Shiites more successful in limiting violence and providing public goods than Sunnis were in Iraq? Why have many women in the Middle East resorted to increasingly conservative modes of dress in recent decades?

Many of the current conflicts in the Middle East have been attributed to sectarianism, a politicization of ethnic and religious identity. From the crisis in Iraq and Syria to the tension between Iran and Saudi Arabia, the struggle between Sunni and Shiites groups for dominance is tearing apart the region and shows no signs of abating; however, for all the religious discourse permeating the conflict, much of its roots are political, not religious. How does sectarianism fit into a larger narrative of the Middle East? How have governments manipulated sectarian differences? And finally, what is the U.S. doing about it?

- See more at: http://worldboston.org/event-calendar/making-sense-of-isis-and-sectarianism/#sthash.FalxQILt.dpuf
results.name: WorldBoston Event: Making Sense of ISIS and Sectarianism

results.description:
Please join us for networking and pizza at 6 PM followed by our discussion on Spark!

Presented by: Rich Tarro, Big Data Architect

Spark is hot and is certainly generating a lot of buzz in the industry. Spark is fundamentally shifting the way data and analytics are exploited by organizations by putting analytics into action where and when it is needed. With Spark, algorithms and big data models can be developed and built quickly with faster iterations enabling intelligence to be embedded into applications for web, mobile, social, Internet of Things as well as business process applications – enabling analytics to take a key role in the way an organization operates and makes decisions.


In this session we will explore the technology behind Spark, how it enables such fast processing, its ease of use in writing applications, and how it can combine different types of analytics such as SQL and machine learning seamlessly in the same application. In addition, we will look at Spark in the context of IBM Bluemix, which not only offers an integrated experience for data scientists and analysts to perform interactive analytics with Spark, but also enables Spark applications to  take advantage of the wide range of services available on Bluemix.

Agenda

- Networking and dinner

- Overview presentation highlighting capabilities

- Demo's focused on Spark Python, Spark SQL, Spark R demos and more!

- Discussion and Q+A

Still haven't registered for your free Bluemix account? Sign up here to get started: www.ibm.biz/cloudboston
results.name: Spark, Big data and Analytics Meetup

results.description:
There are many herbs that support the immune system and help us to stay healthy throughout the cold and flu season. In this class, we will discuss immune strengthening herbs that can be used to prevent illness, as well as immune stimulating herbs that can be used for acute situations. Throughout the class we will sample herbal teas, tinctures, and essential oils and discuss how and when to use each appropriately. Participants will leave an informative handout (including useful herbal recipes) and the knowledge to create their own herbal medicine cabinet for wintertime wellness. With Steph Zabel, herbalist, ethnobotanist, and founder of Flowerfolk Herbal Apothecary and Herbstalk. Trustees member: $15, nonmember: $25.   Presented by Trustees of Reservations.

REGISTER: http://www.thetrustees.org/things-to-do/greater-boston/event-21982.html

Event is held in the Kitchen at Boston Public Market 

For more information, please contact:

Michelle de Lima

Lets get a drink before the Show!  We will meet at the Bar at Orleans (65 Holland St) at 6pm.  If you get there right at 6pm you can probably order some food but we will leave at 6:40pm.

If you miss us at Orleans look for us upstairs in the balcony at 6:45pm.  It is difficult to reserve a large number of seats but we will try to save a few.  Most years we end up sitting in a few groups.


The show starts at 7:00PM.

Tickets:
Save $4 per ticket when you buy during presale. 

1. Buy online with the presale code: presale2015

2. Avoid fees and get a free vintage Warren Miller download
by purchasing at participating REI locations.

General public sale begins on Sept 21.

*In-store presale open to REI members only.

http://www.skinet.com/warrenmiller/

"This fall, Warren Miller Entertainment introduces its 66th snowsports film, Chasing Shadows. Watch JT Holmes, Seth Wescott, Caroline Gleich, Steven Nyman and more as they pursue turns on the mountains of our dreams: Chamonix, Alaska’s Chugach, Utah’s Wasatch and the mightiest range of them all: the Himalaya.

These athletes are masters in their element, and with every cliff drop, perfect line and knee-deep powder turn, they motivate us. Warren Miller once said, “A pair of skis are the ultimate transportation to freedom,” and this year, we’re chasing storms, snow, lines and the freedom they grant us. Take a glimpse into the world of the U.S. freestyle team and the dynamics of snowsports that live on the fringe, like monoskiing, powsurfing and speed riding.

Explore what it means to be inspired, and what it is about exotic locations and snow-covered summits that keep us searching for more. As skiers and snowboarders we chase a feeling, a memory, a storm, a turn — we’ve been chasing it our whole lives and we’ll keep chasing it a lifetime more. Winter starts with Warren Miller."

Additional information to follow.
results.name: Warren Miller's - "Chasing Shadows" movie

results.description:
Come join the Skimos for the best way to jump start the ski season -with a showing of Warren Miller's latest ski film, "Chasing Shadows"  We'll catch the Thursday, November 19th, 7pm show at the Somerville Theatre in Davis Square.  The movie preview on theWarren Miller website website</a> looks awesome!  Join us for a breathtaking global ski tour that will get you fired-up for winter, craving fresh snow, and wishing you were out there riding and skiing!  Tickets are just $20, and you'll get several free 2-for-1 lift ticket deals and other giveaways.  Hangin' with Skimos will help you to take advantage of these special deals -you can always find a lift partner to share in your deal most any weekend during the ski season at our cozy lodge in Jackson, NH.

The movie starts at 7pm, so we'll meet at <a href="http://johnnyds.com/">Johnny D's across the street from the theater at 6pm for drinks and a quick bite.  Look for ski bums and you've found us!  We'll head over to the theater as a group and meet inside the theater on the second floor balcony at 6:45pm for anyone who can't make Johnny D's  -don't be late so we can sit together.  We will sit upstairs so we can grab seats more easily. We could also have a few post-movie beers as well -that would be a great way to meet fellow Skimos and make plans for skiing.  The Somerville Theatre is in the middle of Davis Square, right next to the Red Line T-station.  Buy your tickets at the Somerville Theatre box office, or online before they sell out..! Online tickets go on sale on September 21st at Somerville Theater Events

Hope to see you there!

S-kimos Social Committee

results.description:
Monthly Code & Coffee events are back! Come join us on the third Thursday of every month for coffee, code, and camaraderie.

General Description of our Code and Coffee Events:

Code & Coffee is a monthly opportunity for you to practice your skills, meet new friends, and get help if you need it. Bring your laptop, your recent projects, and your programming problems!

All are welcome regardless of gender or skill level, whether or not you've attended past Girl Develop It events. If you're a beginner, we'll be right there to help you work through your questions as needed.

Code & Coffee events are relaxed and informal, and are intended as a way for our community to work and play together while providing each other with ongoing support and feedback.

This event is free, though of course we encourage you to support our location host, Clover, with a purchase of coffee or a snack.

Feel free to come early, stay late, and/or drop in whenever you can. We can't wait to see you!

We welcome and encourage runners of all levels – dreamers, beginners, as well as those with running experience, past or present. Our volunteer runners will be there to coach you at your current level, and help you meet your goals. We might even be able to help with running gear if needed. 

We meet twice weekly at the Reservoir (Cleveland Circle/Reservoir Green Line C or D train) -- on Saturday mornings at 10:00 am and Thursday evenings at 6:30 pm. We will first gather in front of the Starbucks in Cleveland Circle, before heading over to the reservoir. See you there!

results.description:
"Broadening our visual experiences and influences can enliven and stimulate our creativity and imagination. By exploring other visual art forms such as paintings and sculpture, and how these artists create by using color and visual design, we expand our own concept of experience and expression in our photographs. " Bruce w. Heinemann

Greetings Photographers!

We can discover a great deal about taking better pictures by looking at the paintings of accomplished artists. I visited the Guild of Boston Artists a few weeks ago for the first time. I discovered they have many talented artists who specialize in capturing the luminous effects we are often attempting to create in our photography. I immediately signed up to be on their mailing list and so I know they are having a special event next Thursday Nov. 19th.

At this special reception several artists including Dennis Sheehan (pictured above )will be present to talk about the way they translate their experience of the landscape into a painting. They will briefly discuss topics such as composition, color, and light. And of course these are the same topics we are exploring week after week in our photography workshops.  

I hope you will come and engage with the artists, ask questions about their creative process, or just take time to look at their paintings and discover some new design elements you can include in you photography.

 It is a great evening, so come enjoy a glass of wine and ask the questions you have always wanted to ask. This is also a great opportunity to meet others in the group if you are new to our meet up so I hope you will come out and join us. 

Please RSVP here an then I will contact the gallery and let them know how many of us are attending so they can plan accordingly. 

Hope to see you there! 

Suzanne
results.how_to_find_us: Look for Suzanne
results.name: Free Photo Social: The Guild of Boston Artists Reception

results.description:
Please go here to register for this free event. 

The disruptive force of new algorithms and big data has reached the financial world. What does this imply for the traditional banking system? What are the scientific underpinnings of the innovations of "Fintech"?  How are crowd and data intelligence going to change the relationship between financial institutions and their costumers? Are traditional portfolio management, decision making, and risk taking going to be replaced by artificial intelligence?

On November 19, a panel of FinTech experts from Switzerland and the US are going to discuss the underpinnings of Artificial Intelligence and examine key questions about its implications. 

Event Hashtag: #AIfinancePanel

Panel


Moderated by Sarah Biller, COO of Innovation, State Street Global Exchange

• Nader Erfani, FinTech Entrepreneur, Founder of Quantesys

• Sridhar Iyengar, IBM T.J. Watson Research Center (TBC)

• Adam Broun, COO at Kensho 

• Andreas Heinrich, Swiss AI lab IDSIA


Program

• 6 PM Doors Open

• 6:30 PM Welcome Address by Dr. Felix Moesner, CEO of swissnex Boston

• 6:40 PM Panel discussion, Q&A followed by Networking Reception

• 8:30 PM Doors Close


Please go here to register for this free event.
results.how_to_find_us: Register here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/the-future-of-money-artificial-intelligence-in-finance-tickets-19331046681

YES - park in the lot

NO - don't cut in line

YES - get there early (doors at 7. get there by 6:45)

YES - dress for stargazing

YES - look for the meetup sign, or just talk to the people around you. Everyone here is Nerdy and Fun whether or not they found out about this event from this meetup group.

We generally sit on the back left of the auditorium. Or we get there too late and end up in the overflow room. THEN we try to find each other in telescope lines on the roof.

MAYBE - we'll go out somewhere after, maybe not. Folks might be tired, or hard to collect into a group, or self-organizing and looking for beer, or burgers.


- H

From the Harvard stop on the MBTA Red Line, take any bus or trackless trolley going west on Concord Avenue in Cambridge (Arlmont Village and Belmont Center buses; Huron Avenue trolley) and get off at the Observatory Hill stop.

For more information go to  http://www.cfa.harvard.edu/events or call 617.495.7461.


The CfA would prefer that attendees not take pictures, but if you decide to, please do not use a flash.

******************************

From the CfA:


Watch It Live

Rediscovering Pluto


Kelly Beatty, Sky & Telescope

In mid-July, NASA's New Horizons spacecraft flew past Pluto after a 9-1/2-year journey. But really this historic encounter has been 85 years in the making, ever since 24-year-old Clyde Tombaugh discovered this enigmatic body at the edge of our planetary system. Today we realize that Pluto is among the largest objects in the Kuiper Belt, even though initially it was believed to be a body perhaps as massive as Earth. This presentation traces the history of Pluto - from predictions of its existence, to the discovery of its moons, to its "demotion" to dwarf-planet status - and explores the amazing, unexpected findings revealed by New Horizons. An award-winning writer and communicator, Kelly Beatty specializes in planetary science and space exploration as Senior Editor for Sky & Telescope magazine.


******************************

NOTE: if anyone would like to be an assistant organizer to help run various* events please contact me - Heather

*various = various science and nerdy events around town, and NOT the ones that only market your own event/product.  (SPAM=no)

The waiting list and attendance limit is for the CfA to have a more accurate attendance count.

Please RSVP truthfully. 

If you end up on the waiting list and you REALLY like the topic you can show up anyways as this is a public event.

Thanks!

H

results.description:
Plugging Into Phoenix by Johnny Winn


Elixir Fountain host Johnny Winn will be visiting Boston to present from sunny Jacksonville, FL. He'll show a non-standard use-case for building a Phoenix application.

Phoenix & Ember Living Together, Mass Hysteria by Brian Cardarella

Learn how DockYard is building Ember applications backed with a Phoenix based JSON-API server. We'll discuss, through code, how a server-side application and client-side application can be developed in tandem, how to fully test the stack in development and in CI, as well as why Phoenix is such an amazing choice for building APIs for your favorite client-side applications.

Valid Field by Dan McClain

Dan is going to show his valid_field library for unit testing changesets

We are still seeking a host for November. If your company would like to sponsor this meetup please get in touch!

results.description:
{If we can reduce stress in our life, we can immediately improve our quality of life.  Come and explore what causes you stress, and how to take better care of yourself. 

Our Topic This Evening Will ....

... help you identify your stressors, teach you ways to deal with them, and show you how to prevent them.  

We all have stress.  Stress comes from many places.  What are the stressors that you are currently aware of? What tools or resources do you now use to deal with them? 


Terry will:
• Overview five categories of stressors that can cause a ruckus in our lives.   
• Explore examples of individual stressors within each category.  
• Illustrate the patterns of symptoms that individual stressors can cause.

You will:
• Identify which individual stressors impact you the most
• Learn what what you can do to address the symptoms, and,
• Learn how to avoid these stressors. 

To prepare ....

1)  What do you think your stressors are?
2)  What are your most common symptoms?
3)  What do you typically do to deal with your symptoms?

Our Leader This Evening

Terry Plante is a PGN organizer, a licensed acupuncturist, and a registered pharmacist.  Terry received her Bachelor’s Degree in Pharmacy from Massachusetts College of Pharmacy. She holds a Master’s Degree in Acupuncture and Oriental Medicine from New England School of Acupuncture. She is licensed by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts Board of Registration in Medicine.

Terry is dedicated to helping people live a physically thriving, emotionally balanced, and spiritually connected life.  She specializes in an allergy recovery program and in an emotional release technique.

Terry has successfully used acupuncture/acupressure, and various stress reduction techniques to help hundreds of patients with a variety of acute and chronic physical and emotional health conditions. Successfully treated patients had symptoms including depression, anxiety, digestive disorders, integrated sensory dysfunctions, acute and chronic pain, and allergies. 


In addition to acupuncture, Terry has utilizes emotional release techniques to eliminate allergy.  Children and adults with even severe reactions to foods like dairy, egg, wheat, soy, fish, have experienced amazing results.  Terry’s tactic is to detect to what the patient reacts and to re-program the body to be non-reactive.  These techniques have allowed Terry the relieve patients of severe allergies.

Terry has been a pharmacist for over 12 years, specializing in retail pharmacy. She has a great deal of experience with counseling patients one-to-one on therapies with pharmaceutical drugs, with natural products, and with herbal medicines (both Chinese and Western). 

Terry Is also certified In:
• Nambudripad’s Allergy Elimination Technique (NAET)
• Neuro-Emotional Technique (NET)
• Auricular Therapy (Ear acupuncture)

Links

In mid-July, NASA's New Horizons spacecraft flew past Pluto after a 9-1/2-year journey. But really this historic encounter has been 85 years in the making, ever since 24-year-old Clyde Tombaugh discovered this enigmatic body at the edge of our planetary system. Today we realize that Pluto is among the largest objects in the Kuiper Belt, even though initially it was believed to be a body perhaps as massive as Earth. This presentation traces the history of Pluto - from predictions of its existence, to the discovery of its moons, to its "demotion" to dwarf-planet status - and explores the amazing, unexpected findings revealed by New Horizons. An award-winning writer and communicator, Kelly Beatty specializes in planetary science and space exploration as Senior Editor for Sky & Telescope magazine.

how to get there
Entrance is at the west of the CfA complex, near Madison Street and large parking lot. The CfA is easily reached by public transportation. From the Harvard MBTA Station (Red Line), take any bus or trackless trolley going west on Concord Avenue (Arlmont Village and Belmont Center buses, Huron Avenue trolleys) and get off at "Observatory Hill."
results.name: Rediscovering Pluto - Harvard SmithSonian

results.description:
Join Frederick for an interesting talk and demonstration toLego Mindstorms. Mindstorms is one way to get into robotics - you've got sensors and motors and a controller and all the possibilities of the lego system for the mechanics. Like with anything though lego robots have their good points and their bad, and my intent here is to walk through what you can expect from the current lego mindstorms set, what it can do and how you work with it.

What to expect at this meet up:

• Demos

- demos of R3PTAR and EV3RSTORM, two of five example robots in the current Mindstorms retail set. Those example robots have build instructions, pre-built behaviors, and can be controlled from the mindstorms iOS app

• Quick overview and history of lego robotics

• EV3 Mindstorms set, price, what you can do with it, what it contains

• EV3 Programming, demo of a read-a-sensor move-a-motor program and then a walkthrough of programming custom behavior for R3PTAR

• Beyond the basics

- EV3 and arduino

- EV3 and ROS (Robot Operation System)

- mechanical engineering with lego
results.how_to_find_us: This will actually take place in the Innovation Space. It is easy to get there from HATCH, it's is directly across the hall and has a big sign that says Innovation Space.
results.name: Intro to Lego Mindstorms

results.description:
Join us for an evening of Conscious, Connected breathing. We'll use the transformative power of the breath to still the mind, clear the emotions, and deeply relax your body.

We were inspired by Lisa and her work back in July when she guided us through freeing ourselves from stress and tension using the breath at our July Heartbeat Salon, so we've decided to bring her back for an encore and deepening. We're looking to follow up with a 6 session series!

You will learn:

- A proven and effective practice to gain freedom from the “monkey mind” to attain joy and any personal intention you desire.

- A self-facilitated method which , when practiced over time, will  effectively release stress, depression, anxiety, sleeping problems, stuck old “tapes”, patterns, beliefs and suffering.


“The process of breathing is much more than an essential function of your physical body. Indeed, it is the flowing of Spirit to you, and through you."Abraham

</a>

Our facilitator for the evening is Lisa Jones,  a Certified Breath Coach who has taught thousands of students and supported their journeys into the body/mind realm through  breath awareness classes, since 1998. She is a member of the Global Breathworkers Training Alliance. She invites all to share the insights and joy that come from incorporating body, mind, and spirit into their wellness.

Lisa is committed  to building  breath communities, adding to the ones she facilitates in Peterborough, Boston, and Providence.  She says: "When we breath consciously as a community the amount of healing that takes place is phenomenal for individuals, their loved ones and the planet." 

For more information on Lisa's work, classes and private sessions,
check out her website at:  <a href="http://www.NiaNHandYoga.com">www.NiaNHandYoga.com
and her blog:  http://nianhandyoga.com/blog/
110 Route 101A, Amherst, NH 03031
[masked]

"This was a fantastic workshop...time flew-by! Lisa is a knowledgeable and experienced facilitator. I highly recommend her for this type of work." July participant

results.description:
This monthly Meetup is a place to learn tunes and to play them slowly with other musicians. The tunes we play can be found here (Sheet Music). Since the list is getting large we have started selecting a rotating list of about ten tunes a month that we will definitely play so that new members can have a chance to play along without learning every tune right away. I update this list and email it monthly.

This is still a new group, and how we go about learning and playing is still a work in progress. But the goal is to have fun, and to get together with others who enjoy playing Irish music. Musicians of all levels are welcome. Since the goal here is for everyone to play, new members are encouraged to suggest tunes from the list and to suggest tunes to add to it. If the group as a whole knows a tune well, we'll play it slowly a couple of times, and then pick the tempo up a bit. 

Note on tempo

If you have gone to a typical Irish Session, we play a little faster than half that speed. But we'll start tunes slowly enough that everyone should be able to play along and learn by ear. If you haven't been to a session it is best to just show up and see if the tempo suits you :)  If you like metronomes...  For Reels (4/4), Hornpipes (4/4) and Polkas (2/4) set the metronome from 100 to 140 BPM and play one quarter note per click. For Double Jigs (6/8), Slip Jigs (9/8), and Single Jigs (12/8) set the metronome from 65 to 95 BPM and play three eighth notes per click. 

Directions

By Subway

The closest Red Line stop is Davis Square. From Davis Square you can either walk Northwest on Holland Street or take the bus (the 87 or the 88) to Teele Square. It is about a 10 minute walk between Davis and Teele Square. You can recognize Teele Square as a 5-way intersection with a small triangular island having a sign that says Teele Square. From Teele Square walk North on Curtiss Street for 3 blocks to Powder House Boulevard. The church is on the NE corner of the intersection.

By Bus

The 87, 88, and 89 buses stop in Teele Square.  The 87 bus runs between Lechmere Station (Green Line) and Arlington Center. The 88 bus runs between Lechmere Station (Green Line) and the Clarendon Hill Busway. The 89 bus runs between Sullivan Square (Orange Line) and the Clarendon Hill Busway. You'll want to get off the bus in Teele Square. From Teele Square walk North on Curtiss Street for 3 blocks to Powder House Boulevard. The church is on the NE corner of the intersection. The 77 bus runs between Harvard and Arlington Heights. You can walk from Mass Ave to Teele Square.

By Car

There is parking behind the West Somerville School that is one block West of the church. Parking there is available after 5PM even though the signs are somewhat ambiguous. From Powderhouse, turn onto Curtis, heading up the hill toward Tufts. Take the first left turn from Curtis onto Raymond Street. Ignore the NO LEFT TURN sign, as it is only in effect during rush hours. Raymond runs behind the school. The lot is about half a block down Raymond on the left.

Street parking is also available one block away on Packard Avenue from Powderhouse Blvd on the hill to the Tufts University campus. Pay attention to street signs to avoid parking in a restricted area.

See the map at: http://clarendonhillchurch.org/...

Accessibility

The church has a lift that requires someone to move from a wheelchair to the chair on the lift. I haven't had time to look at this yet, but I will have someone show it to me over the holidays.

results.description:
Itadaki downstairs bar (Boston, Newbury St. between Gloucester and Fairfield) 7 pm to 10 pm

Join me at this izakaya style venue for a pleasant evening of drinks, food and chats. Whether you're learning Japanese or English, buy a drink, join the table, and practice your new language in a friendly and relaxed environment. If you're a beginner or just interested in culture, you'll fit in fine! Don't miss out on this opportunity to learn and practice over a few drinks. Can't make it on time? Need to leave early? Not a problem. Just stop by if you can!

If you are >21 and plan to drink, please bring a MA state issued ID or passport. Other state IDs may not be accepted. Please order at the bar and take care of your own tab.

Transportation: I highly recommend using public transportation. Not only is driving while intoxicated dangerous, but there may not be any parking available in the area. A lot of the parking on Newbury St  is Residential Only in the evenings, and many of the signs indicating this are very well hidden. If you insist on parking in the area, be aware that meter maids love handing out parking tickets around here. Best methods for public transportation are the green line subway or bus #1 to the Hynes stop.

I have made an arrangements with the Itadaki staff for a simpler ordering method. Last time was very chaotic and stressful for the bartender, so lets do our best to not confuse the bartender. :)

Ordering at Itadaki

1) Order your first drink at the bar. If it's alcoholic, your ID will be checked at this time. You will also be  given a guest number to use the rest of the night.

2) If you're at a table, the bartender will try to make several rounds throughout the night to take additional orders. Keep using your guest number and please feel free to order more food and drinks.

3) Keep in mind we're a pretty large group so don't be offended or annoyed with the bartender if he doesn't get to you right away. If you have an urgent order, go request it at the bar.

4) Please take care of your tab and don't forget to tip*. The management and staff are doing a lot to make this all possible.

*Note: If the group is large, an 18% tip may already be included.

See you there!
~Lindsay

results.description:
Hello all,


Our November OpenStack Meetup  is all about Neutron - more specifically we will deep dive into a number of advanced services in Neutronwith Akanda as our co-sponsor.

Our session will be led by Eric Lopez from Akanda. Eric will deep dive on advanced services such as Routing and Load Balancing in Neutron. We will then drill down into typical service provider network designs and the specific technologies in use such as Linuxbridge.  We will discuss Neutron Advanced Services driver model and how it can be useful to Service Providers (and Enterprises) based on our team's experience powering Dream Compute’s networking capabilities using Akanda. 

We will review Akanda, an open source suite of software, services, orchestration, and tools for providing L3+ services in OpenStack that builds on top of Linux and OpenStack Neutron. 


Eric has over 15 years of experience in information security, distributed systems, networking and virtualization technologies. As a Sr. Solution Architect  Eric helps customers implement and integrate networking and OpenStack. Prior to Akanda, Eric joined VMware via Nicira acquisition.


Eric holds Master’s degree in Business Administration from University of San Francisco and Bachelor of Science in Electrical Engineering & Computer Science and Nuclear Engineering from University of California, Berkeley.


Reminders:

• A light dinner and soft drinks will be provided courtesy of Akanda ~ 6:30pm and we will kick off the sessions ~ 7:00pm.

• If you are interested in giving a Lightening Talk shoot us a note with a topic or just come to the session ready to speak!

• DON'T FORGET - for security reasons, the NERD center requires attendees to show a government issued photo ID in order to gain access into the building.

• Parking: Best option for parking is the NERD center parking garage which charges a flat rate after 4pm.
results.name: OpenStack Neutron Advanced Services Deep Dive

We will not have a MUA this evening, please come prepared to do your own hair and make-up. If you would like to model for this shoot, please respond ASAP via email, that includes a phone number, ASAP so that you can be put on our list. The model coordinator for this is Larry Cahill. results.description:
Have you read any extraordinary (personal growth) books that have made a powerful impact on your life?  
Join us for an inviting evening of interactive conversation - an opportunity to share with each other inspiring and empowering things we’ve been reading or exploring. 

This month in our MetroCharles Heartbeat Salon

... rather than having a formal presentation or workshop, we'll have a fun community growing opportunity to share and explore with each other. 

So many of us enjoy reading personal growth and self empowerment books and blogs or listening to inspiring podcasts and radio shows. 

But how often do we have an opportunity to talk about what we’re learning or share and deepen the insights we’ve gleaned by having interactive conversations about it?

Well we’re excited to offer an opportunity for that this month. It will be an easygoing, conversational format. 

Come If you have something that you’ve read or learned about that you’d love to share with others. 

Or come if you are simply looking for inspiration and are wondering what interesting things others have been learning about.


To prepare for this evening... 

• If there is a book (or blog or podcast, etc) you want to talk about, take a little time before we meet to reflect on what it is about it that inspires you. What did you learn or get out of it that makes you want to share?

• Also, if you like, feel free to post a link to the book, etc. in the comments section below once you’ve rsvp’d. That might even get the conversation going before we meet! (note: this isn’t required; it’s also ok to surprise us that evening with what you want to share)

Our Leaders This Evening...

… all of us. 
It will be a community co-created Salon gathering this month.

Links


For Newbies: 
  *  What is a Heartbeat Salon? 
  *  Guidelines for Attending a Heartbeat Salon .

For Veterans: 
  * Find a Heartbeat Salon Near You . 
  * Calendar of Upcoming Heartbeat Salons. 

For Hosts: 
  * Hints on How to Host a Heartbeat Salon . 
  * Topics from Past Heartbeat Salons .

For Presenters: 
  * Hints on How to Present at a Heartbeat Salon .

Suggestion Box: 
  * Suggestions for a Heartbeat Salon (topics, locations, etc) .

results.description:
Ongoing class in Medieval and Renaissance Longsword in the tradition of Johannes Lichtenauer.


The Longsword is the iconic fantasy Knight's sword - a two-handed, straight blade with a cross guard. The weapon may seem to be simple at first but is in reality a weapon of finesse and skill.


The class covers all the basics of footwork, attacks and defenses. Drills are developed from simple to complex; from rigidly choreographed to open-ended. Timing, distance and judgement are developed.


All classes begin with a Strength & Conditioning program designed to physically prepare one for fighting with the sword. Elements develop agility, core stability and power.
results.name: Lichtenauer Longsword

results.description:
Louis Katz, as seen on Comedy Central, Late Night with Jimmy Fallon, America's Funniest Comics, and other places on earth, will headline this month's edition of Strange Behavior at the historic Davis Square Theatre. Come spend a Thursday evening with one of NYC's top comedians as he performs with Brendan Eyre (Montreal Just For Laughs) and NYC's own Scotland Green in this intimate, 175-seat blackbox theatre! 

Thursday, 11/19 features: 

Louis Katz (Comedy Central Presents, Late Night with Jimmy Fallon)
Brendan Eyre (Montreal Just For Laughs)
Scotland Green (Brooklyn Comedy Festival)

For tix and info: http://bit.ly/1HuIVSp 

Louis Katz Bio:
Louis Katz’s comedy deftly combines the highbrow and the lowbrow, creating a style that is truly unique. An internationally headlining comedian, Louis' numerous television appearances include NBC’s “Late Night with Jimmy Fallon,” HBO’s “Down & Dirty w/Jim Norton,” and most recently, Comedy Central’s “Comedy Underground w/Dave Attell.” He was also a regularly featured writer/correspondent on FX’s “Totally Biased with W Kamau Bell.” His half-hour “Comedy Central Presents” special aired in 2011, coinciding with the release of his debut comedy album, “If These Balls Could Talk,” on Comedy Central Records. Louis also produced a series of short films for Adult Swim’s superdeluxe.com, which can now be seen at youtube.com/louiskatzcomedy.

“Katz is funny to the point that Hitler would have given him a sleeper car on the train.” - Doug Stanhope


For more information:
www.davissquaretheatre.com
results.name: Strange Behavior @ Davis Square Theatre!

We will be playing indoors at the Mansfield Sports Plex (31 Oxford Rd, Mansfield, MA).  They have both courts and a turf field.  We can use cleats, sneakers, or indoor soccer shoes on the turf field, but only sneakers/indoor soccer shoes on the courts.  

Come prepared to play on either surface because if we get too many for the turf, we'll have to split into two games (one on turf and the other on the courts).

results.description:
Sign-up link for the webinar is here: https://www.innerengineering.com/online/webinars?signinsrc=Meetup-NewEngland

***REGISTRATION closes 45 minutes prior to the webcast.***  Please make sure you sign-up on our website at least 45 mins prior to the webcast to receive your live log-in link via email.


(Technical Support: <a>[masked]</a>)


The Inner Engineering online program includes guided meditations, powerful breathing techniques, and deeply engaging discourses about the nature of the mind and practical wisdom to manage life’s situations.

Inner Engineering is a combination of methods derived from the ancient science of yoga that addresses every aspect of human well-being — from your body, mind and emotions to the essential life energy within.

This 1 hour introduction to Inner Engineering explains the fundamental approach of the program in a live setting that offers you the opportunity to ask a trained Isha teacher questions about the program and practices available.

“Inner Engineering is neither a religion, nor a philosophy or dogma; It is a technology for wellbeing. One does not have to believe or disbelieve, you just have to learn to use it. Technology will produce results irrespective of who you are.” – Sadhguru
results.name: An Introduction to Inner Engineering--FREE Class (Online Webinar)

results.description:
It's time for Sketchhaus again! NOVEMBER IS HERE. The weather's colder. You're trying to avoid your family. What better time to get warm with some piping hot Sketchhaus?

First up: it's Vitamin Snake! VITAMIN SNAKE are not snakes nor do they take vitamins. Put down the gun SLOWLY and come out to see some hilariously dark sketch comedy. Relive that moment when you found that dead body under your floorboards. With Jon Costanza, Matt Wiffin, Adam Finne, and Michael Taft!

THEN YOUR HEADLINER: From the worst people in Boston comes a show that you will hate yourself for liking. With: Allen McRae, Laura Clark, Ashley Voltz, Ben Scurria, Steve Delfino, Will Van Antwerp, Matthew Fear, and Dave Grinstead!

PLUS: your host for the evening is the astounding Conor Allen, fresh off his stint at Laugh Boston! ALSO: Special Guest Star Adam Abelson, with a beary strange tale! What a killer night of comedy, and it's all for you!

SCRIMMAGES

In the Fall/Winter (September - April), we have scrimmages every Thursday night (except holidays) starting at 9:00 pm at the Simoni Skating Arena in Cambridge, Massachusetts.
All players of all skill levels are welcome. Come and skate with us, or just stop by to meet the players and learn more about Boston Pride Hockey.

We typically gather at a local establishment, afterwards. You can just drop in, or feel free to contact us to get the name of someone who will be at practice that night so you will know who to ask for.

Based on the roast battles taking over New York and Los Angeles, COMIC vs COMIC is Boston's very own comedy roast based competition. We've gathered some of the fastesst rising stars of the Boston Comedy Scene and pitted them against each in four marquee matches that will test their ability to take a joke as much as it does their ability to serve it.
On November 19, 2015, Sean Sullivan, one of the top roast comics in New England, hosts the first ever COMIC vs COMIC showdown featuring:
JOHN PAUL RIVERA vs TED PETTINGELL
EMILY RUSKOSKI vs KENICE MOBLEY
WILL SMALLEY vs ANDREW MAYER
and our main events, both from Last Comic Standing Season 10,
DAN CROHN vs STEVE MACONE
This event is guarenteed to be a show that you will never be able to see again. Come join the rowdy party and be there to hoot, holler, and cringe as friends battle friends for the ultimate braggins rights.

results.description:
Curation of the photography in the Oncology Wing at Baystate Franklin Medical Center continues and I’m back looking to the group to provide the photos! "Summertide Reverie” will be the name of this exhibit. The idea is to bring the warmth of summer to Oncology during the long months of winter. Start looking though your images now so they are available to upload once submission entry begins! If you have not confirmed you will be attending I will be sure to add you in once submission entry begins.

The guidelines as I’ve made them up so far are:

*** New Guideline*** Though everyone will be added as going, those who RSVP "Yes" prior to the meet up date will have 1st access to downloading images. 


Nov 20th Submission Entry Begins
1 Max number of submissions: 3 images
2 Include “The Image Title” by clicking on the “Add caption” field under uploaded images
3 Images can be vertical, horizontal, square, and panoramic, but max horizontal width is 24” including a frame.
4 File size for the MeetUp site must be under 10MB*
* PLEASE make sure your file size is large enough to enlarge well without deterioration of the image quality.
Dec 04th Last Date of Entry

Dec 05th Voting Starts
1 Choose your favorite 19 images submitted by other photographers by add a VOTE comment**
2 If we have over 20 people submitting images than only 1 image per person will be chosen so we can include as many people as the walls allow
3 ANYONE in the group can vote and we encourage EVERYONE that entered an image to do so
**Vote like you were the person choosing the images to be in the show
Dec 18th Voting Ends

Jan 01st Latest date for chosen photos to be confirmed***
***Due to the holidays I allowed myself some extra tabulation time

Jan 08th Information Due Date
Email [masked] with the following information:
1 Your Name as you want to see it in the exhibit
2 Image Title
3 If you are providing a Matted Print (16”x20”) or a Canvas, Metal, or Wired Hang Ready Framed Print (max horizontal width including frame 24”)
4 Dimensions if smaller than 16” x 20”
5 Price if you are offering your image for sale
6 Email Address
7 Phone Number (contact info to be included in the pricing sheet)
8 City of Residence
9 A 1or 2-paragraph story about the image and/or you the photographer (people appreciate the story behind the image and photographer)

Jan 15th Final Day for Image Delivery
Drop off at Ginny’s house 28 River St, Erving, MA 01344
Or contact Ginny by email, text, or phone to make arrangements (Mobile:[masked])

Jan 22nd Images will be hung on or Before

Images will hang for approximately 3 months

Pick Up arrangements for the “Fall-ing Into Winter” images will be figured out once the display has been changed

Please note these photos will be hung in an Oncology wing. Keywords to continue to keep in mind when choosing images are "Uplifting, Calming, Happy, Giggle Inducing, Awe Inspiring"

Remember we have plenty of 16’ x 20’ frames generously donated by Beth available for this use if you prefer to provide a matting print.

We have had a wonderful response from Oncology visitors and the hospital staff over our current show. It was a much bigger success than I’d ever anticipated and I can’t wait to see the turn out for this show!
results.name: Call for Photos - Baystate Franklin Oncology Wing -“Summertide Reverie”

results.description:
Learn how to get your computers ready for 2016 at the North Shore Business Forum’s Meeting on Friday, November 20, 2015.

Featured Speaker: Mark Beckley, Small Business Computing.

The featured speaker is Mark Beckley owner of Small Business Computing, who will give business owners tips on how to get their hardware and software ready for 2016. The presentation will go through the steps required to keep your machines tuned-up and running properly. He will explain what you need to know about Windows 8 and 10, and about viruses and futures.

About the Speaker: Mark has been working in the computer industry since 1978. After working for a number of local firms including Ask Jeeves, Polaroid and Avid, Mark started his own business in January 2004. Since then he has been building workstations and servers and servicing the computer needs of small businesses in the North Shore area. Mark’s IT business is the only one on the North Shore where most of the revenue comes from building custom machines for those folks who still need to use real computers. Mark is based in Reading, MA. For more information contact Mark at [masked] or visit www.smallbizcomputing.com .

The North Shore Business Forum, Inc. (NSBF) is a group of small business owners from Boston’s North Shore who meet on the first and third Friday of each month for informal lectures given by business owners on a wide variety of topics. Members give a 30-second introduction of their business at each meeting. All business owners are welcome: future, past, profitable, experienced or beginning. Meetings are from 7:30 to 8:30 a.m. (registration starts at 7:15) at Acapulcos, 900 Cummings Center, Beverly, MA. The $10.00 admission fee includes a breakfast buffet. No pre-registration necessary.

results.description:
DESCRIPTION
This ~ 6 mile walk will be on well marked trails running through Concord and Carlisle. The trails include some sections with very large old growth pines where the trail is carpeted with soft needles. However, other sections through deciduous growth stands are heavily covered with leaves. The thick leaf layers frequently cover exposed roots and small rocks…. so you must be prepared with good hiking boots.
The start of the walk will be at the (dead) end of Estabrook road where cars can be parked on the left side coming in between the designated parking signs. Although we plan to start the walk promptly at 9.00 am, I plan to stop at the Trails End Café around 8.30 am, and I recommend you may want to also, not the least to avoid waiting around at the start in temperatures that could be as low as in the twenties. Also, if you choose to drive directly to the start you may not easily find a spot to park.  I think it will be better to join us first at the cafe, to use facilities and stay out of the cold.  We will meet at the lower level, I can be (partly) recognized with my blue parka. If you stop by the café please park at the back of the café (Keyes Road entrance). The Trail End Café sign on Lowell Road (front of cafe) is large and very clear coming in on Lowell Road. It is only about ¼ mile away from Concord Center monument oval. We have the option for lunch (or a snack) at the café after the hike… the food selections are very good.
Link to the Café and trail Start & Finish locations: https://sites.google.com/site/estabrookwalk/
For those who sign up I will E mail you all the day before confirming the event... (or cancelling if the weather should turn out to be bad).  Please note that we will be leaving the café at  8.50 am and if you are not at the trailhead within a few mins after 9 am we will be gone. (I am sorry but I do not want to give out my cell to hear you are stuck in traffic).  If you think that you could be late please give ample time margin and meet us at the café.


DISCLAIMER
This event involves moderate physical activity, ie a fast pace of at least 2.5 mph. Therefore, as a condition of your voluntary participation you acknowledge that you have the necessary winter gear and fitness level to participate and you also assume all risks of injury associated with this activity
results.how_to_find_us: Recommend first Meeting at back of Trail's End Cafe, Lower Floor (ie off Keyes Road) before meeting at trailhead... read below
results.name: Fast Paced Hike thru Estabrook Woods

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball.

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

Just a friendly invitation to the 6th Annual Local Craft Brewfest.  This is by far one of my favorite beer fests of the season.  They've moved it this year to a BIGGER venue -- Cruiseport Boston.  I'm volunteering this year so I'm going to be busy and milling around. But I invite you to join the fun!  There is not only beer but spirits, mead, and cider. With the new venue, they'll also have more food options including FOOD TRUCKS! 

Tix and more info can be found here:  www.localcraftbrew.eventbrite.com.  Cost is $55/person, $75 VIP.  Tickets support the Sustainable Business Network with supports the local food economy and also organizes and hosts the Local Food Festival held every September on the Greenway.  

I hope to see some of you there!  Cheers! Isabel

Show Details
When: Friday, Nov 20,[masked]:00 PM (Doors open at 5:30 PM)
Ticket Price: $12.00
Door Time: 5:30 PM
Restrictions: 21+ General Admission
Ages of 10 years and older must purchase zone seating and be accompanied by an adult
Similar Jones:
Similar Jones has been wowing audiences for over a decade with a combined sound that’s bigger than their 7 voices. With a heavy focus on blues and rock, the high-energy vocal band uses a powerful rhythm section to get things pumping and tight, and bright background vocals to build the foundation for a wide variety of original songs and creative covers. Similar Jones performs frequently in the Boston area and has been honored locally and nationally for their innovative arrangements, recordings, and competitive performances.

Band Members: Eric Chung, Dave Cushing, Reena Freedman, Rob Opdycke, Nate Piper, Jeremy Sacco, Mike Stevens
Fermata Town:
Founded in 2009, Fermata Town is a Boston-based mixed vocal band and a proud member of CASA's Contemporary A Cappella League (CAL). The Townies have worked hard to make a name for themselves in the a cappella community, recording multiple award-winning albums while also competing and placing in several competitions including the National Harmony Sweepstakes, A Cappella Armageadon, Boston's Outside the Box festival and WGBH's Sing That Thing. The Townies pride themselves on their original arrangements, unique sound that melds pop and jazz, and the ability to maintain a healthy balance between their music and active lifestyles as full-time working professionals.

Band Members: Melissa Abreu, Dan Campagna, Mandy Cook, Johnny DelToro, Rusty Epstein, Sean Fortney, Chris Giordano, Alex Margarite, Taylor Meltzer, Anna Miller, Liz Mongrello, Tracy Robertson, Sarah Spinella, Becky Vinci, Philipp Walzer
