results.description:
The Paradox of Other Minds


We all believe that our friends have a conscious mind - just as we ourselves do. However, we also know there is no way to access the consciousness of other people. 

From a purely scientific point of view, there is no evidence for the existence of other minds. This can be illustrated by asking how we would determine if an individual is an automaton or a person. The primary way that scientist study conscious experience is by establishing correlations between physical measurements and what a person reports. However, when an individual reports experiencing pain, how do we know that they are in fact experiencing pain? All that we can really establish is a correlation between their verbal report and a physiological measurement. We do not and cannot establish a correlation between their conscious experience and a physiological measurement. 

The paradox of other minds is this: Despite the fact that there is no scientific evidence for the existence of other minds, we all believe that other people have a conscious mind like ourselves.

 ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~/~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

References for Other Minds (Nov 2015)

1. “Other Minds” PowerPoint presentation by Michael Johnson
There are two versions. The preferred version is in MeetUp files:  http://www.meetup.com/philosophy-185/files/

The other version is at this website:
http://michaeljohnsonphilosophy.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/Other-Minds.pptx

This PowerPoint presentation discusses three different ways to solve the problem of other minds.

The Argument from Analogy (Russell)
The Argument for Criteria – Behaviorism (Hume & Wittgenstein)
The Argument for the Best Explanation - Abduction

2. “Other Minds” in Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy
http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/other-minds/#7

“What is clear is that there does not seem to be what might be called a received solution to the problem.” Alec Hyslop

 ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~/~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
results.name: The Paradox of Other Minds

***This event requires a ticket or a commitment to volunteer at the event.  More details below.***

We'll attend CCI's Drylongso Awards event.  From their information:

Community Change Inc. works tirelessly to challenge structural racism. This year's Drylongso Awards provides a unique opportunity for our community to come together to celebrate the work we all do. 

The Drylongso Awards were established in 1989 to honor people doing significant anti-racism work within the local community. Inspired by the book Drylongso: A Self-Portrait of Black America, the Drylongso Awards reflect the message of the book and the struggles faced when challenging racism.

The doors will open at 6:30.  The program begins at 7 pm.  More information is in their announcement. 


Please join us to be part of a gathering of wonderful people, support CCI, honor the awardees, and learn more about what CCI is doing these days.


The cost to attend is $40 per person, and tickets are available here.  If you'd like to attend but cannot afford a ticket, there are volunteer opportunities and a limited number of scholarships available.  Please contact Nancy Griffin (event host for this meetup) for more information, or comment below.
results.name: Attend CCI's Drylongso Awards

results.description:
"Chakra Balancing and Aura Cleansing" Crystal Grid Workshop

This crystal grid workshop focuses on opening, clearing, balancing, and recharging your 7 major chakras of the body. When the chakras are balanced the positive flow of energy encourages spiritual opening, peace of mind, clear thinking, expression of the true self, open to receiving and giving love, confidence in self, joy, courage and over all vitality and physical wellness. The Crystal Grid will be enhanced with a guided meditation, Tibetan bowls  & journaling. (This class runs approximately 2hrs)

Friday,  November 20th  at 7:00 …$66 cash or check

($10 credit towards your purchase of the Complete Crystal Grid Set if you chose to buy them.) 

(Class size limited, Pre-registration with prepayment is required.)

Please arrive 15 min. early to check in & get settled into your grid.

Contact:  Trish Matthies  [masked]  [masked]

Special: Students may purchase the crystals from their grids at a discount.

What is a crystal grid?: A crystal grid is a specifically chosen set of crystals that are used together to create a desired energy shift or healing. The crystals do not work independently, but are charged to react and work together. Although the crystals in the grid are placed on the ground, the energy of the grids are 3- dimensional  to completely surround you. Attendees lay comfortably on mats with pillows and blankets with the crystals around them on the floor, as well as some placed on chosen chakras.

What to wear: While experiencing the energy shifting of the crystal grid, you may see images, or colors, feel emotional releasing, tingling, pulsing, or waves of heat or coldness. Therefore, please dress comfortably and in layers so you may make adjustments for your needs.

About the instructor: Trisha Matthies is a Reiki Master Teacher and Crystal Healer who has also trained in Shamanic Healing, Tibetan Bowls, Hypnotherapy, Aromatherapy, and Color Healing. She is also the owner of The Healing Moon Wellness Center located in Foxboro, Ma. Trisha has been working with the healing energies of crystals for over 15 years and enthusiastically shares her passion for these precious stones with her clients and students.

Buzz about my Crystal Grid Workshops: 

"The grid definitely brought down my stress level alot, so that by midway through the session, I was able to totally relax.  Felt more of that self acceptance. Such a nice way to end a very hectic week! Trish knows how to create the perfect atmosphere to help everyone relax."  I.F.

"The grids are always a magical, soul nourishing experience.  It was wonderful to be in such a beautiful and healing space with welcoming and warm wise women. I felt embraced in my own crystal cocoon of energy. Thanks Trish and Bobbie for offering and setting the place for such a gently transforming experience...It was a night well spent, and highly recommended."  E.L.

"The energy at the grids is always electric and all encompassing. Everyone has their own unique experience. No two people have the same encounter. Each person brings something special to the workshop. Love, love, love participating. Time went by in a flash, couldn't believe. A great experience, so healing. Well done Trish! "T.O.

"This was my first grid and it blew my mind! I'm still releasing today...4 days later!" A.B.

"The crystal workshop was intriguing and fun. We each received our own treasure bag of beautiful crystals, which Trish explained beautifully. We learned how to set up the crystals forming our own safe cocoon. Each crystal and stone made a pattern that showered us all with individual energies. And I believe the workshop helped me shift a direction of healing. One thing I know is 2 days later, I woke up singing! Thank you Trish for this great workshop. Sometimes we do things for fun and end up with an added bonus of learning and healing." B.L.

"This grid workshop was amazing. It's hard to describe what I felt, especially since everyone's experience was different. It was powerful and illuminating. I'm looking forward to taking another session!" L.B.

"The Heart Chakra Crystal Grid Workshop was wonderful! As always, Trish's attention to detail makes her workshops great experiences that are uniquely your own in a roomful of amazing people." P.
results.name: "Chakra Balancing and Aura Cleansing" Crystal Grid Workshop

results.description:
STEAK,CHOPS AND COMFORT FOOD IN NORTH ANDOVER @ 7:00pm 

Lets have some fantastic steak, Chops & Comfort Food in North Andover.

A Little History Lesson

The Loft is located in a beautiful 160-year-old post and beam structure, on Route 125 in North Andover. In the heart of the area's farm country, it served as a very successful working barn for many years. 

In the 1930s, the building stabled horses and was known as a popular riding location. Later it served as a small but productive woodworking shop which specialized in boat building. 

In 1978, this historic building was transformed into a rustic New England restaurant. Careful attention was paid to retaining as much of the building's original flavor and charm, while creating a warm, inviting atmosphere for enjoying food and spirits. 

As the newest owners of the Loft Steaks Chops & Comfort Foods, we take great pride in serving the finest USDA top choice steaks and the freshest seafood, poultry and produce in the Merrimack Valley. 

We invite you to join us 7 days a week for lunch, dinner and private functions.

http://www.loftsteakandchophouse.com/history.html

Be safe, yours truly Eirini Kay

results.description:
FABULOUS FRIDAYS AT CIMC!

Come for an evening of LGBTQ meditation practice, discussion, tea & cookies at Cambridge Insight Meditation Center. 

Taught by our fearlessly awesome teacher, Madeline Klyne, this program is suitable for all levels. If you have never tried meditation, are a beginner or have had a practice for years, this evening is for you. It includes meditation instruction, sitting meditation, walking meditation, an inspiring LGBTQ-focused Dharma Talk, discussion, tea, and cookies.

Come make new friends and help build the OutBreath community! This is CIMC's signature LGBTQ event.
results.name: Evening for LGBTQ Practitioners

venue.name: Wild Rover Bar Boston - 1 Block from Faneuil Hall

results.description:
Biagio puts on a great party and has graciously invited the members of the Boston Social and Cultural Club.  Biagio rented the whole 2nd floor of the Wild Rover to make this an awesome private party.

PLEASE DO NOT DOUBLE RSVP! ----PLEASE RSVP IN ONE GROUP ONLY!! 

Join the legendary crazy dancing at our Mix +Mingle Meetup Private Party for 120+ members with our own DJ, dance area, 2 bars +apps/food from 7-9PM.

7-9PM is the Social Mixer which the best because it allows you to get to know your fellow Meetup members. After 9PM the crazy dancing + loud music starts so please do not complain, since members come to dance to loud music after 9PM.

Bonus FREE KARAOKE on 1st  floor if you want to kick it KARAOKE style.

Its the party everyone loves since its the starting point for thousands of new friendships, real long term relationships and 57+ marriages. Remember this is not a Singles Party it's a Social party.

The BEST part!...Come between 7 and 8:20PM to get 1 included (FREE) drink ticket good for any beer, wine, or mixed drink! (Sorry no shots or top-shelf liquor). This 1 Drink ticket will expire at 8:20PM sharp!!.....Please don't forget to TIP your bartender for the included drink!

When you arrive please head upstairs, (please don't block the stairway). Meet/greet Biagio, say your first name, what group you're with, pay with a $10 bill in hand at the top of the stairs (no $1 or $5 bills, please). You'll get a wrist band to wear so you can go upstairs and downstairs.

1. Biagio collects $10 cash from everyone, but the invited Larger Meetup Group Head Organizers and some of the  Social Fun Organizers..

2. After 9 PM you'll have to pay the bar's cover charge, so stretch your dollar and come before 9PM. If you get in before 9PM you ONLY have to pay $10 to Biagio.

I hope you can all join us for this blast of a party. It should be fun so thanks and enjoy life!..........Ciao, Biagio (a new dad)

==========================================================

Parking for this event: Street parking can be tough so you can try it and of course it's hit or miss. Your best bet it take the T.

The closet T stop is the Aquarium stop on the Blue line, next would be State Street stop on the Orange line.

If you really must drive in and park then there is $10 Parking after 5PM and on weekends at International Place Garage . There is a coupon that lowers it to $7 but this  $7 coupon is accepted at Pay Station in building lobby ONLY.  http://bostonparking.spplus.com/Boston-1-International-Place-Parking.html
results.how_to_find_us: Look for Biagio at the top of the stairs.

2. After 9 PM you'll have to pay the bar's cover charge, so stretch your dollar and come before 9PM. If you get in before 9PM you ONLY have to pay $10 to Biagio.

I hope you can all join us for this blast of a party. It should be fun so thanks and enjoy life!..........Ciao, Biagio (a new dad)

==========================================================

Parking for this event: Street parking can be tough so you can try it and of course it's hit or miss. Your best bet it take the T.

The closet T stop is the Aquarium stop on the Blue line, next would be State Street stop on the Orange line.

If you really must drive in and park then there is $10 Parking after 5PM and on weekends at International Place Garage . There is a coupon that lowers it to $7 but this  $7 coupon is accepted at Pay Station in building lobby ONLY.  http://bostonparking.spplus.com/Boston-1-International-Place-Parking.html
results.how_to_find_us: We rented the whole 2nd floor of the Wild Rover to make this an awesome private party Look for Biagio at the top of the stairs.
results.name: Boston Mix n Mingle Fall Party for 120 Members from 9+ Meetup Groups

results.description: Each and every Friday, we're proud to open the doors of our music school in Central Square for a FREE seminar, demo or meet-up. Hell, we'll even throw a classical music concert or two. What's in store this week? Let's find out: Want to spice up your solo performance? Add an orchestra to your band's live set? Meddle in sublime sound chaos? This workshop will get you started. From cellist Zoe Keating to electronic artist Imogen Heap to beatboxer Reggie Watts, looping is widely used in today's music scene and provides something for everyone. With the help of instructor Jess Jacobs, learn how to use Ableton Live's looper, how to program an external midi controller for ease of use, and get a peek at cutting edge performance devices. Jess Jacobs is a Boston-based composer, producer, performer, and technologist. After spending time at Berklee, NYU, and Harvestworks in NYC studying music technology, she's played solo and with various acts all over the country, including her Boston band, Band Without Hands. An engineer and artist alike, she is always looking to push the envelope in creating musical interfaces that allow new yet intuitive methods of expression.
results.name: One Person Band: Looping with Ableton Live #FREE [11/20]

results.description:
AfterFab is America’s only tribute to the solo years of all four Beatles – and their unique concept has fans buzzing. The genius of The Beatles didn’t stop with “Abbey Road,” and AfterFab brings the brilliant solo careers of Lennon, McCartney, Harrison, and Starr to life with high energy and high fidelity to the original recordings. Over 70 hit singles and numerous iconic tracks compose one of the best-loved classic-rock canons ever, from “Band on the Run” and “It Don’t Come Easy” to “Imagine,” “What Is Life” and dozens more. 

I have seen them before, they are awesome!

Meetup at MetroRock Gym in Everett, offering both toprope and lead


Meet at the left-side hexagonal picnic table next to the bench and cubbies.

Please check  the whiteboard near the bathrooms for a description of what I'm wearing. If anyone else arrives early, please write "MEETUP" and your name & what you are wearing on the Whiteboard.

results.description:
STEAK,CHOPS AND COMFORT FOOD IN NORTH ANDOVER @ 7:00pm

Lets have some fantastic steak, Chops & Comfort Food in North Andover.

A Little History Lesson

The Loft is located in a beautiful 160-year-old post and beam structure, on Route 125 in North Andover. In the heart of the area's farm country, it served as a very successful working barn for many years. 

In the 1930s, the building stabled horses and was known as a popular riding location. Later it served as a small but productive woodworking shop which specialized in boat building. 

In 1978, this historic building was transformed into a rustic New England restaurant. Careful attention was paid to retaining as much of the building's original flavor and charm, while creating a warm, inviting atmosphere for enjoying food and spirits. 

As the newest owners of the Loft Steaks Chops & Comfort Foods, we take great pride in serving the finest USDA top choice steaks and the freshest seafood, poultry and produce in the Merrimack Valley. 

We invite you to join us 7 days a week for lunch, dinner and private functions.

http://www.loftsteakandchophouse.com/history.html

We'll have drums to share, and support for newcomers, and energy for everyone.

Recent accolades!

“Great fun! Good rhythms. Very accommodating leader and group for this beginner. Will be back!”

Adrienne S 10/14

It was an amazing experience .. It was nice to feel free from the world and it's problems .. It's was so relaxing, can't wait to drum again ..thanks!

Justin 6/14

Was an awesome experience, I love hand drumming but really the main reason I came was to relieve stress due to family health situations and the circle definitely met my needs. Alan did a great job leading the circle with the drumming and the short history lessons about drumming and Africa. I will be coming back.

Paul 10/13

This Drum Circle is a great stress reliever after a long week of work and I wish it were every Friday night!! Boston Drum Cirlce attracts a wonderful , eclectic group of people that share the common bond of hand drumming. It is always wonderful to have the multi talented Fanta leading the Circle. Her singing, dancing, and drumming are all 5 star. Thank you for a great night of Drumming!

Carla 8/13

We can't wait to meet you! See you soon....

Alan and Fanta

results.description:
Given all of the recent terrorist activity, I'm changing our theme this week to focus on peace and love, and creating world peace through our inner peace.  Experiments have proven the power of inner meditation and prayer to have an effect on the outer world.  So let's contribute to this ripple effect by gathering our energies in peace and love.  Please join me.  I've also reduced the normal fee for this class so it will be super easy to participate.

Here's the basic description for this bi-weekly meditation gathering, with a more specific focus/theme each time, as well. For now, we'll be meeting on the first and third Friday evening each month. Of course, you do not have to commit to attending every time, however, the more you attend, the more you will benefit; and the better we'll get to know each other!  See end of description below for payment options.


Take the time to slow down, tune in, and connect deeply with yourself and others.


Are you aware of the many benefits of meditating, but can’t get yourself to do it, or it’s too difficult to do on your own?

Do you enjoy the collective energy and ease of guided group meditations?

Meditation can be one of the easiest and most effective means to living with greater harmony, happiness and well-being. It’s also an opportunity to peacefully transform your problems, your fears, and any pain and stress in your life into something more positive.

I also consider meditating one of the most direct and easiest ways to connect to your greater Spirit-Self, and to access all that it has to offer you.


By participating in these group guided meditations, you’ll experience how simple,delightful and easy it can be. You’ll learn and practice:

• Simple yet profound techniques you can easily do for yourself for any length of time that is comfortable for you.

• How to easily get into a meditative state to deeply relax and to create positive, pleasurable feelings, including inner peace, love, ease and joy; and how to bring that into your daily living.

• Techniques to help you shift your perspective and experience of issues in your life causing you stress in some form, and to shift to a more positive perspective, instead.

• How to connect to your inner resources and your best self, to solution consciousness, and how to activate your body's natural healing response.

We have a different theme each time we meet to help build and reinforce positive thinking patterns, beliefs and inner narratives that will support you in living with greater inner peace, love, ease and joy.

We typically have 2-3 guided meditations, with discussion and instruction in between to help you carry the positive feelings and lessons experienced into your day and life.

This is a perfect time to let go of stress and "busy-ness", and to fully let go and relax into bliss. Come with whatever intentions suit you, and the evening is still sure to satisfy. It always works out magically that way.

You're encouraged to bring a journal or notebook and pen to class.

To encourage and support your practice, if you pay for 4 sessions, the fee will be only $60 (in-person, cash or check), to be used within 4 months of your payment.  Or, you can pay for one class at a time for $20.  Just RSVP each time you want to attend. RSVP is recommended and appreciated, as well as showing up or changing your RSVP in a timely manner.

“I'm leaving refreshed, optimistic, empowered, full of love, and excited about bringing more spirit into everything I do. I’m sure that practicing the techniques I learned tonight will help me very much. Thank you!!! "

"Great meditations! I had a marvelous experience with each of them and a lot to take with me: powerful imagery, good feelings, and new techniques for connecting myself with the Universe. Loved the “love ripple”!”

"I truly value our time together. I tried two other guided meditation classes with other instructors, and I enjoy your classes the most. Why? Because you give us time to reflect, journal and share. It really helps to deepen my experience and expand my perspective. And honestly, I relate more to your meditations and love the sound of your voice. Your guided meditations are like group therapy for the soul."


Class leader (and meetup organizer): Ann Ide, M.A., has been leading guided meditation classes for years, and is also a certified master practitioner in Neuro-linguistic Programming and Hypnotherapy, and certified NLP Life Coach. Ann coaches people to move beyond their personal struggles, to new levels of harmony, happiness and success. With her expert questioning, inner exploration processes and personal change interventions, clients become able to more easily create the happiness they desire.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be downstairs in the basement level Roots Studio, enter thru back parking lot, or if go in front door - walk down hallway and stairs will be on the left
results.name: Guided Meditations for Creating World Peace through Inner Peace

results.description:
[Esperanta versio sube] Another informal meeting to get to know each other and learn some basic Esperanto phrases. Everyone is always welcome, even if you don't speak any Esperanto yet. Hope to see you there!

Address:
Uno Due Go is located at 52 Summer St., Boston MA 02110 USA.

Date and time:
Friday, November 20th, 2015 from 7pm to 8:30pm (or later if we decide to go somewhere else after).


Public Transportation:
It is located in downtown Boston, on the corner of Summer Street and Arch Street, across from the Macy's and CVS at Downtown Crossing T [Boston subway] station (Red Line and Orange Line). It is a 5-minute walk from South Station (various T, bus, and train connections), a 5-minute walk from Park Street T Station (Green Line), and a 7-minute walk from State Street T Station (Blue Line).

Parking:
There are parking meters on the street, where you can park for up to 4 hours. Then, they are free after 8pm. After that, parking is free. There is also a paid parking lot a few blocks away at 100 Federal Street, across from the Bank of America building between Franklin Street and Matthew Street. After 5pm, the cost is $10 flat for the day.

Let me know if there are any other questions. See you then!

||

Alia neformala renkontiĝo por interkonatiĝi kaj lerni bazajn esprimojn en Esperanto. Ĉiuj ĉiam bonvenas, eĉ se vi ankoraŭ ne parolas Esperanton. Mi esperas vidi vin tie!


Adreso:
Uno Due Go troviĝas ĉe 52 Summer St., Boston MA 02110 USA.

Tago kaj loko:
Je vendredo, la 20-a de novembro 2015, ekde 19:00 ĝis 20:30 (aŭ ĝis pli poste, se ni decidos iri aliloken poste).


Publika Transporto:
Ĝi troviĝas en la urbocentro de Bostono, ĉe la stratangulo de Summer Street kaj Arch Street, trans Macy's kaj CVS ĉe la "T" [Bostona metroo] stacidomo Downtown Crossing (Ruĝa Vojo kaj Oranĝa Vojo). Ĝi troviĝas for je 5 minutoj piedire de South Station stacidomo (diverse atingebla per la T, aŭtobuso, kaj fervojo), for je 5 minutoj de Park Street stacidomo (Verda Vojo), kaj for je 7 minutoj de State Street stacidomo (Blua Vojo).


Parkumado:
Estas parkumaj pagmaŝinoj ĉe la stratoj, kie oni povas parkumi dum 4 horoj. Post la 8-a ptm, ĝi estas senpaga. Ankaŭ estas pagenda parkejo for je kelketaj stratoj ĉe 100 Federal Street, trans la konstruaĵo de Bank of America, inter Franklin Street kaj Matthew Street. Post la 17-a horo, la kotizo estas $10 po tago.

Sciigu min se estas aliaj demandoj. Ĝis tiam!
results.how_to_find_us: Look for the green Esperanto flag on the table. || Serĉu la verdan Esperanto-flagon sur la tablo.
results.name: Ninth Meeting || Naŭa Renkontiĝo

results.description:
We know we haven't had an event in Portland for a while. We've been super-busy setting up the new center in Boston! Until we have a new venue in Portland, we hope you will come and join us for the inaugural TurnON at our new Boston OM Center!* It's sure to be an evening of fun and shared energy.

How often do we get an opportunity to be real with each other in Boston? At TurnON, we play three communication games, and you can participate at whatever level feels good to you. Imagine meeting new people in an environment where they feel comfortable to be themselves; a refreshing change from the typical networking or bar conversation. That's what we have created.

TurnON events give you the opportunity to look deeper into yourself, through other people putting quality attention on you, asking questions with genuine curiosity, and then listening - really listening – to your responses. What comes up might surprise you!

It's amazing how connected we can end up feeling - even in a room full of strangers - when we are willing to be authentic. It's like a giant exhale when the rest of the world is asking you to hold it in. In just an hour, you may even forget that you are in Boston.

TurnON Boston is an organization that teaches Orgasmic Meditation, otherwise known as OM. At the end of the evening, we will give you a brief description of the practice of Orgasmic Meditation and information on where to learn more. The games we play at TurnON events are designed to create the visceral sensation of Orgasm/OM in your body, without actually doing the practice (or touching anyone, or removing any clothing!).

$10, payable at the door.

Limited non-resident parking is available alongside our building on Dudley Street, or plentiful metered spaces on Mass Ave are only one block away (and free after 6pm). We are a 10-minute walk from the Red Line at Davis Square. 

*Post in the comments to arrange carpooling!

http://tedxtalks.ted.com/video/TEDxSF-Nicole-Daedone-Orgasm--2
results.name: TurnON Boston (in our new center)

results.description:
Come and join us for the inaugural TurnON at our new Boston OM Center! It's sure to be an evening of fun and shared energy.

How often do we get an opportunity to be real with each other in Boston? At TurnON, we play three communication games, and you can participate at whatever level feels good to you. Imagine meeting new people in an environment where they feel comfortable to be themselves; a refreshing change from the typical networking or bar conversation. That's what we have created.

TurnON events give you the opportunity to look deeper into yourself, through other people putting quality attention on you, asking questions with genuine curiosity, and then listening - really listening – to your responses. What comes up might surprise you!

It's amazing how connected we can end up feeling - even in a room full of strangers - when we are willing to be authentic. It's like a giant exhale when the rest of the world is asking you to hold it in. In just an hour, you may even forget that you are in Boston.

TurnON Boston is an organization that teaches Orgasmic Meditation, otherwise known as OM. At the end of the evening, we will give you a brief description of the practice of Orgasmic Meditation and information on where to learn more. The games we play at TurnON events are designed to create the visceral sensation of Orgasm/OM in your body, without actually doing the practice (or touching anyone, or removing any clothing!).

$10, payable at the door.

When attending, please make a point to tell the facilitator or assistant that you heard about this event from the Pleasure Without Borders Meetup.


Limited non-resident parking is available alongside our building on Dudley Street, or plentiful metered spaces on Mass Ave are only one block away (and free after 6pm). We are a 10-minute walk from the Red Line at Davis Square.

results.description:
Friday nights are generally for more experienced students, as we work through some different parts of Fiore's works in a more open format.  New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (c[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.
results.how_to_find_us: Come around to the right side of the building.  The stairs will bring you to the door.
results.name: (Newton) Intermediate Longsword, Dagger and Grappling

results.description:
Dance with us from 7:45 pm - midnight at The First Parish Cambridge Unitarian Universalist Church at 3 Church St., Cambridge, MA.

7:45-9:15 Biodanza with Éva K 

9:20-10:30 Robert 10:30-11:30 DJ Lady Evans

BiodanzaLogoBiodanza, from the Greek word bios, life, and danza, dance, integrates music, movement and authentic interactions to provide intense experiences of being alive in the here and now.

Based on anthropological studies of dance and traditional rituals celebrating life, Biodanza stimulates community, awakens a consciousness for universal solidarity, enhances participants’ joy and vitality and celebrates the sacredness of life.

Biodanza allows participants to further their connection to themselves as well as others, and to develop their sense of identity through the uniqueness of their dances. It fosters spontaneous, playful and vital self-expression and moving, sincere encounters with other participants.

Biodanza was developed in the 60’s in Chile by anthropologist, psychologist, poet and painter Rolando Toro. It is practiced in over 60 countries, all around the globe.

Éva Kyzirides has been fueled by a long term passion for dance. She first studied contemporary dance and worked as a dancer / choreographer for 10 years. Further, interested in the cultural and social dimension of dance, she has traveled in Asia and Hawaii to study various dance forms. She then completed a Masters’ degree in Dance Ethnology at York University, in Toronto. In 2003, she discovered Biodanza, a therapeutic dance approach which was just starting to set roots in Montréal. Three years later, she received her certification as a Biodanza facilitator.

Éva completed the training to become a Biodanza didactic teacher in 2011 and has been coaching Biodanza facilitators ever since. She is part of the pedagogical committee of the Biodanza SRT School of Montréal – Sud-Ouest du Québec where she also teaches. She offers Biodanza classes and workshops for adults, as well as for children and families. A founding member of the Biodanza Canada Association, Éva was on the board of directors for 6 years. Biodanza combines her passion for movement with her interest in dance as a means of self-expression, growth and transformation within the human community.

After class enjoy dancing to music by Robert and then dj Lady Evans

DJ Lady Evans— ” I love to show the world what I have to give,” she says of creating her sets. “I strive to make people experience music on a higher level, with a very good, strong, and positive message. When I play, I want people to feel happy. I want to bring people together, to show them how we’re all the same and we need to help each other and share joy.

“I love creating really big and beautiful atmospheres for parties and clubs, to make each event something special, something memorable, that really touches people,” she says. “Eventually, I also want to produce. I don’t want to just take music and play it. I want to create it. I’m doing this because it’s what I love. I believe that’s what I have to give to the world. I want to reach a lot of hearts.”

Dancers of all ages and abilities are invited to dance barefoot, any way you like, with or without a partner, in a smoke and alcohol free environment. Children are welcome.

Dance Friday is an activity of the non-profit Movement Collective. Suggested Donation: $15 8pm-9:15, $10-15 after 9:30, $5-10 after 11,  under  23 years old $5-15, or donate 45 minutes of your time to help out.  We recommend casual, light-weight, comfortable clothing that you can  move in.

For more information, please call: 6I[masked], go to <a>www.dancefriday.org,</a> or visit us on Facebook at http://www.facebook.com/#/pages/Dance-Friday/[masked]?ref=ts

results.description:
Happy Diwali and Happy November! The temperature may be starting to drop, but Subdrift's celebratory star continues to rise. We're thrilled to return to Danger! Awesome in Central Square for our November open mic, and to mix things up with a Friday night extravaganza on 11/20! Even more exciting: our featured artist for this month, Word-Problems! Those of you who came out to Hindie Rock Fest in September already know this young brother is the real deal, and we can't wait to lift him up and celebrate the release of his new album "The Coming of Age"!

"Hailing from Northborough, MA, Ali Saeed aka Word-Problems may only be 15 but he's got the skills that's way ahead of any rapper out right now. Although he strives to become one of the illest emcees of all time his main goal is to create unity and help those in need through his music. To hear his music go on soundcloud.com and search Word-Problems with a hyphen in between word and problems then click the first result. EVERYONE GIVE IT UP FOR THE YOUNGEST BROTHA REPPIN.....WORD-PROBLEMS!"

Trust us, you don't want to miss this one. Doors at 8:00, show at 8:30, $5-10 sliding scale donation at the door (no one will be turned away for lack of funds). Open mic sign-up available in advance here; as always, we'll have some slots available at the door as well. See you there!

With fireworks a-blazing,

Subdrift Boston (Adi, Bunty, Sapan and Shilpa)


Subdrift Boston November Open Mic FEATURING Word-Problems

Friday, November 20, 2015 (***note shift from regular Third Thursday schedule***)

Doors at 8:00 pm, open mic performances at 8:30 pm
Danger! Awesome, 645 Massachusetts Ave, Cambridge

RSVP: https://www.facebook.com/events/1516512262005961/

results.description:
Here's the game plan:

8:00 - Toss the disc around, meet folks, be merry

8:10 - Overview of the rules, safety, etc - then divide into teams

8:20 - Play!!!!!!

10:00 - Conclude the meetup and begin socializing.

Here's what we humbly ask of you (works great as a checklist):

Dress for the weather

Bring a white and a dark-colored t-shirt. Grey is evil. If you wear grey you may be asked to wear a light or dark "pinnie of shame."

Arrive on time to be guaranteed a spot in a game

RSVP is recommended so you can be notified if the game is canceled

Bring WATER!

If you are a regular, please consider bringing a buck for the Frisbee Fund

As usual, we will supply the frisbees, cones, first aid supplies (hopefully will never be used) and our pretty smiles. As we periodically mention, all these supplies are paid out-of-pocket by your loving Frisbee organizers and everyone has been so generous with their donations to-date. Thank you and let's keep the dream alive!

results.description:
Welcome future dance-a-holics!! Come dance with us again THIS FRIDAY! If you want to learn to social dance and have a blast while doing it, please join me for a beginner west coast swing class from 8:30-9:15pm (Experienced with WCS? Join Marcus Schwarz for the Intermediate class at 8:30!). If you like it and feel like sticking around, there is a west coast social dance from 9:15-11pm.

You don't need a partner.

You don't need to have any previous dance experience.

You can have two left feet.

This is all about having a blast while learning something new that you can actually use in your real life!

WHAT IS WEST COAST SWING?

West Coast Swing (WCS) is a modern, partnered social dance done all over the world.

It is danced to a wide variety of music, including R&B, Rock, Blues, and Lyrical: exactly what’s on the radio today and at functions you attend!

It fits in small spaces like bars, crowded dance floors—even your living room.

You do not need a partner to get started.  Most people come by themselves or with friends.

Once you’re hooked, there are places to dance WCS every night of the week in the Boston area.

People of all ages dance WCS.
results.name: Beginner & Intermediate West Coast Swing Class & Social Dance!

venue.name: Gilliland Observatory of the Museum of Science Parking Garage

results.description:
Fridays, March – mid-November | 8:30 – 10:00 pm
Offering Format: Public Event
Recommended for grades Pre-K – 12 and adults
Museum of Science
Free

Did you know that the Museum offers our starry-eyed public a free evening full of astronomy-themed fun on weather-cooperative Fridays?

Between 8:30pm and 10pm each Friday, weather-permitting, visit the Gilliland Observatory on the roof of the Museum’s parking garage. On clear nights, you can view stars, planets, the Moon, and other astronomical phenomena. On cloudy nights, tour the inside of our Observatory, and participate in astronomy-related activities run by our knowledgeable staff.

This program does not run on nights when the weather is inclement. For more details, and to find out if Astronomy After Hours is running on a given Friday, call our hotline,[masked]-0267. We update each Friday by 5:30pm with the evening’s plans.

Astronomy After Hours runs seasonally, from the first Friday in March to the last Friday before Thanksgiving. Admission is free thanks to the generosity of the Lowell Institute (parking charges still apply).

Thanks to Don Doughty for letting us know about the museum.

Source: http://www.mos.org/public-events/astronomy-after-hours
results.how_to_find_us: Please meet 15 minutes before the scheduled time and to the right of the line in front of the Astronomy building on the roof of the Museum of Science to be with the group. The Meetup group will wait for 10 minutes and then get in line.
results.name: Astronomy After Hours - Museum of Science

results.description:
Event Organizer: Michael Blair @ (978)[masked]

=====

Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the process. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event.

Answers DO NOT carry over from one event to another so you must answer them for EACH EVENT. Also, questions might not show up if you RSVP from a phone or tablet so if you don't see them you will need to use a computer.

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself and others at risk. Consider this before you RSVP.

=== What We're Doing ===

The plan is to hike to three of the 4,000 footers in New Hampshire - Jefferson, Adams, and Madison. We will use Caps Ridge Trail to reach Jefferson and then we will follow Gulfside Trail and some other trails to reach Adams and then Madison. From there we will use Valley Way to get to the trailhead. There will be a few steep sections on the way up to Jefferson and then we will be above treeline for most of the day. The Madison Spring Hut is closed for the season.

If the road to Caps Ridge Trail is closed we will use Lowes Path to Jefferson and then follow the same route from there. This will make the overall trip about 14 miles and about 6,400 feet. We will know a week or so before the trip and will make the necessary adjustments to the itinerary.

If you are interested in participating in this event sign up for the waiting list. I will add people that (1) answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process and (2) have done similar hikes within the past three months.

The maximum group size for this trip will be 12 people. 

Guests aren't permitted.

Dogs are only permitted with prior approval of the event organizer.

=== Trip Summary ===

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you.

On this moderate pace (~2.0 MPH) trip we will hike about 10.4 miles and climb about 4,400 feet. It should take an average hiker about 7 hours 30 minutes to complete. This event is considered ADVANCED because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain.

Use this link for more information about where we are going and how we will get there:

http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/2-Mt-Adams-5774--5-Mt-Madison-5367


http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/3-Mt-Jefferson-5712


Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this event - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants. Use this link for the current weather forecast:

http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lon=-71.29269327215584&lat=44.32131078136757#.ViWJZrTO5_Y


=== What to Bring ===


IT'S WINTER IN THE MOUNTAINS - WINTER CLOTHING AND GEAR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS HIKE. DON'T THINK WE WILL NEED SNOWSHOES BUT WINTER BOOTS, TRACTION (KAHTOOLA MICROSPIKES OR HILLSOUND TRAIL CRAMPONS), AND WEATHER APPROPRIATE CLOTHING IS REQUIRED. EXPERIENCE IN WINTER IS ALSO REQUIRED.

Use this link for a list of items needed for a winter day hike:


</a><a href="http://files.meetup.com/492954/Winter_Day_Hike_List_ADK.pdf">http://files.meetup.com/492954/Winter_Day_Hike_List_ADK.pdf

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

=== Directions ===

We will meet at the AppalachiaTrailhead which is located on the south side of Route 2 near Gorham, NH. According to Google Maps this spot is about 170 miles from Boston and it will take about 2 hours 45 minutes to drive there. Since that is where we will end our trip we will leave a few cars there and drive to the start.

Use this link to customize the driving directions:

https://goo.gl/maps/TTBfdekWgMq


While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride.

=== Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer ===

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.

Join us for our first weekly weekend run! We'll be meeting in Back Bay and logging some miles before grabbing some post-run coffee and treats. All paces and runner levels are welcome! We'll meet inside the entrance to Copley Place at Dartmouth and Stuart right by Au Bon Pain. There are bathrooms but no place to store a bag.

Route: There are two main route options for this week, a 5 mile route and an 8 mile route. Both routes start by heading north on Dartmouth St. to the Charles River Esplanade and then head west to the Mass. Ave Bridge. The routes continue east along the Cambridge side of the river before heading back into Boston past the Museum of Science. There will be run leaders for each route so no one will get lost or left behind.  

After the run, join us back at Au Bon Pain for some coffee or other warm beverage on the team. 

Note: Please post your pace and desired distance when RSVP'ing. The route (or routes) will be posted one to two days in advance.

results.description:
• [Don't be concerned if you don't see many RSVPs here... our members tend to RSVP via our members site at WatertownSaturdayToastmasters.org.]

Please arrive at 9:00 am. From 9 to 9:15 am, we set up the meeting and network. We start the meeting at 9:15 am, and continue until 10:45 am. When you enter Church of the Good Shepherd, walk downstairs and take a left. If you arrive late, just walk in and have a seat at any open spot.

Please visit "Meeting Roles & Responsibilities" for more information about what to expect from a club meeting.

Here's a sample agenda for our meeting:

9:00 AM Setting up/Networking

9:15 AM President's Greeting and Club announcements

President opens meeting and welcomes guests

Toastmaster's Welcome

Introduces each role, its purpose, and the person who will perform the role.

Humorist/Invocation

Starts the meeting on a light-hearted note.

Grammarian's Word of the Day

Encourages each of us to add a new word to our vocabularies. Challenge us to use the new word spontaneously.

Scheduled Speeches

Club members give the speeches that they've scheduled and prepared in advance using the guidelines from one of the Toastmasters International communication manuals.

Table Topics

Our meeting's Topicsmaster provides our members and guests with an opportunity for demonstrating and honing their skills for impromptu speaking.

General Evaluator's Introduction

Introduces evaluation team members and evaluate the evaluators and the meeting in general.

Speech Evaluations

Club members provide helpful, supportive feedback to each of the scheduled speaker in a positive and friendly manner.

Grammarian's Report

Grammarian reports on how many times speakers used the Word of the Day and how we used the English language.

Ah-Counter's Report

Ah-counter reports how many filler-words and false starts were used by each participant, to raise speakers' awareness of these instances and to encourage improvement.

Timer's Report

Timer reports speaking times of all major speaking roles to encourage members learn to accomplish tasks within set time limits.

General Evaluator's Report

General evaluator provides a review of the meeting, what went well, and areas for improvement to encourage continual growth and an optimal quality of our meetings.

Toastmaster's Closing Remarks

10:45 AM President Adjourns Meeting

We usually have a convivial lunch at The Red Lentil. Hang around after the meeting for details.

WatertownSaturdayToastmasters.org

<a href="http://watertownsaturdaytoastmasters.org/"></a>

results.description:
Enfield Tower parking lot;  accessed through Middle Gate of South Quabbin Park 


Belchertown Road  (Rte. 9)

Ware, MA 01007

Quabbin Reservoir is one of the largest man-made public water supplies in the United States. Created in the 1930s by the construction of two huge earthen dams, the Quabbin Reservoir covers 39 square miles, is 18 miles long and has 181 miles of shoreline. It holds 412 billion gallons of water when full.

In order to flood the vast area of the Swift River Valley in the 1930s, the entire population of four towns had to be relocated. Hundreds of homes, businesses, a state highway, a railroad line, and 34 cemeteries were also moved or dismantled. Over 6,000 graves were relocated from the Valley to Quabbin Park Cemetery .


A protected wilderness of 56,000 acres provides habitat for black  bears, moose, bobcats, eastern coyotes, fisher cats,, rattlesnakes, loons, turkey vultures and hawks. It is also regarded as the prime nesting place for bald eagles in Massachusetts and in November when the trees are bare is a prime opportunity to see them soaring over the reservoir and resting.in the trees. The MA Division of Fisheries and Wildlife reports there are 10 breeding pairs of bald eagles nesting @ the Quabbin.


What you need to know:

Estimated Distance: Approx. 8 miles (subject to change)

Anticipate Pace: 2-2.5 mph or the pace of the slowest hiker

Duration: Depends on trail conditions, temperature and the group itself Don’t sign up if you’ve made plans for later in the day. The Event Host(s) is/are not responsible for getting you back on time.

Terrain Difficulty Rating:  Easy/Moderate:  The hike is mostly level with easy hills mixed in and the walking is relatively smooth. You can certainly expect tree roots, small rocks, and things of that sort on any trail walk but for hikes rated as "easy" there won't be any big-step-up boulders to get past and no rock scrambling.

Remember that the Difficulty Rating is for the terrain; not the hike itself. When determining if a hike is right for you, remember to factor in: terrain, distance, estimated pace, duration, weather prediction, driving time and your fitness level as well as your mood and frustration threshold..

This is a group event. We start together, stay together and finish together. We follow the leader’s instructions. We support each other should circumstances require teamwork. If you decide to leave the group at any time, you are on your own.

Please remember that your Event Organizers are volunteers, the event is free and we are all adults. The people who have the best times on these hikes are those who stay loose and roll with things as they happen. If you need everything to run perfectly, this hike is not for you.

Short Version: This not an event for high-maintenance individuals.

By clicking the "Yes" option on the RSVP link you are agreeing to the Liability Waiver as stated @ http://www.meetup.com/Bay-State-Hiking-Meetup/pages/The_Fine_Print/

We hike in light rain or showers, but heavy rain or extreme heat cancels.

Bring water, and lunch/snacks. Wear hiking boots (not sneakers). Protect yourself against deer ticks and dress in layers.

You need a recognizable facial photo as your profile picture in order to participate in this and all Trekkers events. 

No dogs and no guests are allowed on hikes. Have your guest join the group so they can agree to the liability waiver and attend an event. There are no exceptions, regardless of the size of the group or how awesome your dog is.

Trekker membership is open to adults only and our events are designed for adults. We do not allow children @ our events.  AMC-Boston has a Family Outings committee and other Meetup groups offer options for hikes with kids and dogs.

Before you ask if you can bring a guest, dog or child, please re-read the above two paragraphs.

If you want to carpool, put a message in the comment section. To respond, please send that person a direct message by clicking on their profile picture on the right.

For more information and a trail map go to:

http://www.mass.gov/eea/agencies/dcr/massparks/region-central/quabbin-reservoir.htm

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quabbin_Reservoir

http://www.foquabbin.org/

For photos go to:

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/quabbin-reservoir-belchertown

https://www.facebook.com/DCRQuabbinReservoir

htt://www.pbase.com/thewoodsman/quabbin

Directions From Boston:

VIA MASS PIKE: Take the Mass. Turnpike to Exit 8 (Palmer). At the end of the Exit Ramp turn left onto Route 32 North and proceed for 8 miles. In Ware turn left at the green sign "Route 9 West" (just past McDonalds). Go 2/10ths of a mile to a stop sign. Turn left onto Route 9 and proceed west for 7 miles. Turn right at the second green sign on your right. marked "Quabbin Reservoir." The first sign, located at the 5.3 mile mark, is directly across from the Quabbin Cemetery.  Follow the directions in the last paragraph.

VIA ROuTE 2: Take Route 2 W to Route 202 (Shay’s Highway) South. Turn left onto Route 9 East in Belchertown.

Turn left at the second green sign. Follow directions below.

Middle Gate is accessed through a driveway from Route 9 in Ware. When you get toward the end of this driveway, there will be a pullover parking lot on the right. Bear right at the fork here  to continue along the road. You should see a small waterway on your left as you make that right turn. Follow the winding road upward (drive slow because deer often pop out of the woods in front of cars). When you come to the rotary at the top of the hill take the first right in order reach the parking lot beneath Enfield Tower (see above photo).
results.name: Late Fall Trek @ South Quabbin Park

results.description:
MOUNT MORGAN AND MOUNT PERCIVAL
Intermediate 5.3 total mileage 1575' total gain /4 hours


TRAILHEAD 10 AM DIRECTIONS: From the North I-93 Exit 24 onto US Rte 3 S about 4.6 miles to Holderness. Turn left on NH Route 113 and continue 5.6 miles to Morgan trailhead on left. If you miss the Morgan Trailhead parking lot, you will end up at the Percival trailhead on the left 1/8 mile down the road.

DESCRIPTION:
Mt Morgan Trail to the summit of Mt Morgan (2220' - 1500' gain) - an intermediate hike with views. We will do a loop over to Mt. Percival (2212') and descend along Mt. Percival Trail to connector trail back to the parking lot where we began. This will take around 4-5 hours to complete. GEAR: Dress in layered/wickable clothing (no cotton) and expect cool temps and some wind up top.

WEATHER: If there are weather concerns, stay tuned to the meet-up event for updates
and watch for e-mail notification for those RVSP'D. Rain will cancel.


MORE DETAILS ABOUT THE TRAILS:
The Mt Morgan Trail starts at its parking lot and at .1 miles, a .4-mile connector leaves right to circle around to Mt. Percival Trail but for the ascent we will continue along the Morgan Trail. This becomes a trail ascending to an intersection with Crawford-Ridgepole Trail at 1.7 miles. To the left, the Crawford-Ridgepole heads toward Mount Webster but we veer right toward Mount Morgan. Below the summit is a path left for the adventurous who care to scramble up a set of three ladders. From the ladders you must pass through a cave and climb up and around another cliff until you are on the summit. Others can steer right and follow the main trail to the summit of Morgan. After that summit we retrace our steps a bit until Crawford-Ridgepole Trail directs us .8 miles to Mt Percival Trail. We will descend Mt. Percival via the Mt. Percival Trail until we meet the connector tail back to Mt. Morgan Trail where we started.
This is a group event. We start together, stay together and finish together. We follow the leader’s instructions. We support each other should circumstances require teamwork. If you decide to leave the group at any time, you are on your own.

Please remember that your Event Organizers are volunteers, the event is free and we are all adults. The people who have the best times on these hikes are those who stay loose and roll with things as they happen. If you need everything to run perfectly, this hike is not for you.

Short Version: This not an event for high-maintenance individuals.

By clicking the "Yes" option on the RSVP link you are agreeing to the Liability Waiver as stated @ http://www.meetup.com/Bay-State-Hiking-Meetup/pages/The_Fine_Print/

We hike in light rain or showers, but heavy rain or extreme heat cancels.

Bring water, and lunch/snacks. Wear hiking boots (not sneakers). Protect yourself against deer ticks and dress in layers.

You need a recognizable facial photo as your profile picture in order to participate in this and all Trekkers events. No dogs and no guests are allowed on hikes. Have your guest join the group so they can agree to the liability waiver and attend an event. There are no exceptions, regardless of the size of the group or how awesome your dog is.

Trekker membership is open to adults only and our events are designed for adults. We do not allow children @ our events. AMC-Boston has a Family Outings committee and other Meetup groups offer options for hikes with kids and dogs.

Before you ask if you can bring a guest, dog or child, please re-read the above two paragraphs.

If you want to carpool, put a message in the comment section. To respond, please send that person a direct message by clicking on their profile picture on the right.

results.description:
We'll run from the cafe to the river path, go west to Prospect Street, and double back along the river. Finishing up with one loop around the common to make it an even 2 miles. Since it's an out and back we can spread out at different paces to accommodate beginner to advanced runners, but still start and finish together.  Coffee/goodies at the cafe afterwards is also optional but highly recommended :-).

This is a great way to get into running, introduce your friends to the group, or just start your Saturday on a high note.  All ages and levels welcome.

If you are hesitating to come, keep in mind that nearly every week we have beginning runners who use a run/walk/run technique.  If you take walk breaks you will probably not be alone, and it's the best way to get into running, so come on out!
results.name: Beginner run from Cafe on the Common 2 miler-all levels

results.description:
We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (circa[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

See you there!

If there's no parking in Thorndike lot, look for parking on the side streets.
results.how_to_find_us: Come around to the right side of the school (left side of the church), enter under the green awning, then up two flights to the gym!

results.description:
Register to attend the kick-off at Eventbrite: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/hackwinter-2015-kickoff-tickets-19434943439.

Do not register here on Meetup! It's just a pointer to Eventbrite.


Remember last winter in Boston? Of course you do; how could you forget? The historic snow lead to problems with public works, infrastructure, and community access to services. Plus, remember the nightmare that was the MBTA? Out of the mess, a Code for Boston team created the award winning MBTA.ninja, a crowd-sourcing method for reporting transit delays. And it's awesome.

But this year, we decided to try to get ahead of things. So #HackWinter 2015 is here!

#HackWinter 2015 is a three-and-a-half week app challenge focusing on winter-specific apps that can help our community in the focus areas of Transit, Infrastructure, and Community. Over the next few weeks, we'll be reaching out to Public Works Departments in the Greater Boston Area as well as community groups, public health agencies, and more to serve as problem owners for the challenge.

Now the important details: Register for the #HackWinter 2015 app challenge kick-off on Eventbrite.

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/hackwinter-2015-kickoff-tickets-19434943439

The kick-off is at 10am on November 21st at the Microsoft Building on 255 Main Street in Kendall Square in Cambridge. Teams will spend the day forming and collaborating with partner organizations to brainstorm ideas for their projects. Official working time ends at 5pm on the 21st but teams have the next three and a half weeks to work on their project on their own time and at Code for Boston Hack Nights.

Final projects will be presented at #HackWinter Demo Night on December 15th at the Venture Cafe at CIC in Kendall Square. Registration information for Demo Night will be publicized later.
results.name: #HackWinter 2015

results.description:
BOOK:

The Lives of Others by Neel Mukherjee

28 copies in the Minuteman Library System.

DESCRIPTION:

The aging patriarch and matriarch of the Ghosh family preside over their large household, made up of their five adult children and their respective children, unaware that beneath the barely ruffled surface of their lives the sands are shifting. Each set of family members occupies a floor of the home, in accordance to their standing within the family. Poisonous rivalries between sisters-in-law, destructive secrets, and the implosion of the family business threaten to unravel bonds of kinship as social unrest brews in greater Indian society. This is a moment of turbulence, of inevitable and unstoppable change: the chasm between the generations, and between those who have and those who have not, has never been wider. The eldest grandchild, Supratik, compelled by his idealism, becomes dangerously involved in extremist political activism―an action that further catalyzes the decay of the Ghosh home.
Ambitious, rich, and compassionate, The Lives of Others anatomizes the soul of a nation as it unfolds a family history, at the same time as it questions the nature of political action and the limits of empathy. It is a novel of unflinching power and emotional force.

results.name: The Lives of Others by Neel Mukherjee at Ritu Ki Rasoi, Burlington

Join us for the November 2015 Meetup!

ATC THEMES:


1. Let go


2. Hands and Feet (extra swap, postponed from October)


3. Artist's Choice


DEMO/ACTIVITY:  We'll have two activities and people are welcome to bring gelli plates--and anything else they want to work on.    


BOOK CLUB: Discuss "The Silent Land" (optional). 


WHAT OTHER SUPPLIES SHOULD I BRING? There's a suggested list in "All About the NE ATC+ Meetup" (also at the top of the Message Board). But even if you show up empty-handed, that's fine--we have loaner tools.

POTLUCK LUNCH: You're invited, but certainly not required, to bring food or drink for our potluck lunch, or to just bring your own lunch. No need to sign up; bring whatever you like. We can order pizza or other items if people will volunteer to take orders, collect $, and pick up the food. 

FREE STUFF/SALE ITEMS: You're welcome to bring items to give away or sell to other Meetup members onsite. Just remember to remove anything that doesn't get picked up or sold--we can't leave anything behind.

COST: $10, regardless of when you arrive or depart; it covers our costs for the day. Sorry, no partial payments or IOUs. Cash is preferred; small bills are greatly appreciated. If payment is a hardship, please let the organizer know--we can work it out.

RSVPs: Please RSVP "yes" to attend; that way, we'll have an approximate headcount, and you'll receive all notifications about the Meetup! If your plans change, and you will be unable to attend, please change your RSVP to "no" no later than 24 hours before the start of the Meetup, so we'll know not to expect you. Anyone who cancels within 24 hours, regardless of the reason, will need to pay the fee anyway to help cover our costs for the day. 

LAST-MINUTE UPDATES: Please check your email in box and the website before leaving for the Meetup. That way, in the unlikely event that we need to cancel due to bad weather or any other reason, you'll be sure to get the news.

Hope to see you there!

results.description:
Queridos amigos,

Muchas gracias por vuestra participación en la charla sobre “El libro de arena” y una cordial bienvenida a nuevas integrantes Elena, Katie y Laura.  ¡Y muchísimas gracias por la fiesta sorpresa de cumpleaños!  ¡Me encantó y me quedé muy sorprendido de veras!  De verdad me siento muy afortunado de formar parte de un grupo con gente tan especial. Y muchísimas gracias a Gaby por haberlo organizado todo…. 

En nuestra próxima reunión, el sábado 21 de noviembre, vamos a comentar la "Antología poética de la generación del 27".  Además de comentar en términos generales la obra poética ese grupo literario tan importante, la idea de la charla es que cada uno de nosotros escoja entre dos y cuatro poemas para recitar al grupo.  Empezaremos con una ronda con un poema cada uno y si nos da tiempo, haremos otra ronda.  Propongo que preparemos entre dos y cuatro poemas cada uno para que no haya repeticiones.  En unos días, a Schoenhof's le van a llegar cinco ejemplares de “La antología de la generación del 27” de Arturo Ramoneda de Castalia Didáctica que cuesta $26.95.  Como no van a dar abasto en Schoenhof´s, yo recomendaría que la comprásemos en otras librerías o sitios web.  Por ejemplo, la edición de Punto de Lectura de
esta antología está disponible en Barnes & Noble a un precio de $11.99 o en EBay, Amazon o Abebooks.com.  Hay disponible también diversas poesías de la generación del 27 en Internet gratis.  No es importante que leamos todos la misma edición siempre que se trate de una antología de la generación del 27. 

Para la reunión del 12 de diciembre, nuestra lectura será "El amante japonés" de Isabel Allende.  La sinopsis de este libro, que está gozando de buenas críticas, es la siguiente: www.casadellibro.com/libro-el-amante-japones/[masked]/[masked] Isabel Allende va a hacer una comparecencia en Harvard Bookstore promocionando su libro el 11 de noviembre.  Las entradas cuestan $31.32 e incluyen un ejemplar firmado por la autora de antemano.  Algunos del grupo van a asistir al evento.  Aquellos que queráis asistir, a continuación está el enlace donde cada uno habría de sacar la entrada por su cuenta: www.harvard.com/event/isabel_allende1/
 Yo no voy a estar en Boston el día 11 de noviembre pero algunos van a organizar una quedada después del evento para tomar un café (os avisaremos).  Para los que no nos apuntemos a la comparecencia de Allende pero sí a la charla del 12 de diciembre, conseguiremos el libro por otra parte pues no va a estar disponible en Schoenhof´s.  Ya está disponible en otras librerías como Barnes & Noble a un precio de $21.36. 

Por último, como comentamos el sábado voy a indagar sobre la posibilidad dehacer una recaudación en el grupo para conseguir libros en español y regalarles a niños con pocos recursos económicos en Massachusetts.  Mary Liz ya mencionó unas ideas muy concretas sobre cómo podríamos hacerlo en Chelsea y voy a hablar con ella al respecto (¡muchas gracias Mary Liz!).  Si tenéis ideas al respecto o simplemente queréis participar, no dudéis en avisarme.

¡Muchas gracias de nuevo y hasta noviembre!

Un fuerte abrazo,  

Mark
results.how_to_find_us: La reunión se celebrará en la sala al fondo de la librería.
results.name: En noviembre: "Antología poética de la generación del 27"

results.description:
NOTE: this is meetup is on a Saturday rather than the usual Sunday. 


We have rented 3 badminton courts at the BU Fitness & Recreation Center (regulation full sized courts).  The BU facility is immaculate and a fantastic place to play.


The fee (payable online when you RSVP) gets you into the BU Fitness & Recreation Center to play badminton for an hour and a half.  Part of the fee is for the court time and the rest is for your meetup group to cover other expenses, i.e. rackets, shuttlecocks/birdies, meetup.com fees. All fees collected go to pay the Group's expenses.

We have rackets and shuttles for everyone!

Expect to play doubles. The host can help to match up pairs but members are free to join in any game they want.  The courts are reserved only for Boston Badminton members.

Before asking a question, please read through the following FAQs:

Q: The meetup is full, can I come regardless and pay at the event?
A: No, there is limited space to make sure everyone gets to play. A few spots typically open up before the event.

Q: It's my first time, how do I find you?
A: Go to the BU Fitness & Recreation Center reception (see directions below), and tell them you're here with Boston Badminton. They'll tell you where the courts are, check you're on the list, and make you sign a waiver. The meeting point is on the courts.

Q: I am a BU student, do I get a discount?
A: No, BU charges us the same regardless of whether participants are at BU or not.


Directions:
Please click here for a google map to The BU Fitness & Recreation Center.  The easiest way to get to the FitRec center from within Boston is to take the Green Line (B)-Boston College to Saint Paul St.  Parking is limited but available.  Please click here for parking information.

Plan to grab a drink locally after if we have interest.

The club has full locker room and shower facilities.

Note: In addition to agreeing to the Meetup's Liability Waiver, all members must sign a Waiver of Liability Form in order to use BU's courts. This form is available at the front desk at the FitRec center.  We may ask you for your full name in order to help BU and the meetup comply with the liability procedures.

Let me know if you have any questions and I hope to see you there!

Liability Waiver

By attending a Boston Badminton meetup, you hereby agree to the terms of the following Liability Waiver:

The purpose of the following Liability Waiver is to protect Boston Badminton meetup members and group leaders from liability in case of accident or injury. All members must agree to the Liability Waiver in order to participate in the group and its activities.

As part of my membership to Boston Badminton on Meetup.com (hereinafter “Boston Badminton”), I hereby freely and voluntarily agree to the following Release, Acknowledgment of Risk, and Waiver of Liability:

In consideration of the opportunity to participate in events, activities, classes, and programs conducted by Boston Badminton and its affiliates in any venue, and to use equipment located therein, I, on behalf of myself and my minor children, do hereby release, hold harmless and forever discharge and agree not to sue Boston Badminton and its trustees, officers, agents, founders, members, volunteers and employees (together, "Meetup.com Group") from any and all claims, responsibilities or liabilities for injury or damages resulting from or arising out of my or my family’s use of, presence in, or participation in activities conducted at any venue rented or owned by Boston Badminton, whether or not caused by the ordinary negligence of Boston Badminton. I understand, recognize and acknowledge that certain activities conducted by Boston Badminton or taking place in venues rented or owned by Boston Badminton are potentially hazardous. I also acknowledge that it is my responsibility to follow instructions for any activity or use of equipment, and to seek help from the volunteers if I have any questions. I further understand that, notwithstanding precautions taken by Boston Badminton, sports and fitness activities involve a risk of injury and/or death. I/we are voluntarily participating in these activities and using equipment and machinery with knowledge of the dangers involved. I hereby agree to expressly assume and accept any and all risks associated with my participation in activities conducted by Boston Badminton and its affiliates. I have read the foregoing and hereby agree to be bound by same.

This session is designed for students who have already taken an intro to Python, Java, C/C++, or Javascript course (programming beyond HTML/CSS or Scratch). Exceptions may be granted with instructor permission. Students should be familiar with variables, if statements, and loops.

Please arrive prepared with a laptop that already has Python installed and running: https://www.python.org/downloads/. Please also install the IPython (http://ipython.org/install.html), Natural Language Processing Toolkit (http://www.nltk.org/install.html), the full SciPy stack (http://scipy.org/install.html), and SciKit Learn (http://scikit-learn.org/stable/install.html). If you have trouble with this, please still come to the session, but we have a STRONG preference for having this taken care of at home so that we can focus on learning new things.

Depending on student interest and ability, we may cover Cryptography and Computer Security, Spam (Junk Email) Detection, Data Visualization, and an introduction to Machine Learning. If possible, please email [masked] a brief summary of your student's programming experience and interests. Feel free to also email any questions or concerns. Accommodations and modifications will be made to fit student interest and ability.

Students are encouraged to explore the online documentation themselves and experiment with running their own code before class.

results.description:
November 21, 2015


The 4th Annual Piggy's 5K is in loving memory of Paul "Piggy" Logue, a lifelong Waltham resident and humanitarian, and proceeds benefit the Paul Logue Charitable trust which funds services and support to Waltham families in need.   The race starts and finishes at The Fernald School Grounds in Waltham. After party at 

City Streets Restaurant

, 411 Waverley Oaks Rd. (new location). Registration is now open.

About This Event 
4th Annual Piggy's 5K Run/Walk will be held Saturday November 21, 2015 starting at 1:00p.m. in Waltham at City Streets, at their NEW LOCATION, 411 Waverley Rd.,. This race is in loving memory of a wonderful man that we suddenly lost 4 years ago. Paul (Piggy) Logue was born, raised and a lifelong resident of Waltham. Paul loved the Waltham community and therefore we thought this was fitting to raise money and give back to the community through the Paul Logue Charitable Fund. This course is a fairly flat 3.1 miles (5K). The course is paved, therefore strollers or baby joggers are allowed on the course. This year the race is proud to be part of the Race Around Waltham Series (RAW) which encourages support of all Waltham races and promotes friendly competition by tracking runners, walkers and volunteers who participate in 13 Waltham races for additional prizes. Runners and walkers welcome -- tell your friends and bring the kids! Post-race party will be held at City Streets, 411 Waverley Oaks Rd., in Waltham immediately following the award ceremony. Please come and help us celebrate our forth annual run in Paul (Piggy) Logue's memory! Food, raffles and fun!!Course Description 
The event will begin at 1:00pm sharp! Race will be starting and finishing at The Fernald School Grounds on Waverley Oaks Rd.,. The course is a fairly flat 3.1 miles (5K). The course is paved, therefore strollers or baby joggers are allowed on the course. In addition for safety purposes no skateboards, roller blades/skates, bicycles, or animals can be taken on the course. Also note, this race will officially end at 1:45 therefore, anyone that is not finished at that time will need to follow traffic rules and regulations. Police officers will be done directing traffic after 1:45Pm. 

Chip timing provided by RaceWire. Top male (s) and female (s) finishers in each age group TBD at time of raceT-Shirts 
First 250 to registered get free t-shirt 

There will be dri-fit t-shirts sold on-site.Parking 
Parking available at City Streets at their NEW location, 411 Waverley Oaks Rd., Waltham.Ammenities 
Refreshments after race will be at City Streets (across street from The Fernald School, Waverley Oaks Rd.). Race timing provided by Racewire.com. Results posted immediately after race at City Streets.Race Day Infromation 
NOTE: We strongly encourage you to register on-line prior to race day. Registration will close online on Thursday November 19th at 10:00 pm. You can still register Friday night 4-9 pm at City Streets, at their NEW LOCATION 411 Waverley Oaks Rd., Waltham Ma. Bib pick up will also be at City Streets from 4-9pm. If you are unable to pick your bib up on Friday night, you will be able to register and pick up your bibs day of race from 11-12:40. We do strongly encourage you to pick up your bib and your friends bibs Friday night!! Thanks! 

NOTE: For those that will go beyond 1:45pm time you will need to follow traffic rules and regulations ie: using sidewalk and and using crosswalks. We look forward to seeing you on race day! 

www.wickedfunrunning.com

results.description:
PURCHASE TICKETS HERE: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/raspberry-pi-workshop-tickets-15627198371

Would you like to run your own complete Media Center for your home? How about a video game console with hundreds or thousands of games loaded on it? What about your own remote file and media server accessible from any computer or mobile phone? GPS enabled camera for your car? Or how about Home Automation? If so, you should learn how to master the Raspberry Pi.

"The Raspberry Pi is a credit-card sized computer that plugs into your TV and a keyboard. It is a capable little computer which can be used in electronics projects, and for many of the things that your desktop PC does, like spreadsheets, word-processing and games. It also plays high-definition video."

In this workshop you'll learn the following:

Learn the basics of setting up Raspbian OS on your Raspberry Pi.

Learn some basic Linux commands to help with using your Raspberry Pi

Learn how to interact with the GPIO pins on your Raspberry Pi to light and LED and read from a button


Instructor: Mike Rushton
results.name: Raspberry Pi Workshop
